reviewText:
It is clear that the extra time they put into the pc port of this game was worth it.

The graphics settings are much greater than the two prior iterations, however at least in the first hour of gameplay, there have not been any bugs or glitches. The game runs at a consistant 60 fps on maxed out 1080p settings on my GTX 970.

So far, it seems that holding off and waiting for the pc release of this game was certainly worth it!

reviewText:
Most of the reviews out there touch upon technical details of the PC port, leaving the substance of the game alone. I aim to fix that.

First off, let me confirm everything you heard so far about the quality of the port itself - it's really the best one by far by Square Enix. It's smooth, it looks better than on consoles, there is a higher variety of visual options. The port includes all DLC and both English and Japanese audio.

Now, let's move on to the reason I even decided to write this in the first place: the game itself.
Is it good? In short: Very.

At this point, I've spent a little more than 6 hours in it, and I already feel like it managed to justify the price.

The story is pretty good so far, that said, it is very important that you play FF XIII and XIII-2 first, otherwise many many things will be lost on you.

The combat system is probably the most dynamic and player-inclusive in the FFXIII trilogy. It feels quite responsive and your own skill matters quite a lot.

The music is very good, unlike XIII-2. I am yet to find a piece that drives me nuts, like Unseen Intruders, which is a good sign.

The world is gigantic in this game, and it's very non-linear at that.

Now, the dreaded time-limit. I understand that many of you hate the very idea of it, and I was one of you, but now that I tried it, I have to say: the feature is solid. The need for time-management grants the gameplay a sense of urgency and pacing that translates to you feeling on the edge. You experience something similar when you have a last sliver of health in games like Dark Souls. The tensions is exquisite. Completing quests in the game actually allows you to postpone the timelimit, which gives you very real insentive to be efficient. Every day at 6 AM (game time) you are returned to the hub area, and you can see your progress. Let me tell you, when you get there and see that all your actions were not in naught, all the tense gameplay of the day pays off tenfold.

So, yes, I do recommend this game, the only caveat being: If you played XIII and XIII-2 first".

9/10 so far. Will edit if my opinion changes.

Edit #1.

28 hours in. The gameplay is still solid

reviewText:
Following FF13-2 and 13-1, Lightning Returns with a new battle system and an open world concept. It features a day/night cycle that dictate npc interactions and serves as a constant reminder of how much time has been spent. The story was mediocre and aimed too high. However the cinematic story rendering was fantastic and the voice acting was well done (English).

Small gripes I had with this game - Firstly I felt the day/night countdown timer really made players hardpressed to find efficient quest completion routes. If you are a relaxed and slow player like myself, you might not be able to progress far enough into the game to defeat the last boss. My second issue was with the characters and the actual story. I felt the storytelling in Snow's and Noel's storylines were languid. Their motivation in the game weren't realistic and didn't support their original actions against the protagonist. Lumina's behavour was also perplexing, her attitude flip-flopped and you couldn't tell when she was was lying or telling the truth. The story becomes even more unrelatable when you're forced to trust in something she says, given her history of messing with you.
Finally the overarching story aimed too high and simply fell short of my expectations. The final boss and the the wrap-up all felt a little too forced as Lightning, storywise, was shown to be more impressive in comparison to the final boss, a notion that wasn't conveyed properly through the cinematics.

However, despite these gripes, Lightning Returns does conclude the stories of FF13-1&2 in a meaningful satisfactory manner. 8/10. Pick this game up only if you've invested in the first two installments.

reviewText:
This is my first review, so please bear with me.

I'll start by saying that the game was a 14.3 GB download, and the size on the disk for me is 20.6 GB. The version I purchased here in North America included both English and Japanese voice options. The game also came packaged with a fairly decent amount of graphical options compared to the two previous installments.

The graphics options are as follows:
Display Format (Choose between Windowed or Borderless fullscreen)
Display Resolution (1920 x 1080, 1600 x 900, 1440 x 810, 1366 x 768, 1280 x 720)
Scale Display Area
Colour Correction
Glare Adjustment
Depth of Field Adjustment
Shadowing
Lighting
Texture Filtering
Frame Rate (Choose between fixed 30, or Dynamic 60)

The included DLC is very nice, but quite overpowered. It makes the boss battles super easy, so I advise using normal equipment if it's your first playthrough to avoid ruining the enjoyment of the game. I believe most of the DLC is included in the game as well, minus the Aerith garb.

Finally, the performance of the game is pretty good on my end. I'm running a mostly smooth 60fps on the highest possible graphical settings. The framerate never drops below 60 in battles, and seemingly only drops in the open world when you're loading in a new area, or many new NPC at once. Even then, it only lasts for 1-2 seconds for me.

All in all, this game is a really good port. It's quite a step up from the previous two games in the series. Square Enix taking the extra time to release it made a large difference in the quality. It's an even larger step up from the console versions, and I would highly recommend any fans of the series to give this a go. It's easily worth the $17.99

reviewText:
I went into this game with very low expectations, having played Final Fantasy XIII for about 12 hours before giving up on its linear dungeons that simply required me to move from A to B while killing monsters in the process. I was pleasantly surprised to find that Lightning Returns is a far superior experience overall.

To begin with, the world opens up fairly quickly, letting you explore four different hub areas and interact with the NPCs there, from vendors to quest givers, imbuing your character with a sense of freedom that was sorely lacking in XIII. The story is more focused, taking Lightning on a journey to save the souls of mankind before the world comes to an end, but building on that simple premise by adding layers of intrigue through the character of Lumina.

Another positive is how side quests are tied to this story (main is a given), as Lightning will have to undertake personal quests to save souls and learn a little bit more about herself in the process. Nevertheless, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the Canvas of Prayers' quests that basically have you running around collecting materials for anonymous people.

Since the world is coming to an end it makes sense that there's a ticking clock haunting your every step. At first glance this will undoubtedly come across as a huge negative but the game itself provides you with the means to stall that clock in a variety of ways. First, as you gather souls you collect something called Eradia, what can be used to add more days to the clock. Furthermore, you have an ability in-game called Chronostasis that will let you freeze the clock for thirty in-game minutes. If you're still doubtful, start on easy and you can pretty much forget about that clock. On the plus side, the passage of time allows the game to make the hub areas more dynamic; unlocking areas, vendors, quest givers, and even events, during specific times, building on the illusion that this is a living, breathing, world you're in.

Combat reprises the XIII formula with the ATB system but enhances it via schematas. Schematas are essentially builds you can create comprised of garbs, weapons, accessories, and abilities. During battle you can switch between three different schematas, each with its own ATB bar, what gives you more leeway when dealing with a variety of enemies. Furthermore, both abilities and weapons can be upgraded throughout the game, though the latter only on NG+.

If it helps, I found myself sinking a lot of time into this game without even realizing it. What impressed me the most, personally, was its gripping story and actually interesting and relevant side quests. You also don't need to have played the previous games to enjoy or even understand what's going on in this one as the game does a pretty good job of laying out the background. Ironically, Lightning Returns is, to my mind, a much better entry point than XIII ever was. The ending can be a bit confusing, I'll give you that, and does have a Return of the King-esque feeling to it, but I found it immensely satisfying.

So, if you want to get into Final Fantasy in general, or the Lightning Trilogy in particular, give Lightning Returns a shot. Like me, it could be the game you were looking for.

reviewText:
This is a very tough negative review for me to write, because Lightning Returns does so many things right but it also narrowly misses on some very important things.

Lightning Returns succeeds on every technical level.  The graphics are gorgeous, the music is good, and LR has received the best PC port of any Square Enix game to date. It runs flawlessly and even has full Japanese interface available for bilinguals like myself. It is by all means an excellent game on many fronts, and a drastic improvement over its predecessors.

That said, Lightning Returns is direly lacking in both story and gameplay depth. Let's start with the story: It is quite simply eye-rollingly bad. Almost every single line of dialogue is hopelessly contrived at best and laughable at worst. In the interest of avoiding spoilers I'm not going to go too far into details, but my eyes start to glaze over when the major characters are all constantly making melodramatic monologues about how they've been lovesick for 500 years.

To make matters worse, everyone's problems that they've been dealing with for 500(!!) years are MAGICALLY resolved by Lightning Ex Machina because all it takes is a 10 minute chat with Lightning and maybe a fight or two and all 500-year-long issues are instantly resolved. There is no nice way of saying it: it's awful writing that makes Lightning come dangerously close to Mary Sue territory. Which is a real shame because I love Lightning and she has some genuinely great moments.

Another massive issue is that the game is very short. Imagine my surprise when I checked a FAQ to see my progress about 10 hours in and discovered I was over 40% done with the main quest. The main story is astonishingly short and then you're supposed to spend the rest of the time running around doing random side quests before the final boss.

Then there's the battle system. At first blush it seems quite engaging and deep but the problem is that this is actually a massive façade. There is in reality very little strategy or depth to the system at all. I kept waiting for them to introduce new elements that mix it up or keep things interesting but it pretty much stays the same way through the entire game, and that boils down to this:

A) Read stagger conditions/try to stagger the enemy
B) Block when they attack

That's literally it. Stagger conditions and weaknesses vary depending on the enemy but for the massive majority of the game you can get by just spamming whatever and blocking occasionally and you will be fine. I really feel like if the player had been given FULL control of Lightning in battle instead of very limited control that it could have introduced a new dimension of depth to the game that would have kept it feeling fresh.

Overall I have to say though that Lightning Returns is a beautiful game that does so many things right but falls tragically short of being a great game. It may be the right game for someone else, but it just left me wanting more.

reviewText:
As a PC Port, this is definitely the best of the lot. PC players will remember the multitude of crashes that pestered XIII and XIII-2. I played this game on the PS3 and loved it, clocking over 200 hours on it.

All core gameplay remains the same, and Square Enix has rather generously given access to all DLC except the Aerith set. You're really not losing out on anything special. Outerworld has been disabled on the Steam port, making it potentially more difficult for PC players as they can't get Turbo Ethers and Ethers off random NPCs. As mentioned before, DLC does make up for this by providing fairly overpowered equipment. If you want to experience the game with some challenge, try not to use Yuna's Summoner Garb and Cloud's Soldier 1st Class.

I hate the fact that you can't truly customize your key assignments. This port forces you to bind keys to the PS3/Xbox configuration, such that Jump/O/A. Full customization of FFXIII and XIII-2 was possible. Why not here? This is arguably more important for LR, where button preses are even more important than past games. If you don't have a Numpad, you're going to find it difficult to find space to bind keys into a comfortable configuration.

First, some background. Lightning has awoken from crystal stasis 500 years after Chaos flooded the world. When Chaos flooded the world, it had the side effect of stopping humans from aging. Humans did not age, and thus no longer died of old age. They could, however, still be killed by monsters, or die of disease. Lightning was awoken by God, Bhunivelze, to be the saviour. Her duty is to save souls from the remnants of the world so that they can be reborn in the new world that Bhunivelze is creating. Lightning has 13 Days to fulfill her duty before the world ends.

Now let's address the content. Lightning Returns is completely unchanged from the PS3/Xbox version. So let's look at some of the graphics: The NPCs don't look great, the dogs look horrendous. However, the environments bring across each individual theme well. Lightning, however, is of course well animated, although there's some visible tearing in her hair when Lightning touches the crest on her chest where her L'cie mark used to be.

Story: One of the main issues with this particular installment of Lightning Returns is the terrible English translation which ends up contradicting itself. The English localisation does not differentiate between 'Heart' (Kokoro) and 'Soul' (Tamashi). This is a key point of contention within the mythos, and has to be cleared up. As a result, I highly recommend having audio in Japanese and reading the English subtitles. However, always keep an ear out for the above two Japanese terms, 'Kokoro' and 'Tamashi', as the English translation makes no distinction between the two.

Characters: One of the most obvious problems since XIII has been the bland, one dimensional characters. While we may be tempted to continue the bashing, there actually is justification for a one-dimensional character this time around. Imagine if you've lived for 500 years with no true end in sight. No new lives are being born, and death is common. Nothing changes. You'd be depressed too. Each character has their own motivations, but they all end up the same. I'm in despair

reviewText:
Lightning Returns takes place after storyline of Final Fantasy XIII-2. I have played the entire trilogy and will briefly review them here to give perspective on where Lightning Returns stands.

Final Fantasy XIII:
TL;DR Fun and charming story with some very hateable companions and lacklust gameplay. 60hours worth of run to a yellow dot, hit 2 buttons for autobattle, and watch melodramatic cutscenes.

Final Fantasy XIII-2:
TL;DR Open world FFXIII with pokemons. Forced storyline that made an originally complete and charming fairy tale from FFXIII completely nonsensical.

Final Fantasy Lightning Returns:
TL:DR: Lightning is back with actual player controlled combat and no more pokemons. Doom clock ticking down to 0? Better go plant some more herbs.

Pros:
- GREAT PC port. Perhaps mechanically one of the best PC port of all time.
- You get to play as Lightning again! (Experience may vary.)
- You have direct control of all of your character's moves in real time! It controls well and makes game genuinely fun to play.
- Combat is actually challenging now and you need learn to block.
- With the new clock system, you have an actual sense of urgency to the story line. But not enough urgency to skip the sheep herding or flower planting apparently.
- All the  50 shades of grey monsters are gone. You no longer have 3 different colored behemoth running around for no good reason.
- 4 very different land scapes with diverse biomes to explores.
- Monsters go extinct when you kill enough of them, which is awesome.
- Better music.
- No more annoying whiny ♥♥♥♥♥ companions.

Cons:
- No more pokemons :(
- No more companions (meh)
- Lots of running and you need to min-max the most efficient routes constantly.
- Scope of the game isn't nearly as big as FFXIII.
- Story is rushed and you are tieing loose ends left and right with very unsatisfying final quests.
- Plot line is genuinely uninteresting and poorly paced. Story feels very rushed and poorly polished. It follows up to FFXIII-2 plotline and is genuinely worse.

column22: and the enemies hit hard. The window for getting enhanced attacks is even smaller - so small that I gave up on it almost immediately. (To be fair
column23: it doesn't seem that enhanced attacks are really core to successful gameplay.)\n\nFurther adding to the difficulty of battle is the way resource management works. You start out with a very limited stack of carryable restoration items
column24: and a similarly shallow pool of EP. Your EP is sort of your "safety net
column25:
because you can cast curative magic from it. Where things get hairy is that EP is also your pool for attacking powerfully, and for all practical purposes, you can NOT restore EP with your item inventory. (There are ethers in the game, but they are as rare as megalixirs were in other titles.) You restore EP by winning battles, but winning battles can be quite pyrrhic: A difficult encounter can burn through all your items and all your EP, leaving you with nothing in reserve for the next face-off.

You have to fight to progress, but fighting is actually pretty dangerous.

If you get into a really tight spot, you can escape from a battle and get your used items back, but escape costs some of your limited time.

All this creates a nasty ball of frustration, especially at the beginning of the game. You don't really have a handle on how long things are going to take to do, so you don't know if you're taking too long to do them, There's no indication of exactly how much is required to extend the world's time, and the go-where-you-want nature of the game means that you can waste precious hours in finding out that you're just not ready for a major encounter. (The only way to find out is the hard way.) If you're like me, you end up being very tense about everything that doesn't go well, because running out of time means starting over. From the beginning of the game. (!)

As a motivator and tension builder, it's incredibly effective. It can also be not very fun.

The good news is that things get a lot better as Lightning strengthens. As that happens, and you get some wins, the tension begins to ease. That's when you can really start to appreciate just how tightly woven the whole thing is. I might even go so far as to call the game a masterpiece of interlocking mechanics.

A pretty darn difficult masterpiece, but still.

When you do find the groove

you'll have many hours of enjoyable questing in the world. You'll even get good at the time-management aspects.

+ Option between Japanese and English

Cons - Limited options for graphics settings.

- The time perception, even though theres plenty of time to do them, It tricks your mind into thinking you REALLY need to do it when it is very lax. It just ruins immersion for some. Gotta do all main quest to get real ending. (Its all in your mind)

and yes, I ran this on a Titan X.

reviewText:
Did Final Fantasy XIII had to be a trilogy? Probably not.

But Square Enix did a better job of porting this title compared to the other two entries.

Pros
Good pc port of the game.
1080p + 60 fps.
No launcher. The game starts directly.
Decent number of graphical options.
All console dlc (except 1) is included in the download and can be toggled on or off in the options.
English and Japanese VO.
Combat is more action oriented than turn based this time around and fun.
Multiple combat actions, outfits+coloring, weapons, shields and accessories to suit your play style.
New game +.
Multiple side quests to find and complete.
4 big maps to explore.
Neutral
Can't keep ultima weapon & ultima shield when starting new game +.
Lots of different cloating is nice, but it makes it look like a ''dress up my Claire ''Lightning'' Farron'' sim (that also made her pose as a fashion model for Square Enix later on).
Some of the VO for the civilians and quest givers feels out of place.
Questionable start for the game imo if you consider the epilogue of the previous entry.
Cons
Can't rename your chocobo or Schemas like you can on consoles.
Story becomes a bit questionable at parts.
To be updated and score to be given when the end credits is reached.

reviewText:
Forget everything you have heard of this game. I believe the most of official critics really don't understand the game.

Pros:
- Great soundtrack - The best since PSone FF titles
- Tons of costumes
- Very fun and strategic battle/schematic system
- Well-done animations and dialogs
- Beautiful ending

Cons:
- Very very bad textures - maybe because the low GPU memory of old gen consoles
- Better than FFXIII and FFXIII-2, but still poor otimization. Extreme lag when surrounded by many NPC's
- EXP system - you don't receive EXP after battle, but completing quests
- All your old friends wear the same clothes and haircuts after 500 years...


The more controversial question is about time limit. There's no need to worry about it. You have 13 days to complete the game. Using the Chronostasis ability wisely, I have finished all the main quest in day 4, and 65 quests on day 8. You can play over 100 hour of gameplay in 13 days.

Veredict: 9/10 - Play it!
voteText: 45 of 57 people (79%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This is my first review for a game I have been waiting for over half a year. TLDR at the end.

Good things overall:

- It's a good game.
- It's not perfect, but it's a good port.
- Good price.
- Good cards.
- Achievements are not hard (+100 hours if you want all of them)
- Most DLCs included.

Good ingame mechanics:

- Lightning.
- NG+ system like in Dark Souls II
- Tons of items and garbs to get.
- Tons of quests to do.
- Tons of monsters to exterminate.
- You can switch schemata mid attacks and do A LOT of combos, which makes the game more than just atackattackattack, switch and repeat.
- The days system is not bad, it's just that most FF games are endless. This one is just different.
- You only grind gil, you won't need to slay specific monsters for most missions as you will get the items eventually.
- Missions are only hard if you don't explore (on a sandbox game, duh)
- Game encourages you to go to NG+ to get upgrades and other items.

Not so good ingame mechanics:

- Game is only hard (but enjoyable) during NG on normal mode. It will be REALLY easy on NG+ even if you play on hard mode.
- Enemies don't scale on each playthrough, while you do, The game becomes easier and easier the more you play. I'm on NG+ on hard and only final bosses and last ones are challenging... sometimes.
- Some garbs are better versions of other existing ones, and others are niche and would require a complete garb setup to work.
- Aeronite is a ♥♥♥♥♥.
- Ereshkigal is a ♥♥♥♥♥.
- Most weapons and shields are just enhaced versions of previous ones.

Note: Game tends to crash sometimes in the Dead Dunes laberynths for some reason.

TL;DR: Tons of stuff to do, good replayability potential, but it eventually becomes too easy because monsters don't scale and it starts to get boring. Lightning is love.

I'm seriously waiting for a mod to make enemies scale on each playthrough, it's the only thing keeping me away from wasting 1k hours in this game.

reviewText:
Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII (ライトニング リターンズ ファイナルファンタジーXIII) is action role-playing video game developed and published by Square Enix. The game is a direct sequel to Final Fantasy XIII-2, concludes the storyline of Final Fantasy XIII, and forms part of the Fabula Nova Crystallis subseries. Lightning Returns employs a highly revamped version of the gameplay system from the previous two games, with an action-oriented battle system, the ability to customize the player character's outfits, and a time limit the player must extend by completing story missions and side quests.

The game's story takes place five hundred years after the previous game's ending. Lightning, the main protagonist of the first game and a key character in the second, awakes from a self-imposed hibernation 13 days before the world's end, and is chosen by the deity Bhunivelze to save the people of the dying world, including former friends and allies who have developed heavy emotional burdens. As she travels, she learns the full truth behind both the world's fate and Bhunivelze's true agenda.

( Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lightning_Returns:_Final_Fantasy_XIII )

Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII is a wonderful game. The story of the game is interesting. If you enjoyed the previous FFXIII games, when you will enjoy this one too. As always the final boss is a God and he is pretty tough opponent. The ending is beautiful and Lightning's smile is especially heartwarming. In game the time is limited and at first I felt like I have to rush all the time, but little by little I felt more comfortable with the clock and the good thing is that the time can be extended. Story missions are quite good and while the story develops further, you will be able to meet game characters from the previous FFXIII games. I like that the side quests has their own little stories and it doesn't feel like it's a 'hollow' quest. Some side quests are directly connected to the main story. There are also Canvas Of Prayers quest that are kind of boring. Those quests are 'hollow'. Basically you only have to defeat monsters and bring back the stuff. The music is very beautiful and fitting to the mood of the game. The visuals are nice and the style of surounding is sweet.

Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII has a lot of freedom compared to the previous games. The map is quite big and to complete the story you don't have to complete the quests from 1 to 5. The point is that the order doesn't matter. Another good thing is that there are a few ways to travel form one point to another. You can use trains, teleport and ride chocobo in one of the regions. When the game will be completed, the new feature will be unlocked. It's New Game +. As in most games the character's stats will be the same, new difficulty will be unlocked. Also it will be possible to upgrade your weapons. The interesting thing is that if you decide to figh a boss in early days, thIs boss will have one form, while if in the next playtrough you decide to fight the same boss in the end, this boss will look differently and also he will be stronger. Instead of Paradigm fighting system this game has a new system called Schemata. Lightning will be able to change her costumes while fighting the enemy. The thing is that this power reminds me of Erza's Requip Magic from Fairy Tail. One more different thing is that in the battle recovery items are very limited and it makes the game a bit more challenging. Most of the time you will be fighting alone, but at some points you will be able to fight together with chocobo and Fang. The controls are good. I played with Xbox controller and it was very comfortable.

Final Fantasy XIII has 6 playable characters and each of them has 1 costume. Final Fantasy XIII-2 has 3 playable characters. 2 of them has 4 costumes and the other one has only 1 costume. Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII has 1 playable character and she has over 80 costumes. Well that escalated quickly. In game costumes are called garbs. These garbs have different stats and the colors can be customized. There are also DLC garbs. To unlock them you have to go to settings and enable it. DLC containts costumes from FFVII, FFX-2 and FFXIII games. Also there is costume from Tomb Raider. Some garbs are very sexy, others are badass and some are just adorable. To make your character a bit more stylish you will be able to choose from a lot of adornments. Also I like that the variety of weapons is very big.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=646008014
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=644818529
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=644394857

To sum up I can say that Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII is one of the best JRPGs on steam. I really enjoyed the game and I think that game's price is pretty good compared to the quality of the game you get. If you are a fan of Final Fantasy games, when you should get this game even for a full price.

For me this is the best game I have played so far.

Final Fantasy XIII review: http://steamcommunity.com/id/DespairAndFear/recommended/292120/

reviewText:
As most of the other reviews have mentioned, this port is pretty good in terms of performance compared to the previous two games in the series. It runs better and looks better, and though people with higher-end monitors might be disappointed with the 1080p/60fps limit (I personally have a 144hz monitor so it's a bit of a downer), it's nothing worth complaining about in my opinion. I am, however, disappointed by the fact that there are no mouse controls, at all. Why they waited for the third game to remove them is beyond me, but the game is a mess to play unless you have a gamepad to the point that if you don't have a gamepad you may as well stop reading here. The game also requires you to activate the Steam Cloud in order to play, which doubles as more-or-less of an always online requirement, which may bother some people. I found this annoying because I really don't like using the half-baked feature that is the Steam Cloud, but not enough to prevent me from playing.

In terms of gameplay, Lightning Returns is a pretty dramatically different game from its predecessors in a lot of ways, with the big one being that the world is ending in 13 days. Rather than just being a plot point, this is an actual timer in the game, similar to Dead Rising. The actual timer itself only counts down six days, and you have to extend the clock by doing side quests and helping others pass on into the next world until the full 13 days have passed. The timer isn't enough of a threat for me to imagine anyone being turned off by it, and if you manage your time well you'll still have plenty of exploration time, but it does add a nice pressure to it that gives the game a unique feeling. If you don't manage to do everything the first time, there is a New Game+ option, which gives the slower or more thorough players a chance to see everything the game has to offer as well. The game is full of quests, both main ones and side ones, and even the main quests can be tackled in any order due to the game being a fully open world from the start, with the only limitation being the tougher monsters in certain areas. Monsters can be killed to the point of extinction, discouraging farming and encouraging you to fight for your right to have a peaceful nature hike through the Jagd Woods or even just kill every monster on the planet if you're feeling particularly full of determination. The overall frame of the game sort of feels like a less forgiving Majora's Mask, and while a lot of people seem to be against it I really like this system.

The other big difference is the combat. The combat is now far more action-oriented; you don't move around much, but there are no turns, and instead of controlling a party you control Lightning alone and swap between 3 outfits, each with 4 attacks you can assign. The new system feels both smoother and faster, and you get in and out of small fights a lot faster due to the lack of unnecessarily long intros and outros. The same tactics from the previous games are all here, but now they feel more active, with many things requiring timing and strategy to do instead of just choosing the same attack order every turn. This is all aided by the fact that there's no longer a leveling system, removing the urge to grind entirely and allowing you to actually fight because you want to fight something instead of fighting everything because you need the experience. You upgrade your equipment instead, through various methods such as combining spells to increase their power or changing outfits with different stats.

The story is where Lightning Returns falters somewhat. The game only introduces one new character, and the returning characters get painfully little time to do much of anything except for Hope, who serves as your guide. The main quest itself is pretty shallow, and instead the game focuses primarily on the content of the side quests, which isn't necessarily a bad thing since a fair amount of them are pretty interesting in their own right, but it's a shame that the characters they spent two games buildling up get more or less sidelined for the grand finale, with some of my favorites being outright benched and getting less than a minute or two of total screentime. The overall plotline isn't bad by any means, but I just didn't find it as interesting as XIII-2, and I felt like they could've done more with the returning cast to make the end of this series more exciting.

Overall, Lightning Returns is a pretty great game and mechanically my favorite in the series by far, and even though there's plenty of room for improvement it's already worth playing in its own right. If the port woes don't scare you away, there's no reason not to finish the series if you're already this deep into the XIII trilogy.

reviewText:
Lightning Returns, starring everyone's favourite rose colored hair protagonist!
The world is submerged into chaos and it won't be long till the end of the world. It is up to our old pal Lightning to save the day (or is it days?)
Lightning, who slumbered for 500 years is awakened by the god of light Bhunivelze. The world isn't like she hoped it would be, the people are stuck in a world ruled by chaos, they do not age, but they are still able to die from diseases. Bhunivelze gives Lighning the task and power to save their souls so that they can be born again on a new world created by the almighty god of light. Lightning seeing her efforts were in vain sets foot again on a quest to save her sister Serah.
She soon meets her old partner Snow, who knows she's sent by god and isn't so willingy to hand over his soul and questions Lightning's beliefs. So, after a little fight Lightning retreats, while so she meets a mysterious young girl named Lumina who only she can see and hear, her role in this story very important and and she frequently shows up to help Lightning, in her own mischief ways and remind her what she's fighting for. Who Lumina really is, is something that you can find out pretty early if you use your wits. Lightning herself will stay dumbstruck till the end of the game and when she finally figures it out you get a relieved satisfactory feeling.
Lightning will meet many of her old friends on her journy to save the souls, some want to fight her, one just doesn't give one f*** and others welcome her with open arms! Lightning helps them get a hold of themselves by helping out with serious troubles, something they couldn't figure out on their own. Which brings me to something I noticed. There are quests that involve a children who lost their things, one lost her stuffed animal, another lost his ball. In both instances the belongings are literally 30 feet away from them and family disputes which could easily be solved by talking to each other, but instead it took a middle woman a.k.a. Lightning to go back and forth delivering messages. Wheter these people got realy lazy because of the chaos or if it was the developers who couldn't come up with better quests will be a question I don't know how to answer.

So far, there aren't too many main quest, you can finnish these quite fast. The game revolves about a timed based kind of gameplay. The world as we know it will end in a couple of days and it is Lightning's task to save as many souls before they are lost forever. In order to save people's souls Lightning has to help these troubled people across the world, which usually  translate to fetch quests and defeat xx number of enemies or talk to a person. Completing these quests mostly end up in a follow up quests. Once you successfully complete a quest you will be awarded xp and unique items and the person's soul. At 6AM the day is over and you will return to The Ark"

reviewText:
+ Better port than XIII and XIII-2 (smooth performance and more graphical options)
+ Graphics and design improvements over XIII-2
+ Interesting and polished battle system
+ Actual open world
+ More content than XIII-2, I daresay as much as XII if not more
+ The clock is not as bad as people put it
+ Interesting concept with the story
+ Has its own enjoyable atmosphere

- The story doesn't have the best of presentations
- Just like in XIII-2, the atmosphere presented in XIII was completely lost
- Battle system can be difficult to master
- Although much better than XIII and XIII-2 when it comes to performance, still presents some issues
- Uses Steam cloud as a DRM (futile as its been cracked within hours of release)

Verdict: I played 7h straight right after it finished downloading. As I was expecting, Nova Chrysalia got my heart. Lightning Returns is a true open world Final Fantasy with places to explore and a bunch of content to keep the player entertained. At first I thought the time limit would drive me mad, but it turns out I was able to explore, run side quests and follow with the storyline smoothly without having to worry about how much time I had left. As someone who enjoyed the story and atmosphere of XIII, however, I was again disappointed at the sequel. I feel like LR could've been its own thing instead of a sequel since its story feels completely unrelated to XIII (it is instead an epilogue to XIII-2, which also felt like it could've been its own thing) and revisiting the characters doesn't strike the possibly intended feelings. I recently started to really understand the atmosphere and I think now it works very well. It's still not the feeling I liked from XIII, but it's done right. After rubbing shoulders with Vanille for a little while I realized that the characters we encounter from other games are distant bc that's just how relationships work over time. People drift apart and I can't possibly imagine how distant from people I know I'd be after 500 years.

Other than my beef with the atmosphere, it's a very polished game well worth the price if you're looking for an open world RPG with a considerable amount of content. Gorgeous designs, polished mechanics and runs smoothly enough. Steam cloud being used as a DRM doesn't bother me cos Steam is a DRM itself and my internet is always on, so I never even saw the initial message regarding the system. I do hope Square Enix changes that and I understand people who are offended by that, but at the same time I don't have personal problems with it.

I played this game back on my Xbox and I had fun with it but never completed it. I felt put off from the time constraint of the game.

Pros:     Combat is fun.
The voice acting is good.
The story is interesting and I hope to finish it this time.
It is ported fairly well.
The price is very cheap.
It includes all the DLC minus the Aerith DLC.
It features characters from the previous Final Fantasy games, and to my knowledge their voice actors (Though I haven't checked).
Mixed:     The game has a time constraint in it, you have 13 days to save the world (Although you start off with 6, doing side quests adds more days if I remember correctly). I think a second in real time is a minute in game time. Some people like this features and others don't, I am mixed about it. It adds to the story and immersion which is good, but I hate feeling like I have to play the game a certain way, like I'm forced to do things in specific way; I feel restricted. Luckily there is a trainer out there that will allow you to freeze time should you want to, alternatively, there is a feature in game that allows you to temporarily freeze in game time.

reviewText:
I’ll be honest with you. I bought Lightning Returns primarily for the dress up, and my expectations weren’t high. While I wasn’t a fan of FF XIII, and even less of a fan of it’s confused, malformed sequel, you couldn’t fault either game for their excellent selection of high quality, glossy lipped and slightly dead eyed Japanese dolls. The producers of Lightning Returns seem to have realised this and baked it into the marketing campaign with all the subtlety of a cruise missile aimed at a nunnery.

What will come as something of a surprise to many then is that the game is not the car crash disaster it by all rights should have been, though it is heavily flawed. Lightning Returns is a good example of why steam needs a middle ground rating – I can’t honestly give it a thumbs up, not without serious caveats but dismissing it entirely is every bit as unjust.

The core conceit in particular is both original and compelling – God is going to end the world in seven days in order to create a new one, being evidently based on the bored bi-polar sociopath of the Old Testament. You as the hero can do nothing to stop this – all you can do is save as many souls of those in this world as you can, so that they may be reborn in the next. There’s a further wrinkle to this - no-one has been born in 500 years, but equally no-one can die of old age. However, people may still be killed by other traditional means such as disease, misadventure or good fashioned suicide. This sets up a nihilistic Children of Men-esque world covered in a thick malaise of apathy, offset by a tense race against time as you do what you can to save what little hope is left.

This being based on the characters and premises of FF XIII, this potential is of course completely squandered. The story is borderline incomprehensible at best, a train wreck with no survivors at worst. Set 1000 years after the first game, Lightning is awoken from cryosleep by God and has agreed to be the world’s soul collecting saviour with the hook that her sister Serah is reborn in the next world. But she’s also had her emotions removed, the reasons of which are never adequately explained, so why she should be moved by this emotional plea is unclear. Removing your main character’s personality as well as driving motivation doesn’t sound like a recipe for entertaining drama without a careful writer at the helm. Sadly the writing is roughly on par with the last two games – which is to say it’s crushingly, wincingly awful. All of the characters you either loathe or barely remember make their melodramatic, floppy haired return, and chew their way through dialogue so purple it would make Anne Rice blush.

Word of advice – set the language to Japanese. All credit to the English voice actors, they do the best they can with the material they’re served but this is hot, George Lucus tier garbage and not understanding the words being spoken adds a comforting, brain shielding barrier between player and script. Your comlink companion Hope (also thankfully de-emotioned) never shuts the ♥♥♥♥ up either, and in English his repeated dialogue goes from irritating to excruciating very quickly indeed.

So it’s down to the mechanics to save the whole show, and I personally found the game quite compelling in spite of its shortcomings. The impact of the time limit on this game can not be overstated. Make no mistake, this is an absolute core part of the game that cannot be ignored in any way, shape or form. You have six in game days to finish the whole thing, with an hour of game time being roughly equal to a real-world minute. You have a limited supply of EP (I forget what it actually is, so I’m going to assume it refers to Lightning’s collection of Emerson Lake & Palmer records) that can be used to stop time for about three real world minutes – EP is regained slowly, typically by killing baddies. Time management is absolutely crucial, and it is a massive barrier to relaxed exploration. If this sounds like a deal breaker to you, I would not recommend this game regardless of how much you want to see Lightning in her knickers.

In terms of freedom, Lightning Returns finally gets the balance right after the hand holding corridor of FFXIII and the borderline cryptic non-linearity of the sequel. There are four large areas, each containing their own main quest as well as a series of side quests that can be tackled in any order, though enemies do get tougher in the larger, more open sections. The side quests are of particular import – Lightning does not level up by fighting monsters (the lazy cow) and instead gains flat bonuses by completing these quests. They’re of a variable quality – there is a literal “find my dog” quest, but there are some nice multi-tiered interwoven quests that don’t inhale dong in there as well. The time limit alongside a general lack of waypoints can make this aspect of the game quite frustrating, and I feel that they should have made these more optional – you will have to complete a sizable number if you want to have hope of beating the bosses or even some of the tougher basic enemies.

A word of warning - The game is surprisingly difficult, and demands you learn its mechanics quickly. You will need to learn how to block quickly, or you will die, frequently and unceremoniously to even the lowliest of enemies. You will not be able to muddle through things on the default difficulty –Every loss results in a loss of a precious hour from the in game clock. The first boss in particular is a wake up call, and they only get harder from there – seriously consider starting on easy if action games are not your forte, though it should be noted that if you do so your future descendants will feel your gaming shame.

The battle system is fantastic once you get the hang of it though. This is by far the most action orientated of any of the FF games, with nary a menu to be seen. You control only Lightning this time, but she can switch between three different costumes at will – when one is in use, the ATB gauges of the others will recharge faster. While each costume has different abilities and stats, you’re largely free to customise their active abilities as you wish. There’s a bewildering number of costumes and accessories available, and those wanting skimpy bikinis might want to temper their expectations- while those exist, they’re vastly outnumbered by the range of much more tasteful outfits. This is probably for the best, as Lightning is built like a 15 year old boy with two oranges in a bra – her bottom is Isaac Clarke levels of flat. Flatter than Master Chief. Flatter than Sigourney Weaver in Alien. I’m not some kind of badonkadonk zealot, but this is heartbreaking stuff.

reviewText:
Square Enix's most underrated game that every RPG buff should experience
Let me start by saying that I dropped FFXIII halfway and couldn't even stomach pass the first area of FFXIII-2. Confusing plot, mundane gameplay, annoying characters; the list goes on endlessly. I'm a massive Final Fantasy fan (played all the numbered entries, some spinoffs and currently clocking 1000 hours on FFXIV) but FFXIII and its sequel is a steaming pile of disappointment. When Lightning Returns went on sale, I still had doubts that the trilogy could get me interested. One hesitant purchase later, I was pleasantly surprised that all my earlier worries were for naught. Not only is Lightning Returns a great comeback to quality Final Fantasy, but it's also one of the most exceptional RPGs to come out in a while. And just so I can make this clear before continuing my review:  you don’t have to play or like the first two games to appreciate Lightning Returns, although they may help in your enjoyment of the game.

The plot picks up centuries after the second game’s ending. After being crystallized for hundreds of years, Lightning awakens to find that the entire world is ending in 13 days. Numerous monsters rise from sinister zones called Chaos, most of the world has been engulfed in darkness and the remaining traces of civilization left can be found in the Dead Dunes, The Wildlands and the cities of Luxerion and Yusnaan. The worst realization for Lightning, however, is her sister Serah being held captive by the god of light, Bhunivelze. The god then made a deal to Lightning: she would become his servant for the final 13 days in return for her sister's freedom.

I have not finished both prequels, but I can assure you that the game does a good enough job in explaining its branching storyline. Some terms and characters are foreign at first for new players, but it's nothing a few hours of playing the game can fix. The story is also easier to follow and not distracting unlike in the past two games. Also two giant thumbs up for wrapping up the story in one of the most epic finale in the series!

Speaking of characters, Lightning Returns takes a step forward for the supporting characters and a massive leap for our titular heroine. If you couldn't stand any of the characters in the prequels, you'll be glad to hear that this game made their presence actually bearable. All returning characters except Lightning receive limited screen time, but their personality this time around is fleshed out through individual story arcs. With an impending apocalypse in sight, it’s not really surprising that many of the upbeat characters took a turn for the worst. Lightning herself is no longer the constantly broody genderbent Cloud from the first game, but a strong woman who is constantly seeking out her true self while looking out for her sister. From her rich interactions with the other characters and NPCs, I realize that she could be snarky, cynical, hilarious and even (gasp) feminine. She yearns to help others while always putting her mission first. I couldn't help but notice that the characterization of Lightning here just screams Geralt from The Witcher 3.

I would like to thank Square Enix for heavily revamping the combat system and making the battles actually enjoyable. Still remember the clunky mix of turn-based and real-time combat of the prequels? In Lightning Returns, the battles feel like a fresh hybrid of FFX and Crisis Core. You can unleash different attacks real-time using the four button inputs while keeping an eye on the ATB bar. If your ATB bar runs out, you'll be unable to take action for a period of time. Timing your attacks, managing your bar, exploiting the enemy's weaknesses and switching between garbs (which I'll get to in a sec) form the combat mechanics of Lightning Returns. There's even a dose of Dark Souls thrown in where timing your blocks become essential to survive against tougher foes and bosses. Unlike other Final Fantasy games, Lightning Returns will reward players who can master strategic combat instead of those who can grind the longest or obtain the best equipment. This is further backed up by the lack of EXP system in the game.

Wait, did I hear that right? No EXP, so no levels? That's absolutely correct. The term experience points" and "levels" is nonexistent in Lightning Returns. The only way to boost Lightning's stats is by completing main story missions and side quests. Instead of getting EXP
date: killing monsters will net you new skills
recommended: rare weapon drops and EP for your counter. The EP counter is sort of like your SP bar in traditional RPGs for using utility skills. The only reason you will want to grind mobs is to farm skills and build up your EP counter for very situational moments. Strong skills are essential to create the ultimate Lightning
hoursPlayed: but fear not since the drop rate in this game is abnormally high.\n\nIn exchange for controlling Lightning the entire game
voteText: our heroine can equip different armors called "garbs" to fulfill the role of an entire party. Think back to the different roles like Commando and Ravager in the prequels except it involves Lightning switching garbs mid-battle instead. Each garb has their own ATB bar so timing your switches is essential since they can only refill their bar while on standby mode. For even more customization
helpfulPercent: the garbs can be modified heavily with skills that drop from monsters. The maximum number of garbs you can wield per battle is three

reviewText: Writing a review after 100% achivement.\nFirst of to the technical point. It´s the best port out of the three games XIII / XIII-2. Had zero crashes (it even runs zero crashes with only CPU). Story wise i probaly say its the weakest of them all in the series and XIII being strongest.\nBut being the weakest on Story dosn´t mean it´s the worst. The freedom of Customizing your garb (armor/Class) is really cool. And there are tons of garbs to get and find! You pick three garbs and they become the classes you play as. Each  garb comes with diffrent stats/abilties. This is a strong point which the other series imo missed. XIII had the same looks expect weapon, XIII-2 had diffrent looks but not by alot. This game probaly has about 50+ diffrent garbs didn¨t count them all and i guess about 50 + weapons too. Compared to the three games this one gives most Freedom out of them all. You can go whereever you want in Nova Chrystalia whenever you want. This is something i wish the original XIII had freedom to walk wherever you want to. There is 5 Main quest stories and tons of billboard side quest and regular side quest which you talk to people. Dont be scared about the time you have when you start playing, you could actually gain a 14th day and you probaly complete almost all quests anyways or atleast 90% by ease! Content wise I would say in one way weakest to in series since alot of the time you run back and forth if you take that in consideration probaly the least content of the trilogy. What makes this the best is the Freedom,Customazation and exploration.  What give this minus compared to the other ones is Story, lenght and battle system is the most boring one to easy.

reviewText:
At first I was weary about buying another Final Fantasy XIII title. But after playing through this game, I am so glad that I did.

Lightning Returns really feels like a Final Fantasy game. When I played XIII and XIII-2, they felt like okay games, but for Final Fantasy games, they really fell short in a lot of places. On the other hand, LR had the same feel as the old Final Fantasy games did. I could not stop playing, because I wanted to explore the world and literally do every side quest I could in the game. This is the kind of feeling that FFVI - FFX had for me, and I'm really pleased with how Square-Enix brought this exciting feeling back.

A few things that made this game so much more interesting than the others:The opening sequence really drew me in and made me extremely interested in what this game was about. While the other two had slightly interesting beginnings, neither of them pulled it off quite as well as this one did.

Another thing that made this game so strong was the interesting world. It was so open world that you could literally do any of the main quests in whatever order you wanted. I loved exploring the whole world, and how each area had its own unique culture.

All of the NPCs had their own back stories and interesting reasons for doing what they were doing. This is one of the features that really made me want to do all of the side quests, without making them feel like extra work" or generic "fetch quests
date: even if they were technically asking you to go get an item for them or slay a monster. There were even certain times of day that certain NPCs would be in specific areas. This made them seem so real. Like they were real people with real lives, and couldn't just be sitting in the same spot all day, because they had things to do.At first the battle system was my main complaint, but after getting used to it, it turned out to be my favorite battle system in the XIII series. It requires so much strategy and isn't as simple as hitting auto-battle" and sitting there
recommended: watching the battle play through. I love how it has elements of the ATB system from previous Final Fantasy titles
hoursPlayed: but it also brings in much more action elements to really make it feel like you are participating and controlling every move.\n\nAnother thing that turned me off at first was the time limit of the game. At first I was worried that I would be unable to do everything in the amount of time given
voteText: but as I played the game
helpfulPercent: it really wasn't a huge issue. I was able to complete all of the main five quests with at least three days left to finish up side quests. Using the combination of Chronostasis and Teleport really makes things fairly easy to complete in the time limit given. Also
votesHelpful: being a project manager
votesTotal: this was really a lot of fun for me to manage my time and use every second efficiently. It got me excited to be able to write down what times certain quests could be completed
votesFunny: and when things had to be done by. This might be hard for people who don't enjoy time management as much as me
commentsCount: but honestly it's a really fun challenge that is added to the game.\n\nOne last thing that I would like to point out is the improvement from XIII-2
column16: in regards to the PC Port. I didn't find too much wrong with this port
column17: and it ran just like it would on a PS3
column18: for the most part. No lag at all (I played on the lowest settings and it still looked beautiful). The only issues I had were that it would crash in the Jagd Woods in the Wildlands sporadically if I did not save every few minutes. Other than that
column19: I never had any problems.\n\nOverall
column20: I can't express how pleasantly surprised I was with this game. I spent about 56 hours on my first play through
column21: but I got 81% of the achievements and did all besides three side quests (that's about the same amount of time it took me to play through both XIII and XIII-2 combined).\n\nTL;DR:This game is the best in the XIII series. I definitely recommend buying this game if you like unique worlds

reviewText:
+ Stuning Soundtrack that will harbour nostalgia for old Final Fantasy fans as well as fans of the first two XIII games.

+ Beautifully designed world, each area feels alive and has a unique design.

+ Battles are excitingly frantic and challenging, featuring real time strategy.

+ The Story is beautifully deep, and unapologetically eccentric.

+ Solid port, game runs at mostly 60 frame per second with occasional drops into the 40s.

+ The new advanced lighting and graphic options for this version look gorgeous, it truly looks like a remaster at times.


- Has to be online to play. ( Who cares though right? Just get a dongle if you want to play on the go. )

I got a refund
Always on-line DRM
The game does say it just needs steam cloud enabled but it will not launch in offline mode of steam at all thus requireing online at all times.

Also, I couldnt play the game as I had graphical errors that made it literally unplayable and unable to see what was going on. The cutsences played fine for only 50% of the screen and in game looked like a strobe of horizontal bars with the UI and subtitle overlays working fine. So with not being able to ever play this offline combined with spending an hour trying to fix the graphical issues i just got a refund instead. If i can run the latest DMC game i should be able to run this.

EDIT:
Not changing my review because they fixed some stuff later on, once a review is posted your done son.... That being said apparently they fixed the AMD 4800 graphical issue and supposedly" removed online only DRM so it can start in offline mode. reviewText:
Lightning Returns is a uniquely amazing Action-JRPG and a decent PC port. Issues from previous Final Fantasy ports such as optimization issues and graphic options have been fully addressed in this port. The game offers a lot of visual adjustments and resolution, it also runs great on most modern systems, including gaming laptops.

This game and generally speaking the XIII series as a whole has divided the Final Fantasy fan base into two opposite groups. You will either love this game or hate it, there's no middle point. The first thing you need to know about the gameplay is the global Time-limit. That's right, you're given 14 in-game days to finish the game in the best case scenario and if you fail to do that (which is quite hard to do unintentionally to be honest), It's an automatic Game Over with an option to keep all your stats and items and restart the game.

But keep in mind that even though there is a time limit, you don't need to rush the game AT ALL. There is MUCH more time than you need to finish everything on your first playthrough. You can also freeze the time by using an in-game ability as well.

If you mostly play video games just for the story (like I do), then you're gonna be hugely disappointed in this game. The whole story revolves around an illogical concept which is pure non-sense. And I mean it in an objective sense. Basically, everything you do until the very end is completely pointless. Honestly, Lightning Returns has one of the worst plot I've seen in a long time and the ending is even worse. I'm not gonna spoil the plot so pet me put it this way. The ending will take everything you've done and throw it out the window, it would also ironically point out the fact that the whole story was intentionally nonsense and why.

On the bright side, Soundtrack is astonishing and gameplay is great. I would highly recommend Lightning Returns solely becuase of its gameplay. If you like to play good games, you should definitely play this. However, if you just want a good story, you would be disappointed.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Can't recommend this game to anyone but the most avid of FF fanboys.

The port - is pretty good. Well.. people say that, but I'm not sure what their standards are. It runs fine except for 1 certain spot in the Dead Dunes where it crashes constantly. I also had to reinstall it instantly because apparently enabling the JP voice pack with subtitles won't allow you to pass the first cutscene due to certain antiviruses like Avast. Other than that it ran fine.

The combat system - is nothing like the prequels. It's lightning alone changing between three schemata(clothes) with different ATB(stamina gauges) that each have their own 4 attacks. *The system itself isn't bad* but there are some annoying delays that can cause abilities to go off after switching schemata. The primary problem with this system is that the schemata have locked-in abilities that you can't rebind as far as I could discern. This means if you need to change your style for a boss or harder mob you'll have to relearn keybindings. Aerora used to be 1? Sorry, the new schemata you have to use has that bound to debrave. Enjoy casting debrave constantly by accident. This results in a very high amount of irritation while playing and against hard bosses it generally means you can't win until you memorize keybinds completely.

Addendum. The combo mechanic is incredibly stupid. Using finales is generally considered to be a detriment to your gameplay as it is so slow that their stagger gauge recovers AND it leaves you wide open for an attack. This means nuke->nuke->change schemata->nuke->nuke->change schemata repeat until staggered rather than nuke->nuke->finale.

The time limit - isn't as bad as you might think. I presumed it would be rather harsh, especially given that certain quest NPCs, items or pathways are blocked during certain times of day. This resulted in me killing every mob I came across for 'EP' to use Chronostasis and freeze time - resulting in my completing of all main story quests and most side quests by day 6 of 13-14.  Also there is constant chit chat between Lightning and Hope throughout the game which you - if you want to hear it - must stop and listen to, wasting time. It *does* continue after you exit a fight, however there are certain interactions that can cancel it outright and it's gone forever.

The boss loot system - is pointlessly bad. I forgot about it at times and missed very powerful pieces of equipment like the sword with quick stagger that you CAN'T get back to without going through the game again. What happens on boss/omega level monsters is they drop a red shiny on the ground instead of giving you it in the loot screen. Makes sense right.

The clothing" - is ridiculous. Look
date: I've always thought metal-kinis were stupid
recommended: but I'm also not one of the totally unhinged psychofeminists. That said
hoursPlayed: the clothing is this game is just ridiculous. There are a few really well designed sets but I'd say around 50% of them are Lightning wearing bikinis and latex ultra miniskirts with a thong pulled up over her hips. That's just pathetic for an AAA developer and it's a trend that's happening more and more with FF games. "Classic Japan" jokes don't cut it with a franchise like this. Wh*r*ng out you're main character to perverts to sell a FF game. It's just sad. Almost forgot..  you can change the colors of the clothes. Just in case you prefer electronica to have a pink thong.\n\nThe game's length - isn't actually very long. If you remove the cutscenes it's actually quite short
voteText: as the game has no level system for Lightning - only for abilities. I presume this means the last boss will be rather tough unless you farm mobs for ability drops to level up in a very tedious combination system. ** Edit - As well as length there are only 4 areas in the game
helpfulPercent:
with 2 or 3 relatively small dungeon areas that are essentially just repeating hallways. You'll quickly find yourself very tired of running around Luxerion for the 100th time or back and forth across the Wild Lands.

The sidequests - make up the vast majority of the gameplay. As mentioned above it's pretty short for a FF game. It's packed full of a sidequests which are almost entirely fetch/slay quests which are very boring. They give slight stat boosts upon completion and rarely an item. There is a bonus area  for completing some however. Fortunately it's not too hard to reach that goal.

The story - is utterly F'ing nuts. If you played the first two and aren't a blind fanboy you probably already know the storyline is completely insane. Even if they do maintain the rough formula of a FF game they are disconnected and hard to follow with 13-2 being considerably more bizarre than the original. FF13-3 compounds that confusion even further. Constantly contradicting itself and failing to explain major plot points. Even ignoring the repeated contradictions of their own story and absence of how x or y happens the storyline itself is total nonsense. I don't want to spoil it so I'll simply say  It's cliche
votesHelpful:
cringeworthy and entirely mad.

Know now that you will understand little to nothing about everything in this game and will only have a very vague understanding of what is happening with almost all remaining unexplained. For a Final Fantasy game this is unrepentable and the main reason I would never recommend anyone play this game. It's not worth it. At least not for the story. Maybe if you really like the combat. Take that from someone who spent 57 hours trying to enjoy it! If you absolutely MUST see it then at least 99.9% of the storyline happens via cutscene. Just go watch them instead.

*Spelling/clarity"

reviewText:
This is my first time to play RPG game ever.

I've heard Final Fantasy before but I've never played.

Final Fantasy has many series and XIII is the best graphics out there.

At first, I couldn't get used to it but now I'm doing OKAY.

Actually, I really like this game. A woman named Lightning looks very pretty.

Although I never played previous Final Fantasy but I can say this is a good game.

Who never played RPG game can actually enjoy this.

But I do want to remind that people who never tried RPG games might have hard time at beginning so you might need patience to get used to it.

Man, I really like the way Lightning looks. So pretty. Japanese are so good with making these games.


Edited on 4/21/16 : I've played about 92 hours and finally I've seen the end. I was new to Final Fantasy and I didn't do well on time management.

But as the time continues to flow I'm getting used to this game.

People who new to this game, I want to recommend to try for Easy first to get use to it.

Then try to finish the ending, but if it fails then you'll move toward to New Game +.

If you get used to it then you can increase the level of hardness anytime.

Keep in mind that time matters a lot.

You also need to finish the quest to get stronger. So try to finish the main, side, canvas quests as many as possible.

reviewText:
I'm honestly too lazy to write a long-♥♥♥♥ review since there's so many of them already. Just let me say this:

The game has absolutely NOTHING to do with the previous two except the main characters. The battle system is in my opinion not that entertaining, graphics are ugly and low-budget-ish and even the music is below the average for a FF game with exception of some tracks (The Ark, A Sacred Oratorio, Altar of Light, Claire Farron, Sash and Dajh, Sneaking In and a few others).

And yet I did enjoy playing Lightning Returns. XIII characters really grew on me and it was interesting to watch their personalities develop through all three games. That said - the story (although still confusing) is great, voice acting fabulous again (not talking about English voices; Liara and Joel should go back to their games, they do not belong here!) and the finale pretty satisfying.

What really surprised me was a depth of side quests. The quests themselves were made in a boring fetch this and that" style known from many MMORPGs
date: but their backstories were always beautiful. Especially the "Life of a Machine" quest almost made me shed a tear.\n\nAaand that's about it. The game is fun

reviewText:
Great action RPG! The battle system and enemies give you something to chew on, making you come up with complex combinations of different gear, weapons, and abilities to find that sweet spot in quickly tackling individual fights. The combat is fast, dynamic, and requires sound strategy, while button mashing and brute force are punished. Even on Normal mode, the gameplay should give veterans a fair challenge. There's also a lot of meat to the gameplay, and even the fetch quest diversions tend to be interesting thanks to the short stories they tell. The bottom line is that this game offers quite a lot of mileage in terms of game time till you've seen and completed everything, and even then it invites you to master everything on New Game+ cycles, a Hard mode, and some optional content of exceptional difficulty.

The story isn't bad, but a bit on the short side. It is however a nice finish to the XIII trilogy that shouldn't leave your eyes dry if you've stuck with it from beginning to end. I'm fairly certain that it will leave anybody utterly confused if they haven't completed the stories of the previous games before it, though.

Technically speaking, the optimization is lacking. You can tell this is a console game port through and through, from low-rez textures, over significant framerate drops in towns with lots of NPCs, to a lack of in-game mouse controls.

If you do not intend to play with a controller and mediocre ports or performance are things that bother you, steer clear from this game and consider me giving it a flaming thumbs down. Otherwise, I wholeheartedly give it a thumbs up for excellent gameplay.

reviewText:
Congrats Final Fantasy 8: Lightning returns
I didnt think it was possible, but this game just made my Top 5 Games of all time. Truly, Congratulations.

Now I'm not a huge Final Fanatasy Fanatic, I only really played a select few like Tactics and 7, so going in, I didn't know what to expect. I do have a certain passion for turn based games as most FF's are like but what this game gives you is no turn based RPG. The only game I could compare this to would be Transistor ( Another top 5 ) but even that is a stretch. Whats great about this game in particular is that it literally takes my favourite games of all time and combines them. Perfectly. {DETAILS} Majoras Mask quests and time restraints keeps you constantly thinking of what to do next, but theres no Song of Time in this game. Transistor in a sense of combat, after running into an enemy ( no random encounters, they spawn near player ) you're taken to an arena where you battle it out. Most FF games have parties, sadly only select sections in this game do you have said parties. Instead, you have 3 different classes you can switch to at will, each with their own ATB meter, or energy in a sense.  Which combines, somewhat, a beat-em-up game, where certain combos have unique specials and you're constantly switching between classes for the best output.

The game was a great bang for your buck with my first playthough going on for 40 hours, after only purchasing the game for 10$. I would have easily spent 30$ if I had know it would be this good. Re-playability looks to be profitable with doing quests you never got to complete and getting the equipment you could never afford. But I think I'll wait a while before that. Total, I have little to no complaints. Looks great, runs great, feels great. I just highly reccomend a controller.

Buy it? Buy it.

reviewText:
I like it, but I may be in the minority, as I enjoyed the previous entries in the trilogy, and Lightning was my favorite character.

The story is flimsy at best, confusing and weird at worst, and Hope is back (I hate hope), but the important parts are improved.

The combat's been reworked from the previous games, and I actually like it a lot. The game is basically a cosplay simulator, and it gives you all the DLC outfits for free at the very start of the game, you shift costumes to shift, well, basically shift characters, Lightning acts as a 1 person 3 man party in this game. I loved Lightning as a character (again, probably in the minority here) so I'm really enjoying playing as her again.

The game plays almost like Majora's Mask or DeadRising, with a deathclock time limit, and you as the player working within these time constraints as well as a day-night cycle that determines who you can speak with and what you can do at any given time. It's a fresh challenge, and if you enjoy time management you'll enjoy this aspect of the game.

Bottom line, if you like more action-y combat as opposed to the straight up turn based methods of older FF games, or if you've been enjoying the XIII trilogy so far and see the deathclock as a fun challenge as opposed to an oppressive limitation, I see no reason not to pick this one up, especially at it's 20-25 dollar pricepoint.
