reviewText:
OK everyone hear me out i'm a ff fan and always been but XIII was not my cup of tea ♥♥♥♥♥ but even tho i didn't liked the first one too much and the second was ok, i decided to give the third one a chance, Lighting Returns its actually a good game if you give it the chance. Taking out of the way time for me to do a spoiler free review of the game, so let's start with the Pros of the game.

Let's start that first that as a PC Port is definitely the best of the serie, before the recent update (dec 24) you couldn't play offline because of cloud which they finally took off, and now they have added more resolution options. Thank you for that Square. Ok now let's start with the Pros and Cons of the game so you get an idea of what to expect.

+ pro(s):

+ Graphics

Let's get something first, this game cameout in 2013 (Japan) - 2014 (America & Europe) so you wont find new things on it that weren't in the console, now that's not bad, the game still mantains the beauty that was known for it has aged quite well to be honest.

+ 60 FPS

What else i can say....60 fps are best fps and something you wanna see everyday all day in your life.  ?(????)

+ DLC Included

FREE DLC ARE BEST DLC.

+ Battle system:

The battle system  had a huge improvement from previous 13's and now it has more strategy to it, being able to have 3 different schemas (Class) in battle each corresponding to a different garb (Armor) that you need to set up, you could have a debuff class to start the battle and lower the melee and magic resistance to an enemy, then change to a mage class to deal from affar and then a melee class to hit hard and fast ?(?_??).

+ Music

One that has not change much from the other games in the aspect that it's awesome you will simply love the soundtracks of the game and each song reflects very well the place you are at the moment giving you a more deph and meaning to the place. You can find the soundtrack in youtube and see it for yourself but it will have more meaning when you are listening to it ingame.

+ Price

because yeah, i had to go there, i mean to be honest the original price of $60 i would have never recommend the game but now that we have the PC port at  $19.99 this is definitely a must have and even then you could wait for another sale and have a go for it.

+ World map

If you hated how the previous games felt a little bit linear  ( im looking at you XIII) you will be pleasantly surprise and glad to see that Nova Crystalia is such a beautiful place with lots to explore.

+ Side Quests

Finally! the side quests are not only optional but have a meaning for you there are lots of sidequests in the game and they even tho most of them are optional they actually help you improving your stats (hp, magic, strenght...) so if you love to do this then you are in luck.

+ NG+

It's NG+ what else you want me to say

+ Dual Audio

We have the amazing choice to hear the game in English or Japanese (Only voices) so if you preffer the game in any language well now you have the choice, even tho i would recommend to here the game first in english to get more of the story

* Neutral:

Graphics

What? Ceopls you said this was a pro what gives man?... Well yes i said it was a pro and it is BUT here comes the big butt...(see what i did there) it also has its flaws depending on how you look at it, some places will look rather empty" for you in some parts not all thats why is not good or bad
date:
it all depends in your point of view.  Also while its nothing really bad you will find some flickering and some weird shadows ingame but nothing too distracting but hey...i have to be fair


Gameplay

This game has a mechanic very similiar to The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask where you have a certain number of days to save the world
recommended: now you can use some skills to actually stop the time while using EP which can be recovered having random battles or doing side quests (see what i meant with having a meaning) so AGAIN depending of your point of view this could be good or bad
hoursPlayed:
now i was skeptic about this when i started but let me tell you that you will have more than enough time to do everything the game has to offer. There is always guides that shows you the best root if you get lost at some point.

- Con(s):

- Controls

Lighting Returns was literally ported to pc meaning that the control settings is are mapped with the Keyboard keys
voteText: you can play with a 360 controller but all the commands show the keyboards ingame
helpfulPercent: worry not you can find button does what when you are on the intro
votesHelpful:
but it would have been nice to add full controller support to the game so that it shows also the controller buttons in the game

- Challenge

The game itself is quite a challenge on NG (normal
votesTotal:
you unlock hard after beating the game) but once you get to NG+ either normal or hard the enemies wont scale their stats meaning they will have the same stats they had while playing  in NG.

- Story friendly

While the story of Lighting Returns is amazing
votesFunny: you would also need to know what happen in XIII & XIII-2
commentsCount:
so for new players i would strongly recommend watching the story on youtube from the previous games.

- Hope

He becomes the FF version of navi enough said...

Overall:

Lighting Returns its a good game and i would strongly recommend it if you like FF's even if you disliked the first 2...13's

reviewText:
Great port. Good game. Game did not crash once or have FPS issues and ran smooth on my A10  processer on my laptop. None of the problems I had with the first 2 games in the series which were terrible ports and not so good games. This game is actually fun. Thrilled Final Fantasy XV will follow in the steps of this game.

I actually enjoyed his game so much I spent time finishing nearly every quest.  The combat is much more fun and more hack and slash action based never seen in a FF game. The number options are good and only get beter with more costumes, items, and weapons. More open world and plenty of quests.

Don't be fooled by the smaller  disk space of this game compared to the first 2 games.  I played this one for many more hours than each of them individually and actually enjoyed this game instead of feeling like I was grinding and wasting time. I deleted the other 2 games from my drive after beating them to have disk space and because I will never play them again. Kept this game on my drive because it's a really good game.

It's not Final Fantasy VII but it's not Final Fantasy XIII either. It's actually quite different than any Final Fantasy game and very enjoyable.

reviewText: Didn't expect that this would become my 2nd favorite Final Fantasy game of all time (VII being the best), especially not after having just finished the god-awful XIII-2. Lightning Returns is probably the first truly open-world FF game and rather than having an incoherent mess of locations like XIII-2 did, it instead has just four but each one is different from the gloomy European Luxerion and the vibrant, festive Yusnaan to the more open and diverse spaces of the Wild Lands and the Dead Dunes, each of which has a different atmosphere depending on the time of day (the day-night cycle is dynamic for the first time in the series). The battle system is the best in the series, being less about cheap and tedious grinding and more about precise timing, exploiting enemy weaknesses and having the right kind of schemata. The game's most notorious feature, the clock, is perhaps also its best feature, encouraging you to be efficient with your time, and allowing you to feel good about yourself at the end of a productive day. (It's also quite generous; after having finished nearly every available quest on Normal, I still had almost a week left on the clock.) And then there's Lightning, the icing on the cake if there ever was one and a reason in itself to buy the game. You may dress her in all kinds of cool outfits (garbs")
date: which really makes the game the ultimate Waifu Dress-Up Simulator. Note that there are some jarring fps drops especially in the cities
hoursPlayed: but that's pretty much my only complaint."

reviewText:
Completed in 57 hours, ending was so worth it. What a way end FF13 Trilogy. It's one of them feel good games I havent experience in about 15 years never thought get them same vibes I had playing older games back in the late 90's early 2000, it's spiritual ascension.

I would hold this game up there few of my favourite J-RPG's

Illusion of Gia,Grandia 2,Skies of Arcadia, Lost Oddessy, Final Fantast X

Play this game with open mind...

Ignoring the DRM issue which has given this game bad rap.

The 13 days you have to complete the game would be problem, truthfully; Once you get used to the game machanics and learn how to stop time with EP. It's not actually as bothersome as you might think, you can do the main mission and complete side quest's easily enough. The clock ticking down after while becomes less of tension stricken issue more time grind some more side quest's explore towns and it's in habitants and start up conversations where ever you go.

I played this game on this PC" setup:

+ i3-3240 3.4 GHz Dual-Core-CPU with 3MB Cache & Hyper-Threading Technology.
+ AMD Redeon HD6670 2GB
+ 8 GB Ram.

How the Game performed on this setup:
Experience some frame rate drops in Yusaan and Luxerion but nothing that game breaking.

Positives:
+DLC included
+Japanese & English voice modes
+ Great Graphics & Visuals.
+ Motion Capture get's (A Star) from me.
+ Excellent Voice Acting.
+ Awesome Sound Track.
+ Clothing & Item's Galore practically "Lightning" dress up simulator
+ Quests are not as complicated or tedious as what you might think but that could be debatable.

I have always liked the story to FF13 series even though it comes across convoluted mess but no one ever complained about "Metal Gear Solid" convoluted story.

I am actually really impressed with the PC port
date: haven't had single issue yet with the game
recommended:
not encountered any bugs or glitches.

Battling Enamies & Monsters:
Machanics might not be for everyone liking seeing as you cannot level-up in the traditional sense.

Minor:
Leveling-up via quest's might put people off but quest's are easier to do once you adjusted to the game. I am taking on quests like pro. Really enjoying it so far.

Biggest gripe not enough mini-games which is normally expected JRPG's

Can't understand the hate for this game I guess it's cool to be hater these days than it is to be lover.

This game gets solid 10/10"

reviewText:
Lightning Returns is easily my favorite Final Fantasy XIII game.  Given my opinion of the other two games that's not saying all that much, but I genuinely like this one.

The battle system is the best thing to happen to a Final Fantasy game in years, it's a fantastic hybrid between direct character control and picking commands from a menu and it's something I've never seen before.  It's possible it was ripped from some MMO I don't know about, but it was very fresh concept to me and it took me by surprise how much I'm digging it.  The battle system alone is enough to put this game ahead of the other games in the series for me.

I also really like the character customization system.  I wasn't sure how I'd feel about basic abilities like attack and guard being limited, equipable items, but it works.  The garb (aka dress) system also works because, whether we admit it or not, we all like playing dress up with our virtual action figures (they're totally not dolls! :) - whether it's putting spiked pauldrons on a barbarian or a highly impractical armor" on Lightning.

Beyond the combat systems

reviewText:
Lightning Returns is a great RPG game ported over from the consoles, the PC port itself is really good as I have experienced no crashes or bugs. However, this game does not support mouse control so you could only play with either a controller or just the keyboard. Unique to the PC platform is the ability to increase the graphical performance of this game as there are options for resolution, lighting effects, shadow quality and et cetera. There is also the options for english and japanese voiceovers which are both equally good.

In this game you play as Lightning and you have thirteen in-game days to complete it. You might think that it would be very constraining since you are given a time limit, but you are also given an ability to stop time which you could use to complete various quest and activities. Speaking of things to do, there are quite alot of them! There are five main questlines and over a hundred side quest/canvas of prayers to do to increase stats and unlock cosmetics. You could also hunt different monsters to extinction and would be given a powerful reward in doing so.

This game would be a delight for those who love customization. You could unlock many different garbs, weapons, shields and adornment to dress Lightning up in and they each have special abilities and stats. The combat in this game is pretty satisfying as it is semi-action combat and no longer turn-based. You could customized your garbs with different abilities and this would allow you to pull out some great combos during battles.

The soundtrack in this game is amazing and really fits well during different scenarios of the game. After completing the game you are given the ability to continue with new game + which allow you to retain almost everything such as gears and stats. You might be wondering why would you want to replay the game again, well there are some pretty cool features in new game + such as a hard mode for added difficulty, ability to upgrade weapon, shields, accesories as well as the ability to restart the game from day one with almost everything intact at any point of the game.

Overall this is a great game and I would recommend it for those who like customization and role-playing games. I would give it a 9/10!

reviewText:
This is going to be a block of text of me trying to go as in-depth as possible into FXIII Lightning Returns This is my first review so, please bear with me. Lightning Returns is the final game of the FFXIII Trilogy. That being said this game is made to give the player closure after playing FFXIII and FXIII-2. The closure this game gives may or may not be enough for some people but you just have to play it to find out if it is enough for you. Now Lightning Returns introduces a new combat system, Instead of the menu combat it is now Realtime Combat. Realtime Combat made the gameplay extremely immersive and alot more fun (In my opinion). Now Lightning gets to use 3 Schemas which the player can customize like this:
-Garb
-Weapon
-Shield
-Accessory 1
-Accessory 2
-Adornment (Optional Wear: Bunny Ears, Tails, Wings, Tattoos etc.)
-Ability 1
-Ability 2
-Ability 3
-Ability 4
(Note that some Garbs have locked abilities where the player cannot put their own ability into the locked slot)
Lightning again uses 3 Main Schemas and switches out between the 3 different schemas the player has put into their Main Schema Slots.
ATB Bars are basically Mana Pools where Lightning uses an ability and that amount of ATB is taken from the ATB Bar. (Note that ATB is NOT shared between your Schemas and will regenerate when not in use.)
Combat Highly Revolves around how well the player can perfectly Block and Attack.
Staggering is the main way to do damage, Staggering has different conditions depending on the enemy and there are many different ways you can stagger a single enemy.
The player may choose whatever goes into the schema and is completely up to the player on which they would like to use. While on the topic of Schemas I would like to address a complaint that some players have about the Schema Setups.
Some players may feel forced to use a certain garb for a locked ability  Soldier of Peace with Artemis's Arrow  Choosing to use a garb for the reward of easing the play is the PLAYER'S choice and not the games. I personally beat the game using garbs that Lightning wore in the previous games; which are given to the player for free in the Rewards Barter Shop (Only on the PC Port, On console you must have to have a save file from FXIII for 1 and FXIII-2 for another).
One of the aspects of the game are the Time Limit, You are given 6 Days to start but by progressing through the story you are given more. (PROTIP: DO NOT LOOK AT THE ACHIEVEMENTS OR YOU WILL GET SPOILED VERY HARD ;-;) Now roughly 2.5 seconds in Real Life are equivalent to 1 Minute in Lightning Returns clock. So 1 Hour of Lightning Returns time is equivalent to 2 minutes and 30 seconds of Real Life. That being said a Full Day in Lightning Returns is about 1 Real Life Hour. The clock is stopped during cutscenes, fights, and interaction with NPC's. Do not feel rushed, Square Enix knows that the time limit may be stressful and they incoporated abilities to help Lightning get through the quests without running out of time.
Lightning is also given Eradia, which can be found in the bottom left corner indicated by a glowing orange number with orange bars. Eradia has many uses which are given to the player throughout the game. Eradia is lost when using an Eradia Powered ability and is gained by killing enemies. Certain enemies such as, Niblets, will not grant as much Eradia (roughly .02 Eradia gain) than slaying a Zaltys ( 1 Eradia gain). So killing big monsters will grant more Eradia to let Lightning use the Eradia spells.
Now the world is dying and it's all because of the Chaos. Chaos can be seen as a black aura with many tiles. If Lightning chooses to go to this area enemy encounters are alot harder. The enemy is given certain buffs while in the Chaos but if it leaves the chaos it becomes a regular enemy again. Fighting inside chaos may prove a challenge but if Lightning does win a battle inside the Chaos she is rewarded with: Bonus Eradia, Bonus Gil, and a higher chance of good drops.
Unlike the regular experience system in other FInal Fantasy games, Lightning Returns doesn't give you an experience system. Instead Lightning gets stronger through finishing: Main Quests, Side Quests, and Canvas of Prayer Quests (The Board found by Chocolina). While it may annoy some people having to grind quests to get stronger, it is optional. I was so engrossed in the story that after day 7 I slept all the way through the last day to see the ending.
Now we all play Final Fantasy Titles expecting story. Lightning Returns gives us story, some may not like it some may, Personally I enjoyed it. The story may be rushed at times but isn't that how it's suppoused to be? The world ends in 13 days and you can't dally or you fail your mission. The ending is something very special and if you hate Lightning as a character from FXIII and FXIII-2 for her attitude I would say you HAVE to play Lightning Returns. I personally loved Lightning as the main character throughout the series, being cold, violent, and mean made her seem like the biggest ***** alive but if that's the reason you don't want to play Lightning Returns you are doing yourself an injustice. The ending is something VERY SPECIAL while many seem to hate it I loved it (Even though I could barely see the screen through all my tears). It's something unique to say the least, I had always had an emotional connection with Lightning and the character progression of Lightning in this game parody'd (Related too well) to me, May have just caused a more emotional effect (I literally was blind in tears)
Now Square Enix forces you to start with either Normal or Easy, Both do NOT offer the full experience and the player must play again on HARD, which is awarded after completing the game. You basically have to play through the whole game again to get the full experience. May be annoying for some people I found it fun going through the tougher bosses for round 2.
The PC Port of FXIII Lightning Returns, as said in other reviews is undoubtedly the BEST PC PORT for the FXIII Series and is great. I ran FXIII Lightning Returns on 1920 x 1080 60 FPS (Ocassionally dipped down to 40) on a NVIDIA GTX 960M (Comparable to the GTX 750TI for Desktop Users) I5-6300HQ 2.3GHz with 8 GB of RAM
FXIII Gets alot of hate and alot of negative reviews for different reasons and people always have differing opinions. If you did play FXIII and FXIII-2 you MUST play this one. If you want to start with Lightning Returns I would highly oppose it, and URGE you to play through FXIII and FXIII-2 to get the story and get the most from FXIII Lightning Returns.

Too Long; Didn't Read
PROS:
-Realtime Combat System
-Gives Closure
-Replayability (The game gives the option for NG+ I have seen people do 9 Playthroughs)
-Open World (Not Linear like FFXIII)
-SE Gives an ability to FREEZE Clock
-Lightning is Customizeable
-BEST PC PORT for the FXIII Series
-Most entertaining and immersive boss fights (IMO)
-Game Comes with DLC (Except the Aerith and Seigfried Garbs)
-Character Development
-Beautiful Landscape
-No Party Members (If you didn't like the FFXIII Characters will be a pro)
-No EXP system (Lightning gets stronger through finishing Main and Side Quests)


CONS:
-Time Limit (Unless you play like a turtle or lose every fight you will not Time Out)
-Military Time (The Game Clock is in Military Time, Might be difficult to tell time for some people)
-Rushed Story (Makes sense because of the time limit)
-If you don't play on HARD you don't get the full experience.
-No Party Members (Revolves around Lightning, May be a Con for some people)
-No EXP system (Some people liked grinding monsters to lvl, I am not one of those people)
-Difficult Boss Fights (Hard NG+)
-Story might be difficult to understand (Really only in the beginning)

Solid 9/10, My favorite of all the FF games.

(I will finish this review after my completion of NG+ on HARD)

reviewText:
I took the chance on this game and I'm really glad I did. I've spent 88 hours on it in less than a month.
The game had a functional story with lots of character development, especially for Lightning. I felt immersed in the beautiful environments. The soundtrack set the mood perfectly, even in moments of satire. I enjoyed interacting with anyone I could find to hear amusing and even sometimes touching dialogue.

I rate this game 9/10.
I'll go ahead and say that this is one of my all-time favorite games. Across 10 Final Fantasy games I've played this is the only one that held me until the end, even for another playthrough on Hard Mode.

Pros!
-Highly interactive and challenging combat system. Practice makes a huge improvement.
-Vast array of outfits to wear, each with their own buffs and abilities - AND they react to wind and movement, which calls for fantabulously impressive victory poses!
-A myriad of adornments to add style to Lightning. More than I can keep track of.
-Anti-frustration features and intuitive controls/interface
-Memorable story, music, and visual art that capture the essence of the Final Fantasy universe

Cons!
-Many outfits become obsolete upon progressing to New Game+, because the bound abilities can not be upgraded.
-Some bosses can be -incredibly- difficult on your first playthrough, and may make you ragequit. *cough* Chocobo Eater *cough*

Almost cons, but more just gripes.
-Lightning looks slightly different in CGI cutscenes, as if she's wearing makeup that she isn't wearing in-game. She does look incredible in CGI though. With that said, there are comparatively few CGI cutscenes, some crucial story moments don't even have one.

reviewText:
I initially reviewed this game and reccomended it.
I am sorry, since I am a Huge Final Fantasy 7 fan, and I initially liked the game.

It isn't bad, and I have liked the storyline from what I have played so far.

Unfortunately, there are some qualms.

-The game runs at less than 30fps, when I can now run Metal Gear Phatom Pain well over this.
-The settings are almost non-existant.
+Gameplay is very intersting for story and quests, but can be a repetitive back and forth to complete them.
+Combat is diverse, combining both past and newer elements.
( You can now move, block, and the combat is not paused when determing your action )
-Enemies can take much longer than needed to defeat.
+Enemy tactics can make the game more enjoyable.

( Personal + ) Lightning is more attractive and fun to watch, in various outfits with alternating poses when completing a battle.

My overall evaluation is that Square Enix really needs to make sure the game runs better.

http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198030275311/recommended/345350?tscn=1452536603>

Wonder if it will get deleted.

reviewText:
Great game that showcases SquareSoft's latest ambition to push the envelope in both combat, story telling and graphics. The PC port is the first one in the whole FFXIII series to be not only ported correctly with features that easily make this look like a next gen title.

The game itself features a convoluted story and is a side effect of upping oneself in scale and epicness. But don't let that distract you from the game which is really a showcase of the graphics and the combat system.

The side quests are a grind without any real substance, the main quest is much better but still leaves something to be desired. Still, since it's trying so hard to innovate with the combat and mechanics, I really think people owe to themselves to give it a try and see how semi-real-time combat can work.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The best final fantasy of the XIII trilogy.
Tri-Ace completely nailed the combat system, it's fast, responsive, tactical and skill required, the world presents itselft with 2 open world areas and 2 cities to explore.
The game is all set in a big timer, you will have to complete the main quests in a given amount of time, don't worry tho, you will have the ability of freeze time and other tools at your disposal. The story is probably the weakest point, even due to the nature of the gameplay, you will have to complete many sidequests to level up your characters, not fighting, and this is just the beginning of the peculiarities of this original game.
Sadly it's noticeable the low budged of the work, some zones are clearly better than others and it's the same for the main quests, it took 3 games to understand how to make XIII a really good game but it was too late, so in the end it's just" a good game."

The PC Port of FXIII Lightning Returns, as said in other reviews is undoubtedly the BEST PC PORT for the FXIII Series and is great. I ran FXIII Lightning Returns on 1920 x 1080 60 FPS (Ocassionally dipped down to 40) on a NVIDIA GTX 960M (Comparable to the GTX 750TI for Desktop Users) I5-6300HQ 2.3GHz with 8 GB of RAM
FXIII Gets alot of hate and alot of negative reviews for different reasons and people always have differing opinions. If you did play FXIII and FXIII-2 you MUST play this one. If you want to start with Lightning Returns I would highly oppose it, and URGE you to play through FXIII and FXIII-2 to get the story and get the most from FXIII Lightning Returns.

Too Long; Didn't Read
PROS:
-Realtime Combat System
-Gives Closure
-Replayability (The game gives the option for NG+ I have seen people do 9 Playthroughs)
-Open World (Not Linear like FFXIII)
-SE Gives an ability to FREEZE Clock
-Lightning is Customizeable
-BEST PC PORT for the FXIII Series
-Most entertaining and immersive boss fights (IMO)
-Game Comes with DLC (Except the Aerith and Seigfried Garbs)
-Character Development
-Beautiful Landscape
-No Party Members (If you didn't like the FFXIII Characters will be a pro)
-No EXP system (Lightning gets stronger through finishing Main and Side Quests)


CONS:
-Time Limit (Unless you play like a turtle or lose every fight you will not Time Out)
-Military Time (The Game Clock is in Military Time, Might be difficult to tell time for some people)
-Rushed Story (Makes sense because of the time limit)
-If you don't play on HARD you don't get the full experience.
-No Party Members (Revolves around Lightning, May be a Con for some people)
-No EXP system (Some people liked grinding monsters to lvl, I am not one of those people)
-Difficult Boss Fights (Hard NG+)
-Story might be difficult to understand (Really only in the beginning)

Solid 9/10, My favorite of all the FF games.

(I will finish this review after my completion of NG+ on HARD)

reviewText:
Lightning Returns is a great RPG game ported over from the consoles, the PC port itself is really good as I have experienced no crashes or bugs. However, this game does not support mouse control so you could only play with either a controller or just the keyboard. Unique to the PC platform is the ability to increase the graphical performance of this game as there are options for resolution, lighting effects, shadow quality and et cetera. There is also the options for english and japanese voiceovers which are both equally good.

In this game you play as Lightning and you have thirteen in-game days to complete it. You might think that it would be very constraining since you are given a time limit, but you are also given an ability to stop time which you could use to complete various quest and activities. Speaking of things to do, there are quite alot of them! There are five main questlines and over a hundred side quest/canvas of prayers to do to increase stats and unlock cosmetics. You could also hunt different monsters to extinction and would be given a powerful reward in doing so.

This game would be a delight for those who love customization. You could unlock many different garbs, weapons, shields and adornment to dress Lightning up in and they each have special abilities and stats. The combat in this game is pretty satisfying as it is semi-action combat and no longer turn-based. You could customized your garbs with different abilities and this would allow you to pull out some great combos during battles.

The soundtrack in this game is amazing and really fits well during different scenarios of the game. After completing the game you are given the ability to continue with new game + which allow you to retain almost everything such as gears and stats. You might be wondering why would you want to replay the game again, well there are some pretty cool features in new game + such as a hard mode for added difficulty, ability to upgrade weapon, shields, accesories as well as the ability to restart the game from day one with almost everything intact at any point of the game.

Overall this is a great game and I would recommend it for those who like customization and role-playing games. I would give it a 9/10!

reviewText:
I love/hate this game.

The main quests/plot is mediocre and Hope's repetitive dialogue destroyed any sentiment I had towards him. While he can be helpful at times, his need to rephrase the same thing ten times is exasperating.  The side quests are rather enjoyable and I spend most of my day running around in an attempt to complete them all.

Certain NPC's can only be found at certain times in the day/night which makes you have to manage your time. The cities feel lived in and I'm sad that I can't fully enjoy my time exploring (and cosplaying as Yuna) because I'm always anxiously looking at the ticking clock.  Whilst it is a fun challenge to manage your questing/EP, sometimes it feels restricting.

I'm only 5 days in so I'm sure my opinion will change as I gain more time & complete the areas/main story. The combat is refreshing and the world is immersive as always. I recommend if you want to play as Lightning once more and can take a light hearted approach to the storyline.

reviewText: Highly recommended. Final Fantasy: Majora's Mask, essentially, but with some cool semi-action combat; this creates a game with far more satisfying combat and depth than MM had, but with that same atmosphere of tension and meaningful time management. The game is reasonably difficult, though at times it can delve into near-unfairness (such as fighting a certain boss after running through a location that slowly drains your HP).\n\nThe Lightning Saga naysayers are morons. FFX was far more linear than XIII, and X-2 was just unsatisfying and trapped in the deepest ravine of the Uncanny Valley in terms of its graphics (I understand that it was a different time, but seriously take a good look; that game has NOT aged well in any regard). XIII and XIII-2 were vast improvements over each of the X games, and LR is the first game to truly shove aside the conventions of the series for a (mostly) satisfying ending. Give it a shot.

reviewText:
TL:DR:  This is the port of the game from console to PC. Can’t speak for the keyboard controls as I use a controller but in terms of the game itself the time concept and the open world nature FINALLY back to an extent is very refreshing to see again. The game play is fun and the story is not as deep as other games but still a good game, just a shame it didn’t get much development. Really love lightning as a character but the whole emotionless all the time though got annoying but well play the game and see what happens. If you haven’t played it then may be worth playing if you want an end to the XIII story and played the other two but overall I didn’t mind it. Just I’ve played it on PS3 already when it was out. Only got the steam one because it was pretty cheap on sale.

Positives:
The successor to XIII and XIII-2 and how the other two games should have been.
Finally open world again allowing for doing things pretty much however you want with the exception of time based events.
The time concept was an interesting one. And for those who find it annoying just keep using Chronostasis. When I played it on PS3 I stopped for awhile and totally forgot about that ability and ran out of time. But using that ability you pretty much never will run out of time.
Lighting dress up simulator.
Negatives:
Found myself doing a lot of grinding for items or quests. But that’s what I expected having played the PS3 version upon release.
The depth of the story was a little bit disappointing. I was hoping for a super expansive story and universe after XIII was a little bit of a flop. XIII-2 improved a little but while LR was good, it wasn’t the bound I was hoping for.
occasional cringy dialogue.
Time sink. Loss of productivity for awhile …  Loss of self-respect.  Take your pick.
CONCLUSION IS THE TL;DR

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game. My main motivation for and why I even played it was to get some closure on 13-2's ending and Serah and Lightning. I approached it with the mindset of completing it as quickly as possible to see the story, but I found myself enjoying it more the farther I got.

So first, things I liked. I loved the environments. Such an improvement from 13-2 in terms of size and utility. There was much more to see and do in the world that felt a lot more expansive. I liked how there were a greater variety of NPCs you could interact with (whether as vendors, quest givers, or just random people) It also looked a lot nicer than 13-2, particularly the Wildlands and the Dead Dunes. Side quests are a MASSIVE improvement over 13-2's. I'm not talking about the side AREAS in 13-2 like the Vile Peaks or the extra Oerbas that had a side story (they were well done and we SO needed more of those), I'm talking about those meaningless fetch quests with pretty much zero interaction and take up the 80% of the side quest datalog. In LR, there are more side quests, and a good portion of them have interesting stories and actually feature our protagonist INTERACTING with the quest givers. Not perfect, but a major improvement. I actually liked how this game took a bit more of a personal tone with the protagonist, really delving into Lightning as a person and character. I wish 13-2 treated Serah in the same way. Maybe because this series is pretty much just about Lightning :/.

Moving onto things I didn't like:

The time system. It's awfully frustrating and inconveniencing. How I have to wait for a specific time to access some area or a particular quest. There are some quest givers that only appear during certain times of the day and some parts of any main or side quest can only be done at certain times of the day. And once you're finished your quest and go to turn it in? Oh sorry, the NPCs aren't there anymore and you have to wait till the next day... It's annoying, especially when you have a THIRTEEN DAY TIME LIMIT. You have to painfully wait for some quests to progress because of the time while having a constant reminder of the short amount of time you have left. It's stupid. I know there should be enough time to complete most of the side quests, but it's stressful to have to worry about what time of the day I can do what while being reminded that time is running out. I understand how the time limit imposes a sense of urgency that's more realistic, but it could have been far less annoying and restrictive. Maybe I just want to take my time, enjoy the environments and explore as much as I can.

The combat. I liked having a real time battle system (it's what I'm used to), I liked being able to time my attacks, my dodges, and my guards. It made fighting more immersive. But what I liked even more was the more strategic-based combat system in 13-2. I liked the paradigm system where I was able to choose my strategy, assign roles to party members. Every move felt like it had some thought and planning put into it. I usually like real time combat, but for some reason, it felt off in this game. Nothing bad about it, it's just a personal preference, I guess.

The story for the most part felt rather incoherent and messy. There wasn't some underlying path Lightning was treading on to reach her goal. Her journey felt all over the place. There wasn't anything significant tying each chapter of her goal to save Serah. It felt like she was just visiting the areas to do busywork, taking part in the irrelevant lives of others. Yes, she was working to save the souls of her close friends, but it wasn't tied to her ultimate goal. It feels like the work she's doing throughout those thirteen days didn't advance any part of the overarcing plot: to save Serah. The final encounter did not have enough buildup from the plot at all, which made it feel rather incohesive with the rest of the story. I still enjoyed Lightning's reunion with her friends throughout her story, however, especially the Snow part (one of the sections where you could really feel the connection to the plot). Sections like that maintain the game's continuity from its predecessors.

The villain was a disappointment. He wasn't much of a character. He basically had no presence in the whole game until the very end. He had zero development and didn't feel like a threat at any point in the game, because he was missing for like 95% of the game. You couldn't really feel his influence on the story at all, it's like he came out of nowhere and conviently makes an appearance to take the physical form as a target who the good guys need to unleash their weapons at.

This brings me to my biggest complaint: how the characters were handled. My ultimate motivation for playing this game is to get some closure on what was left behind in FF13-2. Mostly on the characters. For the most part, the characters were handled well throughout the story. It was how they wre concluded that left me really disappointed. Serah, the person that Lightning starts this whole journey for, the centerpiece behind her motivations, and the person who was the main drive for her actions and story, is basically non-existant in the game. And what little there is of her takes form mostly in a fake Serah they created. I thought this was a neat concept (especially how this fake developed to harbor feelings for Lightning) but WHY NOT use what little characterization and development time there was on the REAL character? You know, the one Lightning talks about for the WHOLE GAME. But the biggerst letdown was how the journey for Serah concluded. There is basically no satisfactory closure on her relationship with Lightning. What did Serah want to say to Lightning after being revived? Did she forgive Light for her death in 13-2 (we should all know the answer but I would've liked to hear it from her)? Did she and Light have anything to say to each other after 500 years that showed the power of their will to be together again? Did she have any words about how she felt about everything that happened and being together with Light again? Did she even acknowledge Snow? Her fiance??? Nope, it ends just like that. She utters maybe three lines (that weren't all that memorable) before the game ends. Lightning has spent THREE WHOLE GAMES trying to get her back, even defeated a god. Then it's like she came back and it doesn't even matter at all. I mention Serah, and not so much the other characters, because I really felt like Lightning and Serah were the two most important characters in the trilogy (on how every game has been about them trying to be together), with everyone else a whole level below in terms of significance. If that is to be the centerpeice of your trilogy, it better be well developed and concluded, which I felt that it was not. Not only that, closure on the other characters were scarce too. It's like how everyone is leaving behind their old lives and homes, and no one cares. This game needed better, more satisfying closure on the characters than that last cutscene. It's supposed to be a happy ending, which is good, but there's no reason that a happy ending like this can't be more satisfying.

Overall a decent game that I enjoyed my time with, despite frustrating things, mostly because of the return of characters I grew into, even though in some cases they may have been inconsistent or lacking. The gameplay held its own well enough for me, though on a mechanical standpoint, this game really doesn't have much going for it, as there isn't anything all that special about it. The game is mostly carried by the characters built from the two precious games, and their stories. If you like the character or generally like Final Fantasy or JRPG style characters, then this may be your thing. If you don't care about the characters or the story beyond 13-2, I would say this isn't worth the time.

reviewText:
I don't usually do reviews on here, however after playing this game I felt I had to.

All round a brilliant game that I originally missed on the ps3 due to the end of the generation. I have played every FF and can safely say this is one of my favourite, I didn't get on well with FF13 however this game captured me. Below is the reasons.

PROS

Great combat system once you get used to it (at the start its a tad underwhelming but this gets better)
Good dress choices/schemata (who doesn't want to dress up the waifu)
Great mob variation
Actual storyline with a plot......im Looking at you falcie besie lesie ff13
Replay value & many optional side bosses quests
Music - now this is the main one, the music in this game is amazing truly is one of the best scores I have heard in any game. From Chocobos to peaceful temples.


CONS

Chronostasis can be abused to much and sometimes distracts from the game & causes the worry of managing your EP
Some quests can fail for really silly reasons
The tutorial explains Perfect Guard, but doesn't tell you this works on attacks as well. (you can literally get halfway through the game before you realise.

Other than that a great port, with good graphic options, very little stuttering and fast load times - also the game does look stunning and the design overall is top notch.

EXTRA

Not enough Snow saying he's the Hero
Needs more Moogles
You wont realise how much time you put into dressing your Waifu.......

reviewText:
Played this game on console prior to the Steam release. This was a decent enough port. It ran smoothly for me and even had English voices included, since XIII and XIII-2 only had Japanese VO for me due to regional restrictions for whatever reason. But overall it was a good port and it felt nice to finally play LR at 1080p 60 fps and have shorter load times. Really made a difference.

As for the game itself, my opinion stands that gameplay-wise it's superior to the previous XIII games, because of the brand new combat system that's reminiscent FF X-2's dressphere system, even though sometimes it may seem like the game is basically Lightning Dressup Simulator 2013. There are a WIDE range of garbs you can choose from, and you can customize the skills and weapon types that they use. They usually have one or two skills that are locked to that specific garb, so each garb can be unique in their own way.

You get skills like Attack, Fire, etc as drops from enemies and their levels vary. You can upgrade these skills by way of synthesis and later on in the game boost their levels. There's an encouragement to do New Game + with this game as well, because there are a few new features available to you that you can only get in NG+, such as upgrading weapons and shields. I was a little disappointed at first that you couldn't do that from the start, but if you think of your first playthrough as a stepping stone, it's fine.

The game pretty much drops you into its world and lets you go about the various main quests and side quests however you like, so I wouldn't say it's COMPLETELY linear. But I wouldn't say that it's open world, either. It also has a time limit with an in-game clock that can be a hassle if you don't know how to manage it and use it efficiently. I highly suggest following a guide, because certain quests in the game have very specific requirements, and their availability very much depends on the time of day and your progress in the main questline of that area. The reason I recommend guides is because the game doesn't really tell you much about these things when it comes to finding or completing these quests, and since the world of the game is a literal ticking timebomb, having a guide handy will help you complete as many quests as possible, as fast as possible, if you're the completionist type like myself.

The story is, quite frankly, abysmal nonsense. Granted, the XIII series' story in general wasn't that strong in the first place, but I liked the simplicity of it and thought it ended nicely. However, starting from XIII-2 it just went downhill from there when it started to introduce time travel and alternate universes. LR expanded on that and made the story even more nonsensical and not even worth your time investing in, in my honest opinion. Since I'd already experienced the story in my first playthrough on console, and was completely baffled at the time, this time around I skipped through the cutscenes and dialogue. I just couldn't be bothered with it anymore.

I'd recommend this game based on the gameplay alone and suggest that you tune out the story if you liked the story in XIII, because this game pretty much ruins it all with unnecessary convolutedness and turning all the characters into hollowed-out shells.

reviewText:
In this game, you play as an overburdened and emotionally withdrawn warrior named Lightning. She has been awoken from centuries of sleeping in a crystal stasis to be humanity’s savior in the last days of Nova Chrysalia.

The world is going to end in thirteen days (or fewer, if Lightning fails). Lightning’s primary motivation throughout the game is to reunite with her sister, Serah. The primary conflict of the story is Lightning’s increasingly antagonistic relationship with the all-powerful deity who holds Serah hostage unless Lightning agrees to become humanity’s savior. This relationship is strained by the presence of an enigmatic figure named Lumina.

Lightning is a steadfast protector of her friends and offers salvation to those who need it most, but the burdens of godhood force her to struggle with her own humanity. She remains emotionally unavailable to those who care for her and her interactions with those she saves are (at least on the surface) cold and driven by necessity more than empathy. Nonetheless, she is determined to protect her last remaining family member, Serah, by any means. Her journey reminds me of Rose’s from Sony’s Legend of Dragoon and her cold but protective persona reminds me of Mikasa Ackerman from Attack on Titan.

Mechanically, I had low expectations going into this game. The doomsday clock scenario sounded needlessly constricting and the new combat style seemed unvarying from fight to fight. However, I am happy to say that the doomsday clock gave me more than enough time to finish all that I wanted to do in a single playthrough. The combat was enjoyable, though I didn’t enjoy the staggering mechanic in this game as much as I did in the previous two entries.

My least favorite thing about this game is the dialogue (and unnecessary monologues). Almost every sentence felt banal, monotonous, and repetitive. Though I was emotionally invested in Lightning and her journey, there were several times throughout my 50-hour playthrough that I felt compelled to skip through cutscenes and conversations. The ideas the story reaches for are interesting enough, but the way they are presented comes off uninspired. Luckily, the game keeps track of all major events in its ‘Datalog’ feature (a catalogue of information about the game’s world and mechanics).

You can choose between English audio and Japanese audio (with subtitles). I chose to play the game with Japanese audio and I feel the game’s dialogue wasn’t quite as bad. I feel the voice acting in the Japanese audio is more genuine than the English one, so the dialogue doesn’t come off quite as tedious.

Though the objectives are typically mundane and the dialogue remains uninspired at best, I love the sentimental plots of some of the side-quests. You have the opportunity to save a robot who rationed his energy source just enough that he could be with his friends at the world’s end, reunite a woman and her dog, and attend a romantic dinner with a man who was stood up by his girlfriend. Some of these stories are contained to a single quest, while others may result in a chain of quests. In completing these missions, you save the souls of these people so that they can be reborn in the new world.

Overall, I loved the time I spent watching Lightning’s epic tale unfold and interacting with the world of Nova Chrysalia. The ability to customize what Lightning wears into battle is great (I liked her outfits from the previous two games the best). I liked the pacing and difficulty of this game well enough to recommend it to anyone who enjoys roleplaying games, though I would like to see more complex battle systems in the future.

I strongly disliked the game’s dialogue writing and I also disliked how mundane some of the side-quests were. I would like to have been more involved in Lightning’s decision-making regarding some of these quests, but the game offers plenty of player agency otherwise (in selecting which quests to do, which areas to explore, what gear to wear, and which abilities to use).

The game runs well on my Intel Core i5-3570k (3.40GHz) CPU and GeForce GTX 660. I have no complaints about its technical performance.

Overall, I am very happy I purchased this game and heartily recommend it to other people who love sentimental stories of stoic warriors fighting to save humanity!

reviewText:
The Performance of the PortLightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII is a port that completely blows its predecessors out the water. Performance-wise, Lightning Returns is pretty much superior in every single way compared to its predecessors. Gone are the 30 fps limiters, controller-seeking microstuttering and just terrible optimization in general. With any decent modern day GPU/CPU, you can typically expect a rock solid 60 fps gameplay in battles with only occasional drops to 40-50 fps in the Open World. Due to 60 fps being most important in battles, this port sells itself as a pretty darn optimized port.

Specs that I'm running:
i7-4710HQ @ 3.4 GHz Turbo
8 GB RAM
GTX 860M 4 GB GDDR5

Note that the 860M is the laptop equivalent to the 750 Ti, a mid end gpu that most people use in modern day budget builds. Even so, with everything on max settings (except Scaling - as I'm running a display of 1920x1080 on my laptop), the game holds a 60 fps in battles effortlessly while having occasional dips to 40+ fps in the Open World. Considering the fact that the game had such terrible performance even on consoles, the performance of the PC version is not just a small step-up; it's a huge one.

The Minor Gripes about the PortDespite having such a stellar performance compared to its predecessors on Steam, it takes a few frustrating steps back - steps that which are easily rectifiable and would have made it a perfect port. For one, as this is a first day review, the game only supports a resolution up till 1080p. Hence, everyone who runs higher resolution monitors would not find this too pleasing. There is a very very good chance that some workarounds will be here very soon though, and perhaps, just maybe, a patch from Square Enix themselves.

Other than that, the game still has no option for True Fullscreen to be enabled. True Fullscreen would give quite a big performance boost to everyone, but alas, its not present. The game's fullscreen" is a borderless window.

The biggest gripe to all non-controller users though

reviewText:
In this game, you play as an overburdened and emotionally withdrawn warrior named Lightning. She has been awoken from centuries of sleeping in a crystal stasis to be humanity’s savior in the last days of Nova Chrysalia.

The world is going to end in thirteen days (or fewer, if Lightning fails). Lightning’s primary motivation throughout the game is to reunite with her sister, Serah. The primary conflict of the story is Lightning’s increasingly antagonistic relationship with the all-powerful deity who holds Serah hostage unless Lightning agrees to become humanity’s savior. This relationship is strained by the presence of an enigmatic figure named Lumina.

Lightning is a steadfast protector of her friends and offers salvation to those who need it most, but the burdens of godhood force her to struggle with her own humanity. She remains emotionally unavailable to those who care for her and her interactions with those she saves are (at least on the surface) cold and driven by necessity more than empathy. Nonetheless, she is determined to protect her last remaining family member, Serah, by any means. Her journey reminds me of Rose’s from Sony’s Legend of Dragoon and her cold but protective persona reminds me of Mikasa Ackerman from Attack on Titan.

Mechanically, I had low expectations going into this game. The doomsday clock scenario sounded needlessly constricting and the new combat style seemed unvarying from fight to fight. However, I am happy to say that the doomsday clock gave me more than enough time to finish all that I wanted to do in a single playthrough. The combat was enjoyable, though I didn’t enjoy the staggering mechanic in this game as much as I did in the previous two entries.

My least favorite thing about this game is the dialogue (and unnecessary monologues). Almost every sentence felt banal, monotonous, and repetitive. Though I was emotionally invested in Lightning and her journey, there were several times throughout my 50-hour playthrough that I felt compelled to skip through cutscenes and conversations. The ideas the story reaches for are interesting enough, but the way they are presented comes off uninspired. Luckily, the game keeps track of all major events in its ‘Datalog’ feature (a catalogue of information about the game’s world and mechanics).

You can choose between English audio and Japanese audio (with subtitles). I chose to play the game with Japanese audio and I feel the game’s dialogue wasn’t quite as bad. I feel the voice acting in the Japanese audio is more genuine than the English one, so the dialogue doesn’t come off quite as tedious.

Though the objectives are typically mundane and the dialogue remains uninspired at best, I love the sentimental plots of some of the side-quests. You have the opportunity to save a robot who rationed his energy source just enough that he could be with his friends at the world’s end, reunite a woman and her dog, and attend a romantic dinner with a man who was stood up by his girlfriend. Some of these stories are contained to a single quest, while others may result in a chain of quests. In completing these missions, you save the souls of these people so that they can be reborn in the new world.

Overall, I loved the time I spent watching Lightning’s epic tale unfold and interacting with the world of Nova Chrysalia. The ability to customize what Lightning wears into battle is great (I liked her outfits from the previous two games the best). I liked the pacing and difficulty of this game well enough to recommend it to anyone who enjoys roleplaying games, though I would like to see more complex battle systems in the future.

I strongly disliked the game’s dialogue writing and I also disliked how mundane some of the side-quests were. I would like to have been more involved in Lightning’s decision-making regarding some of these quests, but the game offers plenty of player agency otherwise (in selecting which quests to do, which areas to explore, what gear to wear, and which abilities to use).

The game runs well on my Intel Core i5-3570k (3.40GHz) CPU and GeForce GTX 660. I have no complaints about its technical performance.

Overall, I am very happy I purchased this game and heartily recommend it to other people who love sentimental stories of stoic warriors fighting to save humanity!

reviewText:
Lightning Returns on PC is a fair, but not fantastic port, a huge improvement over previous XIII titles in that regard. It only goes up to 1080p by default, and I have noticed some stuttering when the game streams in new areas, but that could be just my computer. The PC version includes almost all the DLC, but I recommend playing a few hours before unlocking any in game, it's mostly a bit overpowered.

This isn't a technical overview though, so what about the game? Personally I thought the first XIII was okay but often monotonous, and I hated XIII-2. Lightning Returns is by a very large margin my favorite game in the XIII series. They have crafted a much more enjoyable non-linear campaign than XIII-2 by essentially breaking it into a series of short stories that can be tackled in any order. They fixed the monotony of XIII through myriad improvements that make the world feel more alive and interactive. The plot is ridiculous, but it works much better than XIII-2's. No terrible mixed metaphors, no more purple prose. Lightning's personality has changed, and her new aloof, deadpan style is a joy to see against some of the crazy situations. I genuinely love most of the dialogue.

Combat feels like the ultimate refinement of the previous 2 games. I enjoyed the paradigm system alright, but taking direct control of lightning makes you feel more involved in the action. Designing your schemata (a mix between dress-up and paradigms) is fun and gives you a ton of control over what abilities and stats you are focused on. Passive abilities on equipment push you toawrds certain strategies while wearing them. You will swap between them constantly in battle, changing your style as you do. (unless you make 3 very similar ones, which you can do.)

Character growth is unique. You don't get XP from killing monsters and there are no levels. Rather, completing quests rewards you with permanent stat boosts. I love this system. It encourages actively play towards your goal and not grinding. Which is good, because the game is on a (very generous) time limit. Lightning has the ability to pause time, this ability, and others like a full heal, self res or limit break, use a limit-esque gauge that is refilled by killing monsters. At first the gauge will seem very limiting, but in monster filled areas you can often keep a time-stop going indefinitely. (Be sure to abuse it!)

I do have a couple issues with the game. Missions locked to a time of day are a neat way to have the player explore and branch out more, but certain time locked mechanics (like doors that lock/unlock every hour in one dungeon) just punish players for poor play by wasting their time. That makes sense mechanically with the game... but is not terribly fun if it happens. A few missions send you out to find things with no further hints (many let you gather information and are fine) these just feel like complete time wasters and I recommend looking them up online. Additionally, some enemies can be complete sponges that are almost unbeatable unless you carry the right abilities. This led to me running from battles a lot when I first entered areas, and running costs you an hour of in game time every time.

The game is still the best port so far (still have a bit of work to do there) and I believe the best XIII title both in terms of storytelling and game-play. FFXIII fans will probably get the most out of Lightning Returns, but even if you couldn't complete XIII or were turned off by XIII-2 I recommend you check out Lightning Returns.

reviewText:
This game proves that FFXIII universe and it's characters should've been buried into the ground right after the first game.

Techwise this is a first proper FFXIII port to PC supporting some graphical options, arbitrary resolutions and more.
From a gameplay POV this is a nice game (apart from horrendously implemented time mechanic) but a total lack of any sort of character growth over the years (centuries to be precise!!!) is just not right expecialy for a Final Fantasy game. Lightning herself is an extremely boring protagonist being rid of emotions in this title just proves she didn't have any to begin with. Her and other character's superficial motivations make it hard to empathize with them leaving the impression of a poor farce rather than a serious drama (which it is supposed to be). On top of all because of the hazardous combo of pink color, kawaii elements and a lot of character hysterias game leaves a bad aftertaste which lasts for a while and certainly has nothing to do in Final Fantasy series. I want to forget FFXIII trilogy and would rather remember Final Fantasy by dramatic games like FFVI-XII

reviewText:
Time limit -

Just to get it out the way since its a none issue with traction for some reason..... After a day of grinding and exploring I can say the time limit everyone is so scared of means little to nothing against the gameplay; if anything it just serves as a catalyst to make gamers fight more often (which you have to do anyway) to collect something called EP that lets you stop the clock for a set amount of time. I'm still in the first day and I've completed 5 side missions, 4 parts of 2 different main missions, and have collected much. If the time limit scares you, don't let it

Review -

I'll make it quick, there are no bugs in my play through so far and the graphics look amazing. The FPS can be locked or stuck on Dynamic and the graphic options are all present. The graphic options are basic however with only Normal or Advanced to choose from and the screen size stops at 1920 x 1080. I love the cut scenes, action, and combat as its different but a take on a few things other titles had; if I had to explain it I would say a mix of FFXII and FFX-2 as you can move freely during combat and switch what you do by switching outfits during combat and there are a lot of outfits to choose from. This title ends the story and the gameplay gives a sense of urgency and grandeur you don't see often, I believe this game to deliver in both presentation and execution.

reviewText:
After almost throw my life away for about 2 week on this game, I can say I really enjoyed the game.

ofc the lack of time limit always made my rush things and do things in order make it a bit annoying, but the game give you enough time to do most of the quest. (unless you going for genocide/extinct all monsters then good luck man :D)

combat fast pace, fun, you can choose your play style and always need to understand what the monster/enemy do to counter it. Though I have a hard time fighting some of the bosses, and with the lack of healing power, they can be very annoying and make you want to throw the controller.

game has tons of costume, swords shield for people to collect and try make Lightning stronger, and new game+/hard mode you can further upgrade your weapon and costume are good touch thoguh I wish they are in normal mode too. but overall, I had a lot of fun playing the game, and screw around with it. story is not bad, continue with the story they left of on ff13-2(btw still fk that ending) and make the story make a lot of sense, and yes they finally did a semi-good ending this time.

For me to rate this game, I have to give a 8 or 8.5/10 base on my enjoyment and the fun I had, but I can see a lot of people hate this game too. still suggest you at least try it when is on sale, since is not expensive at all, definitely worth the time and money

reviewText:
Lightning Returns is a really nice A-RPG. While many people complain about the Time Limit it isn't even a big problem. With a bit knowladge about the enemies, a bit tactical skill in battles and patience not to use up your EP you're able to beat the game without any problems.

I finished my first playthrough at Day 8 and skipped the last days to the 14th Day to finish my first run and start over on Hard Mode NG+. I must say yes I abused the EP Ability Chronotasis a lot but just because I always had enough EP to use it and also stay alive.

This game runs good, the only downside for many people is the DRM but for me that isn't a problem at all. You're just in need to be online to launch the game. After it's launched you don't need to be online. I got dc'ed once or twice while playing and the game didn't close so it's fine from my perspective.

Gameplay-wise it's a really nice system. If Final Fantasy 7 Remake get's a close-type of Battle system I'll love it. You might ask why, I'll tell you. Every enemy-type is different. Not just from the look, no and also a no to just from the elemental resistance. They also differ in the way you have to defeat them if you're not overpowering them. Some enemies need to be staggered to deal with them at the beginning and they just get shocked if you manage to attack their heads which sometimes is just possible if they attack you. Others instead need to be shocked first to weaken them, then you need to shock them once more to actually deal the real damage. There are also enemies which needs to be shocked while they are shocked to actually deal with them.

Also there are lots of sidequests. Actuall Side-Quests but also Missions from a Mission-Board which doesn't count towards the secret day. This game offers you a lot and I would buy it once again if I wouldn't have it already.

reviewText:
The game. This is a review for the game.

I've played the game so far for 15.1 hours of writing this review and i am confident in saying that i have played my moneys worth - and i haven't even finished the game yet!  Much more to go.

The game works well, runs smoothly, has fantastic graphics, beautiful soundtrack and a very nice storyline. Easily one of the better PC ports of the Final Fantasy series.

This game does require internet to be played, but that doesn't bother me at all. The debate about requiring internet to play a single player game is split, and fair enough. It's all about the person who plays the game to give a care or not. I'm just one of those who don't mind.

Overall, the game is much worth the price and is a current favourite in my game library. 8/10

Buy this game if you travel and need to play in offline mode. you will be able to now! as of christmas day 2015, SE actually released a patch in response to feedback from fans (wow).  ill update my other content as well. SE has enjoyed quite a thorough shaming at the hands of its fans. now its our turn to return the favour and give them encouragement.

i have changed my recommendation to recommend the game.

Here is the plot synopsis if you dont mind a spoiler:

TLDR: This game is the server reset after a long beta period basically.  some people will get a beta-test bonus if lightning manages to save them.  The rest were useless noobs who didn't send in feedback to the developers and won't get to carry over their beta characters.

Long:
Actually.

everyone dies in the end.  its one big crusade for Lightning to right wrongs until the last day.  and to try and save as many souls as possible.  Or to discover the ones worth saving, make them worth saving etc.

It's a bit weird in that respect.  As you approach the end of the game, it becomes clearer and clearer that this is the final fantasy".  When the game ends
date: everyone and I mean EVERYONE dies.  They are gone forever.  Maybe to be reborn; who knows.  This pantheon of gods is quite  alien
recommended: they don't care much about the life they created except to gather data and see how things might occur.\n\nand as we saw in the previous games.. even their "demi gods" and "lesser gods" they created were flawed and needed to be deleted too."

reviewText:
Amazing port! Much more optimization and options than previous games.

In terms of FF13 LR itself, it's the best out of the 3, IMO.  All major quests can be completed in any order you want, and the gameplay is a lot more involved than previous iterations. You don't level up in the tradional sense but instead, save people and complete quests for stats.

This game probably should have been the first in the series as it explains almost everything without using words like L'cie or Fal'cie, and if you've been paying very close attention to FF13's story, the plot will ruin itself.

But to sum it up, it goes full bayonetta.

Definitely worth the 20$ price tag, even more so if you can get it cheaper!
Solid 8.5
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've purposefully not spoiled myself on this trilogy and waited years to finally get this game (and trilogy) ported to PC and not that I've played all three  I can say that I am happy that I did.

It's not my favorite Final Fantasy game(s) from the whole franchise, but as a whole I really enjoyed my time with it.

The enviorements and graphical quality of the game are beautiful alongside it's wonderful soundtrack (which I think it's best from the trilogy).

I recommend it for those who aren't that picky about the story aspects in general. In terms of the story I preferred XIII-2 > LR > XIII, but gameplay wise I would rank LR as the top one (because of it's battle system) followed by XIII-2 and finally XIII.

Conclusion: Should you play this game/trilogy? Answer: MOST DEFINITELY.

reviewText:
Played this back on my Xbox (Preorder) and quite enjoyed it till my Xbox died.

From a techincal standpoint, the game has some issues with framerates in some cutsceens (mainly in the Arc) and in some indoor/outdoor locations. However, none of it is really determental to the enjoyment of the game.

The graphics are 'good enough' for me to not be disapointed in how the game looks for being released two years ago. Still has the FF13 look and feel to the apearance of characters and abilities.

Combat is fun, and the Garbs available make for interesting combos once you unlock more equipment. The more active style of the combat mechanics makes even simple fights a little more interesting. Yes, you could just spam your strongest skill all the time, but maybe you need to brush up on Guard timings. Easy enough to find weak badies and brush up on your own ability.

My only gripe with this game is part of the key mechanic of the game; 13 days and its game over. There is a constant, overbearing clock that is ticking down till the game ends. You can slightly extend your game time, but there is still a very limiting maximum amount of time to enjoy a playthough. I personally dislike that, a lot.

I do recomend this game, even with the aspects that I dislike and the few techical hickups. Its enjoyable and worth the $20 for it.

reviewText:
Lighting Returns the only Final Fantasy XIII game that should have been and that I can recommend.

The cutscene problem seems to have diminished to the point where they went back to their roots, Yes some of them are long, but they are managable to the point that i can actually watch them, compared to the first 2 games.

The timer which most people hate for some reason is a warm welcome to the franchise, makes it actually feel like old school Final fantasy for the type of game it is.

No visual levels, however there is stat upgrades from completing quests(think of Chrono cross's boss battles)

Gameplay - Type-0 with a battle screen, only 1 character, and a jobsystem-ish switching on the fly style. I can't praise it enough.

It may have dresspheres" however it isn't like that unholy Charlies angels type game that some of us try to forget.

Square went into the right direction with this game

reviewText:
The port is definitely better than the previous two installments of the XIII series. It looks plastic-y at the beginning, but at least it runs fine. I'm only experiencing minor framerate drops in Luxerion and Yusnaan, nothing that ruins my enjoyement.
The story is less confusing than I thought reading other reviews, but I'm fresh off the first two.
The combat plays in a meaningful way... while being meaningless, as experience is acquired upon quest completion. The customization possibilities of the Schemata system is amazing. World map is huge and quests have a decent variety. The time limit isn't eally an issue either: I completed all 5 main quests by day 6 and had the rest to complete sidequests and canvas quests at a leisurely pace.

For my first playthrough on easy I went yolo and didn't really use a guide. Already digging NG+.
Now playing online isn't even required anymore so ;) get it!

reviewText:
If I have anything good to say about it, it's that Square Enix finally produced a rather good port of their in-house made game. Other than that, you will like this game only in case you: a) like Lightning as a model (not as a character) b) like what they done to the combat c) like fetch quests in MMOs.

If not, this game is an incredible dissapointment and probably the worst part of the XIII trilogy. The premise and ideas are absolutely fantastic - the world is ending, events of XIII and XIII-2 just postponed/lessened the impact of what the main antagonists were trying to do, but they essentially got what they wanted. People lived for 500 years stuck at the age they were when the ending of XIII-2 happened, no new people are being born. All that is left is that Lightning, as a Savior, saves the chosen souls to be reborn in the new world, where people can live, die and be born again. Sounds amazing, doesn't it? Sadly, the actual events to follow up on this are just horribly dumb.

Instead of a brilliant dark but hopeful ending to the trilogy we get stupidly boring retread on the previously done stories. Story has flashes of brilliance in terms of ideas, but never seems to understand what to do with them. Cutscenes are horribly and sometimes amateurishly directed, dialogues (often monologues) are boring and often poitnless. mini-stories in side-quests are sometimes interesting, but tied to most boring fetch quests you can imagine with most intriguing and involved quests in the entire game being the very first one you get. Things often just happen, get dropped, kinda picked up by the end, but there's no unifying feel to any of it. Everything is just *there*.

Same goes for the combat/RPG systems. Yes it is more involved and action-y than other XIII games, but it's still boring and often pointless. It's no Vagrant Story of Parasite Eve II. In terms of the soul saving, time restricted mechanics it's no Valkyrie Profile either, despite Tri-Ace working on the game. Also some features that could make first playthrough fights at least a bit less pointless are locked away until NG+ and some stay locked unless NG+ is played on Hard. Because reasons.

It's a game with a great premise that fails in devlivering on it. That has features and mechanics that have been used in much better and more fun games. That has an unsatisfying story, that could bring an interesting end to the trilogy, but instead goes for a Lightning wet-fantasy fanfic" feel
date: that often reminds of Metroid: Other M in terms of how boring
hoursPlayed: repetitive and stupid it is. Such a shame."

reviewText:
Perfect Game Review:

2nd Hard Playthrough just to get all achievements but the Final Aeronite Boss and Accessories. Got all the items I need and equipment to defeat him. 10 hours(Again pausing increased time)

Storywise -  it completes the FF13 storyline I still find it very confusing but somehow you will understand the story.

Controls - YOU MUST USE A CONTROLLER - I had to buy one since the keyboard schemes are BAD.

reviewText:
This is, at last, a fairly decent port from Square Enix. Limited but simple graphic options that work, 60fps without stuttering, no launcher, good price, etc.

Very good surprise this port. I didn't expect any good.

Anyways, some cons for some people:

Max resolution 1080p --> In 2015, there is a lot of people (not me) who rather to play at higher resolution, but that won't be a problem soon. Right, Durante?

This game DOES require Steam Cloud to start --> Watch out and read the requirements before buy! It needs Internet connection to start. That's ♥♥♥♥, but, again, not for me and a lot of people. Still I didn't like this.

No Aerith's Schema DLC for PC --> Probably due to license issues. Maybe obtainable thanks to modding?
These three points aside, the game looks really good and works fantastically. Recommended.

They should update the other two games with this system, but probably they won't. What a shame!

reviewText: I have only barely started the PC version of this game; however, I'd like to start by saying: Thank you Square-Enix for finally making a good port of Lightning Returns. I sincerely hope that whatever engine optimizations you made to get things to run at 60fps you reimpliment into FFXIII and FFXIII-2 through patches. Really, good work here. A stable 60fps was I ever wanted.\n\nAnyway, I'm going to make this short. I played this game originally on the PS3, and found myself falling in love with it's quirkiness. Although, there are some muddy textures here and there, and were some frame drops every now and then in the PS3 version, the new battle system and the time system really worked for me. I'm not sure if this is for anyone, because the game is VERY Japanese, but if you like quirky characters, over the top action and drama, this is a great entry in an awesome series.

reviewText:
Pros:
- 60 fps out of the gate, also the option to lock the game to 30 if any stuttering occurs.
- Vast amount of graphical options, plus I like the fact we don't have to quit the game to enable or disable any of them, just hover to the top of the screen and they pop up.
- Incredibly optimized compared to the first two games in the trilogy, no stuttering or issues running the game maxed out.
- Pretty long game, only 14 hours in and still have so much to do not to mention the new game plus for stuff I missed.
- Music is just as good as the first two games.
- Combat system is a mixed bag but I do prefer it over the first two games.

Cons:
Weaker story, but spinoffs usually are meh story wise compared to the orignials.
