reviewText:
I only paid 10 dollars for this game and still feel ripped off. I know now that I'm not going to finish it, and I tried to convince myself that my first impressions were wrong and that the game is anything above terrible, but I just couldn't lie to myself any longer.

The plot is focused around your strong female avatar traveling the world and gathering worthy souls before the end of times. If this sounds like a plot you want to play out, I suggest getting yourself a copy of Valkyrie Profile. It's the same thing, just done a lot better many years before FF13 came out.

tl;dr - Buyer's Remorse

reviewText: Now. Before I start, I just want to say that I never liked the XIII series, never liked XIII or XIII-2. Just to me the series was horrible, FFXIII's level designing and story was awesome and all but the battle system I had issues with, the fact that you had to switch to different modes to change what effected you or the enemy was horrible and unforgiving. So then XIII-2 came along and they fixed that but the battle system was the same, push random buttons and the battle system will choose the command for you, I hated that so much! It made the game feel boring. So when Lightning Returns came out the first time I never bought it or looked at gameplay, I just felt like it would be the same boring mess that it already was. So when I saw it came out on PC I decided to buy it. And if I hated, I would refund it. So I gave it a try and holy mother of Tetsuya Nomura did it fix a WHOLE bunch of things. The battle system was TOTALLY different and original and I LOVED it, it fixed things like the different modes and you can select the moves and each time it hits the enemy you feel succeded and that's an awesome feeling! The storyline was good as all the other Final Fantasy's are! In conclusion to this huge review I say that this is a good buy for those who disliked FFXIII and FFXIII-2 the way I did.

reviewText: This ported version is flawless and very intriguing. At 60fps/1080p not a bad deal at all with dynamic scenary and crystal clear graphics that are far better off than the one made for consoles. I have not really seen any problems so far so thats actually good. If you got the other two FF13 here on steam, this will be a great game to add to them to make the story complete or if you love RPG games look no further as this one will satisfy your taste.\n\n10/10  Will totally love to see more remastered versions of Final Fantasy here on steam including the upcoming remastered FF7 :)

reviewText:
TL;DR summary below:

PROS:
+ Some of the most satisfying ATB combat to be found in any Final Fantasy, ever.
+ Lots of schemata options and customization for your character so you can play dress-up to heart's content
+ Looks and (most of all) plays beautifully on modest hardware. Good job finally, Square Enix!
+ Lots of graphics options and graphics options are in-game without obtrusive launcher
+ All DLC (excepting Aerith schemata due to licensing issues) included Day One
+ Great story-line (this is IMO, but you either like it, love it or hate it)
+ Very open world after first chapter and most quests can be completed in almost any order (if requirements are met)
+ Many hours of game play and content
+ Price is right

CONS:
- Not all resolutions supported beyond 1080P (I game on 1080P so not a deal breaker personally, but if you have Ultra Mega HD displays caveat emptor)
- Always on-line Steam Cloud DRM (I am almost always on Wifi or tethered online on my mobile data so personally not a deal breaker, but if it is for you then don't buy the game)
- Time limit system in game play

OTHER THOUGHTS:
Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII (to be known as LR FFXIII from now on) is the odd duck in the trilogy, but with a highly satisfying ATB combat system, good PC optimization and in-game graphics options, breathtaking visuals and lots of content to be had, LR FFXIII is a must-play and a satisfying end to the FFXIII trilogy. 8.5/10

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
DETAILED REVIEW:

So first off, let me preface this by saying that I overall have been a fan of the Final Fantasy XIII series, although I haven't finished many of the games within the trilogy for different reasons. FFXIII was hard to get through on Xbox 360 due to the linearity for about 2/3 of the game and when it re-released for PC I decided to give it a second try but found it nigh unplayable due to poor optimization and unstable frame rates. FFXIII-2 also owned on XB360, but just never got to playing due to huge backlog of games on my old XB360. Gave it a second chance on PC, but between backlog and reports of same issues that plagued the first PC release I shelved it. I own the final installment on PS3 and bought it digital when PSN had a sale for 50% off and played it some, but the PS3 version was just awful looking, played poorly and at the time I was turned off by the limited time game play mechanic in a RPG (which usually focus on exploration) before I understood the games mechanics. I didn't touch again until it came out on PC. Maybe I just have an Attention Deficit Disorder when it comes to games, but moving on...

First off, despite my fears and misgivings after being burned on the other two PC releases and the poor ports they received, let me get this out of the way: LR FFXIII looks and plays amazing! There are quite a variety of graphics options and they are contained within the game through drop-down options (no ugly or obtrusive launcher). This is a big deal for me, because my HTPC is set up to launch automatically into a Big Picture Mode shell so it's really jarring when I have to set down my controller for other Square PC ports and mess with my wireless KB&M (first world problems, I know). There are some downsides to the graphics options. First, there's no slider or degrees of graphics options, just either Standard or Advanced (sometimes Off) which kind of sucks. Also, there's no actual AA option to speak of although it looks like there is some sort of filtering in the Scaling Display option that varies in IQ. Finally, to address one of the real glaring issues for many QHD and UHD and Ultra Mega HD display owners: only up to 1080p is officially supported. I don't see why a PC game or any application in this day and age can't query the OS for available resolutions and scale to that display. I only game on and own 1080p displays so not a personal deal breaker, but caveat emptor for those who want bleeding pixels to burn their retinas and own the high-res displays. Most importantly, this game plays very smooth at 1080p and 60FPS with modest hardware. My HTPC runs on i3-4160 and Nvidia GTX 960 and 8GB RAM and it runs constant 60FPS with all settings maxed. My laptop runs on a i7-4720HQ aand GTX 960M with 8GB RAM and all settings maxed with Display Scaling to Advanced (which seems to be less impact than Standard) and still 1080p60FPS with occasional dips to 45FPS (mostly in The Wildlands which is huge open world area so more to render) but still very playable. As far as other technical aspects, I must mention that this game requires an online connection and Steam Cloud enabled to play. I will make you aware of it, but there are some bashing the game solely on this alone and even starting flame campaigns" against the game due to it. If it's a deal-breaker to you due to you can't always be online or you have issues with Steam Cloud
date: then don't buy it. If you didn't know about it and bought
recommended: then get a Steam refund. I am always online Wifi at home or tethered on the go
hoursPlayed: so nothing for me to lose sleep over. Moving on...\n\nAs far as gameplay goes
voteText: it's Day 2 in the in-game time and ~15 hours in real play time and I am loving it! The different areas to go through and explore are awesome. Combat is very deep and satisfying and requires pacing and timing between the various schemata. Schemata are outfits you equip your character with but aren't just for aesthetics: each schemata has custom abilities and enhancements
helpfulPercent: strengths and weaknesses. In addition
votesHelpful: you can outfit your character with additional skills and attacks
votesTotal: weapons and shields that also have their own innate abilities and enhancements. You cannot button mash and you must think about your equip load out and attacks
votesFunny: especially with stronger enemies (not just bosses) are you will get you butt handed to you. There have been times where I have gone too aggressive or not watched my ATB gauge and paid the price for it
commentsCount: eating the full brunt of an attack. There's also a Stagger mechanic system that takes advantage of elemental weaknesses (for enemies who have them) and Perfect Guards
column16: which is a properly timed guard right before moment of impact that encourages players to think about what skills and equipment is used in their load out along with timing of Guards. Staggering an enemy will halt their attack and make them more susceptible to attacks
column17: both physical and elemental weaknesses. This encourages strategic and timed game play
column18: as opposed to mindless button mashing. It honestly works very well for this game and the combat is one of my favorite things about the game
column19: especially when you face off against an enormous
column20: powerful foe and you still come through victorious through proper schemata and skill preparation and well-timed inputs (like the first time you fight a Reaver in the Wildlands). Now
column21: the dreaded time limit aspect of the game. I must admit
column22: when I first played the game on PS3 I didn't have a guide and I didn't understand the game's mechanics. The time limit was a big turnoff and I stopped playing it. First off
column23: I HIGHLY RECOMMEND getting the guide for this game. If it isn't available in hard copy there's e-guides or PDF scans of the guide online. Second
column24: there's a mechanic in the game called Chronostasis that allows you to temporarily halt time and eventually you get the ability to teleport or fast travel to locations you have been before
column25: which consume EP which are earned as you defeat enemies
column26: complete quests or are reset at certain points in the game. Get to understand these mechanics and use them to your advantage. It will make the game and the time limit aspect much more manageable. I use to sweat the time
column27: but once I learned how to use and take advantage of Chronostasis
column28: Teleport and EP management the game has become much more enjoyable. Give this game a second chance. I did and I'm loving it!"

reviewText: Now. Before I start, I just want to say that I never liked the XIII series, never liked XIII or XIII-2. Just to me the series was horrible, FFXIII's level designing and story was awesome and all but the battle system I had issues with, the fact that you had to switch to different modes to change what effected you or the enemy was horrible and unforgiving. So then XIII-2 came along and they fixed that but the battle system was the same, push random buttons and the battle system will choose the command for you, I hated that so much! It made the game feel boring. So when Lightning Returns came out the first time I never bought it or looked at gameplay, I just felt like it would be the same boring mess that it already was. So when I saw it came out on PC I decided to buy it. And if I hated, I would refund it. So I gave it a try and holy mother of Tetsuya Nomura did it fix a WHOLE bunch of things. The battle system was TOTALLY different and original and I LOVED it, it fixed things like the different modes and you can select the moves and each time it hits the enemy you feel succeded and that's an awesome feeling! The storyline was good as all the other Final Fantasy's are! In conclusion to this huge review I say that this is a good buy for those who disliked FFXIII and FFXIII-2 the way I did.

reviewText: The wait for this game was well worth it. Finally a well done port for Square Enix in Lightning Returns: Final Fantasy XIII. The optimization settings are all what people have asked for and the game runs flawlessly on even a mid-tier PC setup on highest settings.\n\nThe gameplay is amazing and a good divergent from Final Fantasy XIII and Final Fantasy XIII-2. There is tons of stuff to do in this game despite you technically having 13 hours to beat the games. If you were able to stick it through Lightning Returns's predecessor, this game is a very rewarding ending to a decent Final Fantasy triology.

reviewText: This game has opened up a new genre for me, and I dub it the 'chore' game.  It's literally an entire game of fetch quests with a simple twist: there's a timer.  Every character and NPC is completely aware of this, and in an attempt at breaking the fourth wall, Lightning contually bemoans and begrudgingly accepts these countless tasks thrown her way under the guise of duty.  My biggest issue is the game could have at least TRIED to hide this!  Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING will work as follows: a person will tell you something they need, you will get that thing and take it to them, this with either complete the quest or simply lead you to the next person who tells you they need something.  While it could be argued many games work this way, in LRFFXIII there is no padding.  If you aren't fetching an item, you're looking for a person to fetch for.  I would have been shocked if a SINGLE character said, I can help you
date: right this way!"  Spoiler alert: that will never happen.\n\nI'm guessing this is aimed at anyone who absolutely must know the conclusion to Lightning's story ... but this game is clearly tacked on the series.  Five centuries after XIII-2 the world is going to be destroyed in thirteen days and it's up to Lightning to get the band back together ... in heaven.  It might not be as dumb as it sounds except it's delivered almost exclusively through forced exposition that DOES. NOT. STOP.  You will different conversations spouting the same exposition often several times in a row!  Need a thing?  Don't worry
recommended: Hope will remind you every five minutes of that thing
hoursPlayed: even if it so happens you know what you need to do but you can't because the game runs on a clock.  Like the fetch quests
voteText: there is no deviation from the strict exposition-only policy.\n\nSo it's basically what it looks like
helpfulPercent: a cosplay fetch quest fantasy.  I'm not really sure what Square Enix was trying to create here but while I admit it has some charm and appeal
votesHelpful: personally I found it too limited to put up with for more than my recorded play time."

reviewText:
An RPG who's main mechanic is time limits.

If you are a casual gamer/rpg'er/Final Fantasy player stay away. This game is a load of stess.

You have 14 in game days till the game ends.  For every minute real time 'x' minutes pass in the game.  This time does not stop for menues, dialog, nor battles.  Missions are only avalible in a set time window inside those '14 days' and have requirments in them like 'find these 6 things and be at point Z at 7am sharp'   STRESS STRESS STRESS

You don't gain exp or levels from battles but from competing quests (saving souls) you do get gil (money) and items though, but overall battles are somethign to avoid.  So, again, stress.

There is a mechanic to 'pause time', for a time, but it's a finite resource in the game, only obtainable via completing more quests. In which you may be missing, or find yourself needing to use this finite resource to complete!

I am curious who the desginers thought they where making this game for as so many central game mechincs run completly counter to so many who enjoy RPGs and past Final Fantasies.

The central time mechianic is by far my biggest reason to cautioning people from buying this game.  But there are plenty of other cons.

Dialog seems bad even by FF standards, graphics are quite poor, yes, certain things look pretty, but it seems like another step in what I feel like has been FF's direction of making certain things look good for screen shots, but everything else look terrible.  Such a large studio on such a large franchise should have everything looking much better then this.  So many just... boxs.  They may be skinned like other things, but they are a straight up polygon box.  Nothing is even bumb mapped. It's... really mind blowing for a game made past the ps2 era.

Buggy.  If my controler turns off because I walked away for a while it reverts to keybaord/mouse controls and won't change back until you restart the game.

Lazy port. Menus literally tell you not to turn off your PLAYSTATION 3 when saving. uhg. Mouse curse floats over screen.

Spent an hour just getting the setting set the way I wanted because not only do you have to relaunch the game for most of them, the 'main' setting page doesn't seem to affect existing saves.  Nope, have to load the save then open the menu and change those same settings there instead.

Honestly, I have grown so disappointed in the franchise over the years.  I keep trying to like it again, maybe 'that one' just wasn't for me, trying to dawn some rose colored glasses of nostalgia for the franchise in which to grade it on a curve... but they dont' take.  Square failed on this.  This is a bad game.

I would have used Valve's refund policy for the first time ever on this, but unfortunatly between the time I spent getting the settings right, walking laps in frustration, and getting far enough in to the game to get a reasonable feeling for what the game will ACTUALLY be like (which I probabaly didn't even get there, always takes a while in any Final Fantasy game) I had rung up 3 hours 'play time', one hour past the max allowed for a refund.

Just skip this ones guys, Square really doesn't deserve the money. I'd go as far to say they should be ashamed, nothing contained within is deserving of the FF name. Nor a good review if it had been called something else and held at the standards any other game is.

reviewText:
This isn't exactly a jrpg game, it's more like a bet on a new gaming style, it feels like a giant puzzle/strategy game where you have to start it over and over till you reach the perfect speed run. Reminds me when i used to play resident evil over and over to reach the fastest playthrough.

People complain about lightning personality, i think its the most mature character square enix has ever created, she has emotions but the fact that she handles them quite well makes the emotional kids angry with themselves.

The problem with this game is that it has a great system. but do not let you enjoy or explore it without forcing you to play it from the beggining over and over. Only the most clever people will get it right from the first try.

Its a big world, full of dumb quests like an MMO, and great quests that you can't explore without elaborating a complex and unreliable strategy involving some of the game gimmicks.

So, if you is an ansious person, have no patience at all or can't work under pression, dont buy this game

reviewText: I started playing this game when it first came out on the xbox 360 and ps3. With 30fps and not-so-bad graphics at the time, the game was somewhat good. It ran smooth for the most part and never game me any issues. Square Enix then releases FF13 and 13-2 and they were both terribly ported. With LRFF13, I was hoping for much more with the huge delay they gave this port. It still seems they needed a significant amount of time to get this running perfect because it does not. Optimization is terrible. With an amd r9290x and an i7 4770k, This game should be nothing to run on high settings but it is VERY sluggish. Dropping the graphics down will fix it but it is a pretty bad eyesore to play when you had the settings on high. There are not very many graphics options either to get the best out of your experience. This game has many issues and I cannot recommend it to anyone until these issues are fixed.

reviewText:

So if you are a fan of the Final Fantasy universe, GO BUY IT!

reviewText:
Though it's not the best port, it's clear that SE finally listened and it's obvious that they worked a bit on this port, and that's commendable. Given their history with the other 2 previous games in the series, this port is AMAZING!


The ESC button no longer closes the game automatically.
There's more graphics options (though not enough) with no launcher.
The default keyboard bindings are way better than the previous ones and they're actually usable this time around. (You can change them yourself)
60 FPS support at 1080p*

Pretty good port, and I'm hoping that this proves to be profitable so that SE continues to improve their work on PC. Who knows, we might get a simultaneous launch of KH3 or FFXV along with the consoles. Here's hoping

*After playing for quite a bit, the FPS is not stable at all. Often times it drops to as low as 20 for whatever reason; This is only outside of battles, which is most of the game unfortunately.

That being said, it's still playable, I just wish that they would fix this issue.

reviewText:
Like what everyone else says, the game runs pretty solid at 60FPS now with minor drops you shouldn't really notice
sooo perhaps it was worth the wait ever since FFXIII-2 PC release (around one whole year?)

Some people personally have odd setups that doesn't cater their resolution (sorry 1920x1080p is the standard right now?).

Gameplay
Least storyline imo out of all three games but in terms of gameplay it outclasses the previous two
- Open World
- Very quest based (no level system)
- Majoras Mask Based (lol)


Heads up to those that wants to play this game and want to do one run only.  I've played this game on PS3 so here are some advice.
- This game expects you to play it twice at least if you want 100%
- Few Quests are permanently missable (may want to rely on guide for this) unless you consider new game+
- Weapon upgrades unlocks after new game+
- Do not sell your level one abilities.  It's better to upgrade it then to straight up buy higher level abilities.

Well it's the last game to the saga and despite the beginning sounding all religious like with god this and god that, if you can get past that, I think the game is relatively fun.

Also play this game on a controller.  Playing this game with keyboard is cancerous imo.

reviewText:
I can't believe it took a year for SE to put this game on Steam, I have an X360 Controller so I don't really care how the port is, that was just too long.

BUT, DLCs are included and the same price as its predecessors, as well as 60fps 1080p great graphics (among FF series), that worth it.

When you put on a DLC outfit the BGM is different when finishing a battle, too. For example if you put on Yuna's Summoner outfit the BGM will be the same as in FFX. There are also many kawaii decorations.

This time the battle system changes a little bit, it is more simultaneous. I just prefer the previous ATB battle system

reviewText:
[Review based on playing the PS3 version at launch and PC version for less than two hours.]

Graphics are a nice upgrade from the PS3 version, although the game already looked great. Gameplay is fun and fast-paced, with enough to keep you entertained for many hours. Although not exactly open world, it's very non-linear with most of the game consisting of side quests tied to the in-game clock, which can only be accessed and continued at certain times of the day.

I would not suggest playing this for the story, but rather for the intense and plentiful gameplay, and dressing up Lightning in cute outfits. Really, Square-Enix must have put at least a third of their budget into costume design because there is a buttload of them, including many cameos" from past FF games such as Kain
hoursPlayed: December 10, 2015
voteText: true
votesHelpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I freaked out when I saw the game running at 60fps. I'm not running this on the best computer in the world and I'm seeing no issues.

As for the gameplay, it's the same as it was on console so no surprises there. Good style of action-RPG where you have to manage multiple ATB bars at once all while making sure not to get hit. If you're a hardcore fan of turn based RPGs then this isn't the game for you.

The story wraps up the trilogy of confusing plot points by essentially rehashing everything we knew up to this point into a new world seperate from that of Cocoon or Pulse from the previous games. Returning characters get their own story arcs and all playable characters from XIII & XIII-2 make an appearance (even though unplayable) in what can only be described as the rapture meets a soap opera. You race against the clock trying to save everyone's souls which actually ties into the levelling" mechanics of the game. The more people you save
date: the better chance you have to unlock a secret dungeon before the end.\n\nPlus side of the PC version is you get all the DLC (minus Aerith... For now) and even the choice between English & Japanese voices for cheaper than their console counterparts. Other than the FPS difference
recommended: I'm not seeing a dramatic difference with the graphic settings
hoursPlayed: of which you can only select "Standard" or "Advanced" for the majority of options. The game doesn't use a launcher this time round which is a plus side for changing settings on the go (although some options such as voices and enabling DLC still require reboots).\n\nIf you enjoyed the game when it was on console and want another shot at it"

reviewText: Decent port with a weird options setup. Gameplay is about the same as the first two games except with no party members. This time you switch clothing outfits to change your attack setup, each outfit has a limited amount of uses per time so you'll have to constantly switch between outfits in battle for usage of other attacks or due to time degradation. The visuals are great but character designs are mostly too silly and zany (for my tastes) while the game itself tries to take everything seriously. We have characters in chicken outfits, plastic glasses, cat ears, checkered clothing. Everybody in this game must shop at thrift stores and costume departments. But then again it's the end of the world, in this game you're limited to 13 in game days to complete it or the world end...  Don't worry too much, fail and restart from the beginning, keeping your EXP and some items. Every five minutes you're reminded god is watching you and the VA is great for those that like monotone.\n\nIf you like Final Fantasy games, JRPGs, or long games with good character custimization give this a go.  Another thing, nice to see it's not the price of a brand new $60 game. Instead you'll find it's a more suitable $20 (or less).

reviewText:
Though it's not the best port, it's clear that SE finally listened and it's obvious that they worked a bit on this port, and that's commendable. Given their history with the other 2 previous games in the series, this port is AMAZING!


The ESC button no longer closes the game automatically.
There's more graphics options (though not enough) with no launcher.
The default keyboard bindings are way better than the previous ones and they're actually usable this time around. (You can change them yourself)
60 FPS support at 1080p*

Pretty good port, and I'm hoping that this proves to be profitable so that SE continues to improve their work on PC. Who knows, we might get a simultaneous launch of KH3 or FFXV along with the consoles. Here's hoping

*After playing for quite a bit, the FPS is not stable at all. Often times it drops to as low as 20 for whatever reason; This is only outside of battles, which is most of the game unfortunately.

That being said, it's still playable, I just wish that they would fix this issue.

reviewText:
If you are looking with comparison's in mind to 13 and 13-2 performance wise, then this is a buy.

I was streaming this just as it came out and the performance (with streaming in mind) is really good.
60fps largely, no stutters or screentearing. There are some dips in fps in certain places, most notably in Luxerion. Which looks like it might be the lighting. Right after that we went to Wildlands as that looks like the place to expect the most framerate loss (biggest zone), but proven otherwise. The Dunes was stable as was Yusnaan.
In Luxerion there are a couple of spots (which looks likely to be the lighting) where the fps went to 45, but that goes back to 60fps in matter of seconds if you passed it.( #Edit Replayed the first hour without streaming and the problems have lessened. Fewer dips and less heavy, lowest dip was 50 and went back to 60 in 1-2 seconds)
Combat was a stable 60 fps.

Prologue Gameplay
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H953AcWN8kQ

All in all I can safely recommend this port, Square Enix delivered.

My modest rig: i5 3570, GTX 960, 12GB ram, Windows 10.
voteText: 12 of 28 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewerDisplayName: W r a i t h
reviewText:
EDIT: I realize now why this has so many dislikes, turns out I had 60 fps on the brain considering this ports never hit it that so I wrote I was getting 60 fps instead of 30 fps. Welp, too late now.

TL;DR at the bottom.


So, Lightning Returns, the third installment of the notorious FFXIII trilogy. Well, first things first, the all-important question for us PC users. Does it run well? Well, yes, yes it does. Unlike the previous two titles, I'm able to get 30 fps for the most part..... I say for the most part because I find when I'm in menus it definitely dips here and there, but really, it's the menus. Also, there's the occasional spike here and there but it's not a real problem. There's no more launcher, if you run your mouse up the to the top of the screen, there's a unimmersive drop-down menu which has all the settings you desire. Well, not really. There's a bunch more options, but you choose between standard and advanced as far as I know. But regardless, it looks and plays better than it did on consoles. Some things to point out though, IT'S NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE TO PLAY WITHOUT A CONTROLLER. This time around, the nature of the gameplay means you'll need more buttons, and square obviously doesn't know how to make a keyboard button layout that actually makes any logical sense. It'd be much simpler if there was mouse support, but I think it may have occured to you something was up when I said you get the drop-down menu when you drag the mouse up to the top edge in-game. Yeah, there's no actual mouse support here, making it even more impractical to play with a keyboard. It's not even KB+M anymore, it's just KB. Oh, missed an important point, you need online connectivity to play. Yeah, that's brutal. Anyways, on the to the review.

-----------

Uhhh, so basically a bunch of nonsense happens and the story of FFXIII-2 which overwrote the story in FFXIII, is overwritten again by the story in Lightning Returns FFXIII here. Welp, sure, whatever, no one's really expecting anything at this point. Anyway, bad stuff has happened various circumstances have made everyone still alive immortal. However, the world will end in 13 days and you, Lightning, obviously, have been chosen by the god Bhunivelze to save the souls of the worthy within the 13 days. And you know all the other characters show up, blah, blah, you defy fate because when do you not do that in these games. Bottom line, who really cares. I like the ending scenes though. The characters are still dull sacks of potatoes. Snow, whose was the energetic meathead, is kind of a dull sack of potatoes now. Hope, lmao whatever. Lumina, a new character, mysterious....mysterious and generic. Yes. So on and so forth. The characters are boring, that won't change no matter how many games you put out.


-----------

Let's talk about something more interesting. The combat system has been redesigned yet again and so we go from having a party of 3 in FFXIII, to a party of 2 in FFXIII-2 with 1 monster ally, to a party of 1 tsundere and her various costumes, er, schematas. You can now move in battles, albeit it's not that useful, and basically you switch between 3 schemata, each with it's own abilities and action bar. Essentially you play all 3 party members combined into one. There's realtime blocking now though. Now that all sounds great, real-time combat, moving and blocking, etc. But really, it's still arguably turn-based. You unload on the enemy with all your skills, then you save some points to dodge and block the enemies attacks. By that time some of your bars on your schematas will have refilled, signalling it's your turn again and you proceed to spam once more. It's TBS, without actually telling you it's TBS. Staggering is back of course, that's the name of the game no matter what enemy you happen to come across. Get a monster's stagger up, stagger it,unload spells, rinse and repeat. It's still fun though. This version comes with all the DLC schemata, except the Aeris one which I think is now available nowhere. So you can enjoy dressing up your Lightning for better combat efficiency or simply because you have waifu 4 laifu syndrome. Perfectly acceptable reasons.

------------

The gameplay. So while FFXIII had linear everything until Gran Pulse opened up to you, which was essentially a never-ending bland field of shortgrass and rocks filled with more floating rocks that provided you with generic kill quests, FFXIII-2 had more open zones filled with gates for you to open, and places to throw your mog at for pointless collectables, LR decides to combine all those together, yay! Well, what you get are 4 open areas, some being linear city streets and other being more open plains and deserts. There's side quests and stuff to do everywhere, but the trick is, they don't appear all the time. Remember when I said 13 days, well it's really 13 days to play in these zones. Some things only appear on certain days, certain times per day, etc. Think Persona. But with 13 longer days (optional 14, hint hint). What to do when you missed something? New Game + (beating the game also unlocks hard mode) unlocked by clearing the game or getting a game over, meaning you wasted 13 days chasing chocobos...yeah, you can actually game over if you screw up the days. All the typical JRPG content is here, dungeon-type things, battle arena-type things, questing, talking to people, talking to people at different times, walking, running, yep, yep, yep. The 13 day system may feel a bit restrictive, which to some extent it is. Heck, if you flee a fight (unless you're on easy), you lose an hour of that day. But they attempted to balance it out with the multiple playthroughs. Why get it all in one long playthrough, when you could do it in multiple shorter playthroughs? I don't know, design choice, hit or miss. Some things are only obtainable on the unlockable hard mode, so multiple playthrough was encouraged by the devs for sure.

-------------

TL;DR = Fans and critics call this is the weakest of the series, but there's some bias considering the fact they even decided to make it is an automatic -2 points to a lot of people. Everyone believes milking the boring cow too many times only yields (insert witty phrase to make point). But this is a solid title without a doubt. It's not better, but it's not that much worse. What it is, is different. Slightly refreshing combat, larger areas with more content in each to mess with, collecting items, etc, it's got it all. Games like this, you used to be able to get them all the time. Like every week there'd be one. But now, not so much. LR:FFXIII is a little bit nostalgic, a little bit cringe-worthy here and there to be honest, but it's a content-packed JRPG with pretty aesthetics, an eargasmic soundtrack, and lots of potential for great gameplay.

reviewText:
Runs as smooth as butter, I wish all companies optimised their games this well.
I'm a big fan of the Final Fantasy franchise, but hated XIII.
I went into this game without expectations, and if I don't compare it to other Final Fantasies then it's great.
The combat system is really unique and the amount of equipment available is incredible.
The story isn't as needlessly complicated as FFXIII and easy enough to understand for people who haven't played it.
If you think you'll like it or even just want to try something new, then go for it! It's really cheap compared to most games.
As a heads-up though: the controls can be pretty awkward. You won't be using the mouse at all, so I rebound all the keys around WASD like a MOBA, and then my right-hand is strictly reserved for camera and menu control. I found it much easier after making that small change.

reviewText:
Finally some good news for the Final Fantasy 13 Trilogy on Steam! It's a decent port everybody!

This port doesn't use a launcher to start the game but instead just starts the game up from the get go and if you hover your mouse near the top of the window you will get a drop down consisting of a Quit and Reboot option, Graphical settings and a choice of 2 button layouts (where X and O (or A and B) get switched around).
The game supports 30 FPS (Fixed mode) or 60 FPS (Dynamic mode). It also has graphics options including: Shaders, Shadows, Bloom, Lighting and others but you can only choose from two options from each; Standard (For lower end PCs) and Advanced (For higher end PCs).

I have never had a problem with the other two ports so I cannot talk from experience here but I have had no problems with this port of Lightning Returns and I have been playing it at its maximum graphic settings (that is until someone realeases graphical mods for it eventually).
To be honest the only problem I have had is a very, very tiny drop in FPS for about 1-2 seconds when walking into a crowded area but it goes back to 60 FPS before you can really make a comment about it.

Overall it is a very well ported game in comparison to the other two FF13 games that have come to Steam and I am very happy with it.
And to make it even better it comes with the majority of the DLC and it only costs £11! It's a steal not to buy it!

Side Note: If you do experience problems with this port; please keep in mind that it *may* be your computer and not the game and also I am pretty sure there will eventually be solutions to issues in the community hub for this game!

reviewText:
This port works much better than the previous titles in the XIII series. The FPS stays at a very smooth 60 frames per second, and there are no bugs that the console versions didn't have. It probably has even less bugs, in fact.

There aren't very many options for graphics, basically a low/high setting for shadows, lighting, etc. However, there is no doubt that the port looks incredible regardless. It really does crap on the console version.

Overall, I would recommend this port to any FF fan.

reviewText:
Yes... YESS.. AT LAST THE SAVIOUR HAS RETURNED FOR THE THIRTTEENTH TI- alright moving onwards.

PROS:
+Amazing Performance on a dated GPU, 670 with 2gigs of Vram, with every setting cranked up to the maximum gives me a solid 60 fps with the few drops here and there, but nothing game breaking
+Amazing gameplay, the best kind of ATB in a Final Fantasy game and a stylish one to boot
+Customization out the wazoo with a large variety of armor and weapons to switch between from, allows for very flexible gameplay
+I can finally fulfill my dream of playing dressup with barbie dolls in a video game without people knowing about it
+As for the game world, its open and decently sized, lots of quests, lots of dialogue, plenty of exploration.

CONS:
-Limited Resolution Options. For those few with 1080p+ monitors, you'll find no support here. Wait for a fix.
-Limited graphics options - There's not even a launcher or ingame menu, its built into the top of the game window, just like an emulator.
-The Story is absolute ♥♥♥. Seriously, the series isn't known for its great story or characters but they're literally being shoved into predictable archetypes and the story from what I've played so far is extremely limited and boring, but the story has never been core to the XIII series.
-The in-game countdown clock may give some players majoras mask syndrome, thankfully there are ways around this but you're still racing a game clock.
-Lightning's assets" aren't defined enough and some of the costumes
recommended: look very goofy and bizarre.\n\nI'd personally rank it above XIII and XIII-2. It's also half the size of both
hoursPlayed: only 14 gigs with both audio languages installed. For $20

reviewText:
This is it, the contraversial conclusion to this contraversial trilogy.  And boy is it something.  Those who didn't like the first game didn't like it because of the linear gameplay for most of the game and while this is true, it's pretty much the only aspect of the game that wasn't absolutely brilliant.  The story is fantastic, the characters are awesome, the music and graphics splendid and combat system unbelievable.  Then comes the second game.  It was still sort of linear (or at least as linear as you can make a game about time traveling), but a lot less so.  Despite losing one character in battles, the combat system was still somehow improved.  Story even better, graphics even better, music even better, characters even better.  Even the DLC were brilliant.

Finally, the conclusion.  How could it get any better?  This time they threw linearity out of the window; you can do anything in any order.  Other than that, they again somehow managed to improve the combat despite removing yet another character.  It also manages to answer every question you might have gathered throughout the previous games, and delivers a story that's simply perfect and ends up with an ending that will just... blow your mind.

To recap, the XIII trilogy is a serie that quickly learned from its mistakes and steadily improved at an exponential rate before reaching perfection in its climactic ending.

reviewText:
In short, it's everything I wanted: smoother performance than the previous 2 games in the trilogy, no ugly launcher when you start the game (yay!), beautiful visuals and music, and fun gameplay.

While still not perfect, it is clear that at least in some ways Square Enix is learning how to make a proper PC port and they deserve some credit for that.

If you like the other games in the XIII series, I highly recommend this. The in-game time limit really isn't a thing to be stressed about. You'll have plenty of time for everything. Just spam the Chronostasis ability fairly often and you're good to go.

Oh, and it has one of the best soundtracks I've heard in a Final Fantasy game, and that is saying A LOT.

reviewText:
I want to like this game so much... it really does have a lot going for it, but it still has to be my LEAST favorite FF game.  Mostly this is due to the focus put on time in this game.  After finishing the first day of thirteen, I can honestly say, I felt like I literally accomplished nothing.  The timing thing does away with what is, in my opinion, the stongest appeal of the FF franchise: I have as much time as I want to build up, explore the world... I can take my time and soak it in.  This game however, makes me feel like I have to skip through dialogue and not take time to learn about the world and the backstory.

Add to that the incessant talking by Hope telling you the same thing every fifteen seconds.... UGHHH...

The combat feels pointless as it doen't contribute to your experience as in other FF games and the enemies are absurdly hard (Schrodinger cat literally one-shot killed me; for something you can randomly run into in the middle of town, that is unforgivable), so I actually spent all my time avoiding combat -- again, the anithesis of what FF games are about.

This game is total head-scratcher to me.  I'm not sure why the developers would take everything that makes Final Fantasy what  it is and remove it?  Especially at the end of a trilogy!

Extremely dissappointed with this game.  It had a ton of potential.

reviewText:
I want this review to be a word of caution in contrast to the weirdly overwhelming amount of reviews praising the performance (this review only deals with the performance issues, I've played the game on the Xbox360 and enjoyed, so I would recommend it solely from a gameplay perspective).

The game seems to run fine for some people (constant 60fps), others like myself seem to be less lucky (60fps in battle, drops to 28fps in the busier parts of some cities). There doesn't seem to be a common factor yet which results in the lower framerate, with there even being people with the exact same specs getting very different results.

I personally have an AMD FX6300 cpu and a GTX750ti which should be sufficient. However on the forums you can find posts of people with high end machines (both Intel and AMD) getting the same issues as I have, while some people with more modest systems can get a constant 60 fps.

So as a word of warning, know that you are taking a gamble if you pick this up.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying three things. First, this is a major step forward from Square on FF ports, i have nothing to complain about the port. Second, i've played almost every FF there is, but this one is probably the worst one, in every aspect. Third, this is only my opinion, it's not something written in stone.

What i think is the worst aspect of the game is the combat. Some people might all it complex, others might say it has strategy, to me is just annoying and bad. The staggering system, that i think was best on FF XIII, is really annoying and takes away some freedom during battles, since the so called strategy is basically doing what you have to do to stagger that monster and then beat him up. Then you have the fact that most fight are useless, since you don't get any xp, potions, etc... you only get monster items and sometimes attacks or spells.
The enemies are also very few in variety, and you will find yourselves fighting the same enemy countless times, even on different zones.
The schemata is a downgrade of FF X-2 fighting style, in my opinion, and i found it way less fun.

Then you have the story, god the aweful story. I really liked FF XIII story, and didn't dislike XIII-2 story even if basically had little to do with XIII, but this one, was a pain to sit through. In my opinion theys should have stop on XIII-2, and even that one was not necessary, because this game's story felt like somthing they tought on the spot. Serah was a more interesting character than Lightning is on this game. She's like bipolar, she's loosing human's emotions and only cares about saving her sister, but at the same time she cares for the people she's saving. She's a contradition. The only character that i enjoyed was Lumina, at least she was interesting.

The side quests are nice, and way more interesting than the main story, and that's kind of sad. When the optional content (here isn't much optional since it's where you'll get upgrades to your stats) is better than the main game you did something wrong.

The countdown is a nice touch and is not much of a pressure, but you will still keep an eye on the clock.

I gotta be honest, i gave up on the last boss, not because is hard (i love Dark Souls, so i don't really mind hard bosses), but because i didn't find any motivation to keep trying.I didn't like the story, i hated the combat system and it was the only FF that i couldn't get 1 minute of joy to play, i was only playing it for the love i have for FF. But to me, this isn't a game i can enjoy playing, but as i said, it might be for other people.


So basically, in my opinion, this is a great port, way better than XIII or XIII-2 technically speaking, but it's a bad game having the story and the gameplay in consideration.

reviewText:
I'm going to keep this simple. The game it's self is pretty fun, the combat system is engaging and the most annoying aspect of FFXIII has been removed (the vast majority of your party, who except for Fang and Sazh, were obnoxious). However, that being said, I'm probably going to request a refund. The online only nonsense is unacceptable in a singleplayer game.

Pros:
Graphic options are decent if not as granular as most enthusiasts would like
At 60FPS, gameplay is quite fluid
Performance seems pretty good though I'm not sure how a lower end system would fair
Gameplay is really enjoyable, lots of tactical options to keep a player invested
All the console DLC made it over except for the Aeris Costume

Cons:
Aeris costume was omitted for no discernable reason
Graphics have not improved in any meaningful way from the console versions aside from Resolution,  better shadows, improved depth of field and anti aliasing. The character models are still fairly low poly, textures are still abysmal, and environment models are still embarrasingly low poly with obvious UV mapping errors to boot.
Has a completely arbitrary online only requirement (*Steam Cloud needs to be active in order to start this game.)
Arbitrary resolutions (i.e. 1440p, 4k, etc) are not supported, only maxes out at 1080p
Loadtimes are still incredibly slow, even on an SSD

My specs (if they matter):
Intel i7 5820k @ 3.8Ghz
MSI  X99S Gaming 7
32GB HyperX Fury DDR4 @ 2666mhz
EVGA GTX 980Ti
500GB Crucial BX100 SSD
voteText: 11 of 30 people (37%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The big killer here that makes me never want to play this again is Square's continued poor port jobbing that makes this game lag and stutter constantly like FF13 and 13-2 did. I got this for $15 at gmg but this is the last time I ever buy a Square game for PC, ever. The lag stuttering is bad and constantly distracts. It is hard core lag-slowdown-stuttering that is inexcusable but expected from Square. They are the bad port masters and this one buddy boy it shows it. It's wicked and angering. I should have known better than to buy this. Square has made me ill for years and this is just the last straw. They get no more support from me because they just do not care about their PC side of their games since 95% of their profits come from consoles. I suppose I wouldn't either.

Even though I am a huge FF fan, my favs being 7 and 12, this one just rubs me the wrong way in several ways. The combat just is imo not very good for a FF game. The 13 day time limit is not fun at all. It reminds me of Dead Rising 2 where if you fail to complete the main mission in time you can start over with your saved stats. I don't want to do that in any game, ever. I just feel very stressed and rushed while playing. Hopefully this is the last time they ever put a time limit in a FF game. I felt so incredibly rushed, especially with Hope chiming into my earpiece every couple minutes telling me to hurry up, that while on the first real main mission where you have to find the pass code symbols I got stuck and couldn't find the fourth one, which in itself is incredibly stupid mission gameplay for any game let alone a FF game. It was in no way fun at all. Without the help of a Youtube guide I would probably have never figured it out because I didn't know you could set the time to wake up at a inn to the next day. I thought if the day ended then you failed the mission, since earlier it had snapped me out of the mission to take me back to the main base when the day ended. It is confusing but i figured it out.

Even more confusing is the gear system and discovering robots early on that have what feels like billions of hp and take me about 5 minutes to beat per battle doesn't help. It says they are weak against lightning but aero and blizzard do twice as much dmg to them than lightning does. It says use lightning to stagger them but lightning, no matter how many times I cast it, won't stagger them. The schemata system is awkward to say the least. Should I have a fire spell in the red schemata slot, a lightning in the yellow slot, and blizzard in the blue? Or can I do like one person I read online and make the red assault, the yellow for debuffs, and put all magic spells in the blue schemata? Holy ♥♥♥♥ man what do I do! lol.

Don't get me wrong, the more I'm playing the more I think that I might be getting the hang of it. I may just restart the game on easy and try that since normal is hard like folks have said. Then again probably not since, poor performance aside, this game absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing blows.

Pros:
Good graphics
Characters
Fun move switching (when it works right)

Neutral:
the combat

Cons:
Runs like garbage
Time constraints
Unbeatable enemies in the first area
Enemies in the first area that take 5 minutes to kill each time you fight one

Not my FF I remember from 1 through 14 (all the 13's blow ♥♥♥). I dont like the time limit and the schema system at all. Who knows, maybe I will get used to it and change my review, if I can force myself to play it again.

5.5/10

reviewText:
I'm giving it an negative review because there are still fundamental issues with port that existed in XIII and XIII-2 that never been resolved.  Performance is better than XIII-2. I only recommend this game for those who really want to play Lightning Returns on PC, however should be avoided for PC gamers with high-end systems who expect quality.

Pros:
- It's Lightning Returns on PC
- Playable
- Pretty stable, only had two crashes for over 30hrs of game-play. Crashes maybe due to playing at 4k with memory hack.

Cons:
- Capped at 1080p resolution, even though there's a memory hack that proves the game runs okay at 4k resolution.
- Choppy frame-rate when the game loads assets.  Commonly happens when roaming the world and in cut-scenes.
- Cannot run game off-line
- Some NPCs have awful textures.
- No full-screen mode, have to play windowed or borderless windowed.
- Still fixed frame-rates with in-game frame-pacer, however not as aggressive as XIII and XIII-2.

Tested System: Windows 10 64-bit, i7 3930k @ 4.6Ghz, Titan X, Samsung 840 evo SSD, 16 GB ram.

reviewText:
Before reading my review, I want to make it known that my hours clocked in as recorded by steam is about 40 hours short of my actual play time, since I was playing in offline mode for most of the game. As proof, look at my achievements and youll see ive compelted the game.

Lightning returns, but not with a bang but with the liquid ♥♥♥♥♥.

Honestly, this game is terrible. Not in terms of optimization and configuration, because lets be honest here if you playing a port of a game a year or more older and from japan most of you probably dont expect much better than what the console release did. In that form it is surpisingly better, being able to give 60 fps during cutscenes and battles, higher resolutions than just 720 and 1080, and other settings for a better experience, however the frames take a marked hit while in the overworld. Apparently this was an issue even in the ps3 release since it was rushed out the door before the 8th gen consoles came around.

The gameplay however is just a complete, confused mess. The game has a doomsday clock feature where you have to complete objectives with in 13 days before the world ends. A minute in the doom clock is 3 seconds in real time, and by extension an hour goes by after 2 minutes. I didnt think this was a problem at first, but make no mistake, unless youre gifted with luck, you NEED a guide to be able to get everything done with in that time frame. Some quests are hidden, some are failable if not completed quick enough, others are missable and while in other rpg's it would normally just mean the loss of a weapon or item of some sort, in this game it means your weaker before the end game. This game does not have a level or exp system, instead growth is given from quests you do in the game, meaning that any quests you miss means your weaker when fighting a boss, or worse, the end game boss.

The doomsday clock also takes away from one of the bigger elements that rpg games usually have, that being exploration. Normally in other rpg's youd be able to explore areas, discover secrets, talk to npcs and discover things as you go along, however the clock makes the beautiful visuals impossible to take in, to the point that I have to read what npc's are saying as i run to the next objective. This relates to my earlier point about quests, since the limited time frame you have to complete objectives, yet are still expected to talk to npc's to start quests makes you have to plan out ever move you make before you begin each day in the game. Granted the one thing the game has to make completing quests easier is a feature called chronostasis, which pauses the clock for about 1 minue real time. This can be done so long as you have enough eradia points, which can be refilled by killing monsters.

About fighting monsters however, that is where the game is the most dim. The battles use an active time battle (here on our called atb) system similar to the previous final fantasy 13 games where actions take up atb points, though the typical action such as guard or attack take up very little points. Its complicated by the fact that you have 3 atb guages. Each guage is linked to a schemata, that being a set up of 4 abilites, a garb, weapon and shield. A garb is the clothing lightning wears that also grants auto abilites but also locks one or two abilites, in practice similar to the job systems of previous final fantasy games. You switch between garbs in battle to have access to abilties you have set, such as an attack, a guard, a magic attack, etc. Though this could have been a fun way to shake things up, it only adds another layer of confusion to the gameplay. The atb guages fill rather slowly while in battle and at times you will standing waiting for the guages to to fill before making another move, that is unless you plan ahead and manage every action you take. When the enemies in this game are tanks that at times can take for ever to kill, it adds a pointless way of wasting time to a game that could otherwise move at a faster pace. Dont be surprised when a chunk of your hp was just taken when you meant to switch garbs and press the command button for guard, but accidentally switched to a different garb instead and used an abiltiy you would have otherwise wanted to save for later. Locked garb abilites for that matter means that abilites assigned to a button cannot be placed elsewhere on your list of commands, just to make it more difficulty for you muscle memory.

The game is further complicated by an ability system that makes it highly difficult to have a proper set up. Abilites come in different types, such as different attack abilites like heavy slash, elemental atacks, blitz attacks and the like, but also come in levels, from 1 to 5. Dont be surprised if later your ability list is swamped with loads of abilities that you dont know what to do with. The ui for the list is terible as well, even by sorting, it says alot that couldnt add a ui to sort by ability type. The ability system which could have been interesting like that used in kingdom hearts birth by sleep is made pointlessly difficult to understand and honestly quite a chore if not for the level system, since youre also expected to synthesize abilities, which require in game currency as well as a limited pool of items you get from killing enemies. For that matter, the garbs i mentioned earlier have locked abilities.

As for enemies, there are very few unique enemies in the game, There is less than 50 actually, including bosses, if you dont count last ones. Last ones are much stronger versions of 31 of the enemies in the game which appear after killing a certain number of that monster. After its killed, thats it, that monster will never appear again during your current playthrough. My biggest gripe with this is that such a complicated battle system, with an even more complicated ability system, seems wasted on such limited content.

And to make matters worse, later enemies you fight can do hefty damage. In rpgs this is normally not an issue, just heal up and keep going. Actually scratch that, there is no cure spell other than curaga which uses your limited eradia points, and the only other two ways are using mediguard, an ability thay blocks attacks and reocovers hp at a snails pace, or by using recovery items which you have a very limited number of which you can hold at one time. Your supposed to be able to trade blows and do damage to tanky enemies through out the game yet some how still guard, which isnt perfect since residual damage will go through and slowly chip you bit by bit, and are expected to do this over the course of multiple battles as you complete quests or main objectives. For that matter i was at a loss at what to do when fighting the first boss. The first boss does way to damage, I did way to little and my guard ability didnt exactly do a good job of guarding. At this point I should mention perfect guarding, which a function of using the guard ability in which if I used the guard command right before the enemy attack connects, much more damage will be blocked while also possibly staggering the enemey. Staggering means the enemy will be be idle for a short amount of time and take more damage. The problem with this is that even on normal, the window for perfect blocking is small. VERY small. If youre a guarding master in dark souls, then this game will be a piece of cake for you. How ever for first time players new to the battle system, being expected to know how to perfect gaurd when im barely on the first boss its just to extreme. Perhaps if the window was bigger on normal difficulty and made smaller in hard, then i could appreciate it as a mechanic for people who want a challenge, but for now, if I wanted to play a clunkier dark souls, then ill just ♥♥♥♥ing play dark souls.

Thank god for easy mode

reviewText: This game puts you on a timer, has scripted/timed events you have to find (or use a guide), and you can permanently fail events too. This wouldn't be so bad except that often the game has mini-games that are terrible, like stealth mobs who can see you through objects and that have no indicators of their view distance (which seems to be extreme). Also, you can't even save-scum to try again because the game has an auto-save feature that is clearly designed to make players have to live with failures.\n\nHaving said that, it's beautiful and if you aren't a completionist who goes nuts not being able to get all the goodies without completely restarting the game, this is a really interesting battle and itemization system that looks quite good on PC (even if the maximum resolution is weirdly 1920x1080).

reviewText:
I put a good 200 hours into this game on PS3 when it came out and I hope it's PC version serves me the same if not more enjoyment.

The Pros are wide:
-Female Protag who isn't forced into some pointless romance.
-Lesbians.
-Gorgeous world with easy to understand side quests.
-Well paced battles.
- Improvements to graphics from the original console versions.
-Engaging story with lovable characters.
- Extra DLC garbs I didn't see in the PS3 version.

Cons:
-Hope needs to shut up once in a while.
-FPS drops in cities.
-Poor mouse support.
-They fixed the dog glitch.
-I think at some point I got stuck on a cat NPC for a good 2 minutes.
-People still compare this game to FF7 despite it being completely different. Lightning is NOT a female Cloud.
-NO TONBERRIES.


This entire trillogy gets so much hate for no good reason, all because it's different than what's the norm for gameplay, while I'd disagree that this is a GOOD case of dummed down" battles. This isn't some RE5/RE6 level crap
date: this direction is a GOOD change for this game and honestly works with the narative.\n\nI totally recomend playing all three titles if you can."

reviewText:
tl;dr+ decent gameplay; almost action game-esque
+ collecting different outfits, weapons and shields
+ quasi open world
+ interesting side stories
+ a girl asked me to find her green doll. I brought her a red doll. She started laughing hysterically and went insane. The game told me her soul was now lost forever.

- main story is completely inane
- pointless and annoying time limit
- framerate is still terrible

I'm really torn on this one.

On the one hand the gameplay is pretty decent and I would definitely lie if I said I didn't have fun with this game. Finding and changing between different costumes (surprisingly few of them are metal bikinis!) and weapon/ shield/ ability sets really motivated me to continue playing and exploring. Battles still mostly revolve around the stagger system which has a lot more depth this time around. More often than not you won't be able to dish out any meaningful damage on your opponents until you finally stagger them. However the conditions to do so vary from enemy to enemy. Sometimes you have to attack using a specific element, or use only physical or magical attacks respectively, other times you have to wait for them to attack you in a particular manner (like wait till they raise their weapon and stand on one leg) and then block/ dodge and counterattack or knock them over during the wind up. Part of me wishes they would have turned this into a proper action game (like Devil May Cry) or an action-RPG (like the Tales of series) because it certainly feels like those at times if it weren't for the lack of direct control. But, in the end, it's still fine the way it is.
The only thing I didn't like gameplaywise was the timelimit. In fact I absolutely hate the whole idea. It doesn't even make sense from a storytelling perspective. Because apparently ever since what happened in XIII-2 the world itself has been slowly dying over the span of hundreds of years. But only in the last 13 days God decides to bring back Lightning to collect some souls for him. Like, he really couldn't have done that a little bit sooner...?
And now from a gameplay perspective, why would you ever design an open world RPG that more often than not asks you to run from one side of the map the other, and then limit the time you're allowed to explore all these areas? Even moreso when it's constantly shoved in our faces (Really. Hope never ever shuts up and reminds you - I think - every ingame hour which is about three minutes in real time that you're supposed to 'hurry up!').
Now, what most people will tell you, though, is that the time limit hardly even matters. And that's completely true. But, you know what? That ultimately makes it even worse, in my opinion. Because when the game constantly prompts you to speedrun through the game, you're most likely going to hurry from plot marker to plot marker and NPC to NPC to finish as many story and side quests as you can before you run out of time". But in doing so you inevitably run out of things to do about halfway through the game
date: which means you now actually have to purposely waste time until you reach the final day to trigger the final story quest. That's just bad game design and so unnecessary as it really doesn't add anything to the gameplay or the story.\n\nThen again

reviewText:
Been playing this game for over 70 hrs. now and I don't think I can't stop myself from playing this over and over.
At first I thought this game was gonna tie me tight on schedule due to the story line of the world is gonna end in the 13 days but after I got a hang on how to manage time and learn how to use EP ability instead of game will end in 20 - 30 hrs. as I expected, it got me playing over 40 hrs. just to get end this game normal mode.

For battle system I think it was a lot better than FFXIII and FFXIII-2. When I start playing this game I thought I just walk in stagger the enemy and then pound thier HP down like I did in earlier FFXIII series but it differents. Every enemy I face in the game have different way to stagger them and since I only have only 12 ability to work(3 schematas , 4 each) with instead of a lot of number like in the past and don't forget about guarding. Eevery enemy I face have at least one way or another to get a huge chunk of your HP if you don't guard against its attack. For example when I face nibblet in the first time I thought like Oh what's a cute little monster" and then "thud" I have to say good bye to good chunk of my HP so that's what make this real time ATB system very interesting.

For side quest and farming. There are a ton of side quest to do to keep you occupied until the last day come for sure
but sometime it throw me off schedule sometime. Farming in this game is fun until the extinction system kick in. I think this is making farming very interesting since you can't just farming all day like old time because monster now can come to extinction so it make me have to come up with other plan when one monster come to extinction.

So far playing on the Hard mode NG+ now all I can say is This game was a blast."

reviewText:
They're learning...

This is the first square game I have encountered that has actually made a sound effort to supporting other controllers, or at the very least has been written not to look at drivers before the controllers I am actually using, last remnant, ff13 and ff 13 2 do this, and I always have to disable a driver or update some sort of controller thing to get it to work. I don't know how many of you care abot that, but I do. Unfortunately these drivers seem to forget they support controllers in any sort of stress or sleep, So I literally have to lean my remote on the sticks to get them to keep working. It's ugly, but if they're making an effort... Hopefully we'll see some actual success by the time 15 comes around.

Also, it may or may not run better, but there's way less going on on here than the older ones. So it's smooth, s nice, plays well and doesn't crash aside from the controllers.

As for the game... It's hard to take in, There's tons of things to do, and people to know, but no time. I switched to easy so I could stop time in infinite chains and actually get to enjoy the game. Though monsters like omega reaver make me want to flip out. also, even with dlc gear, it seems really hard to understand and You're literally building a party out of one person and stretching her thin. It's interesting and new, but I miss having other targets for enemies to hit... Hopefully the chocobo will play that role.

Otherwise, great game so far. Can't really review it because it's a port. Butruns good and they're trying to fix their silly controller support issues... Here's hoping they actually do.

reviewText:
Now that the always online requirement has been fixed I'm repurchasing the game and changing my review to reflect my new opinions. Although my play time at the moment is very short I spent upwards of 80 hours on the Xbox 360 version.

The story is pretty good, I felt that it was a satisfying end to the trilogy. If you haven't played the other games or haven't paid attention to the story so far then it will be pretty hard to follow, so I recommend playing them first. Some of the dialogue is a little cheesy, but no more so than in the first two.

The combat system is very different in this installment. It is much more intense and fast paced and will probably appeal a lot more to those that had a problem with the combat system of the first two. The open world aspect offers a lot more to do and explore as well. You can do many parts of the story in whatever order you want, so the game feels a lot less restricted and linear.

Many people are also wary of the clock aspect of this game, and I don't blame them. I generally hate being timed in games, the most notable exception for me being the clock in Majora's Mask. But after 80 hours I can safely add this game to the list. Its presence encourages you to plan out your quests, and the availability of certain events at certain times adds a fun layer of complexity. Part of the reason it works so well is that there really isn't a huge penalty for running out of time. Unlike Majora's Mask, the only thing you lose is your progress on the story. All quest completion will reset, but you get to keep all your items and abilities and whatnot. Plus it's pretty easy to beat all the main quests without running out of time. Completing quests also increases how much time you have left before the end of the world, and you can get up to 13 total in-game days. Don't let the presence of the clock be the factor that keeps you from trying out this game.

Overall, I really loved this game. I spent a ton of time on it and even got all of the achievements. I haven't spent a ton of time on this particular port, but from what I've seen it's a significant improvement over the console versions and it has a ton of graphics options. More than likely if you didn't like the first two 13's then you probably won't like this one either, but this is also the one you are the most likely to enjoy out of the three. Take from that what you will.


Old Review:

I love this game. I played it on the Xbox 360 for upward of 80 hours and took the time to get all the achievements. I was really looking forward to getting it on here and I bought it as soon as it was available, but I just got finished requesting a refund. This game needlessly forces the user to be online and connected to the steam cloud, and I don't want to support that always online DRM practice. This is a single player game with no online features, I mean come on now. There was no reason to ruin this great port with this crap. I encourage everyone who feels the same way to also request a refund so we can get the message across.

If Square Enix fixes this, I will happily repurchase the game and change my review.

reviewText:
Very fun, recommended.  I enjoyed this game so much that I completed 100% of the achievements just to ekk out every bit of game-play possible.

In this game you can upgrade your abilities (skills) and completely customize what schema you want to use.  I found that replicating what FF13/13-2 did worked out best for my gaming experience.  You can use three different groups; one as commander (melee), two as ravager (mage), and the third schema as sentinel (tank)/saboteur (debuffs) hybrid.    Following are my final set-ups that beat 99% of the game on normal mode, with the exception of a few switches to battle a couple of the final bosses.

Garb Commander: Soldier of Peace
Weapon: Masamune
Shield: Blasphemy
Accessories: Tiger's Emblem, Dawn Gauntlets
Adornment: Killer Shades
Abilities: Shadownbind, Attack, Heavy Slash, Mediguard
Why use this Schema? Leveled up Heavy Slash turns Artemis's Pierce into a one turn killing machine.  Alternatively use Mediguard to life-up.

Garb Ravager: Spira's Summoner
Weapon: Chaos's Revenge
Shield: Summoner's Shield
Accessories: Falcon Charm, Sniper's Gloves
Adornment: White Mage's Hat
Abilities: Elementa Lv. ★, Mediguard, Magnet, *
Why use this Schema? Elementa Lv. ★ will simply destroy 99% of the game. Alternatively use Mediguard to life-up.  Never found much else to use in the other two slots that was worth ATB Vs. Elementa, besides perhaps magnet and then something like fire or air depending on the enemy.

Garb Sentinel/Saboteur: Guardian Corps
Weapon: Blazefire Saber
Shield: Noblesse Veronique
Accessories: Preta Hood, Runic Ring
Adornment: Black Mage's Hood
Abilities: Deshell, Deprotect, Imperil, Mediguard
Why use this Schema? Those accessories will make you immune to magic attacks.  This is my default garb, so when the battle starts you can cast Deshell and Imperil onto target then smash them with Elementa.  Cast Deprotect before hitting with Heavy Slash.  Mediguard for life-up.  Alternatively switch to Guard Glove & Ghostly Hood accessories when fighting heavy physical enemies.  Also switch Imperil with Poison for some bosses.

Since the PC version of Lightning returns gives you all DLC for free (turn on DLC in the options and buy them for free in the rewards screen) most of these garbs are already available to you... starting out I did use Cloud's SOLDIER 1st Class in place of the commander's Soldier of Peace garb (along with his weapon/shield.)  The Guardian Corps and Blazefire Saber are unlocked for free also if you have a FF13 save file.

reviewText:
I put a good 200 hours into this game on PS3 when it came out and I hope it's PC version serves me the same if not more enjoyment.

The Pros are wide:
-Female Protag who isn't forced into some pointless romance.
-Lesbians.
-Gorgeous world with easy to understand side quests.
-Well paced battles.
- Improvements to graphics from the original console versions.
-Engaging story with lovable characters.
- Extra DLC garbs I didn't see in the PS3 version.

Cons:
-Hope needs to shut up once in a while.
-FPS drops in cities.
-Poor mouse support.
-They fixed the dog glitch.
-I think at some point I got stuck on a cat NPC for a good 2 minutes.
-People still compare this game to FF7 despite it being completely different. Lightning is NOT a female Cloud.
-NO TONBERRIES.


This entire trillogy gets so much hate for no good reason, all because it's different than what's the norm for gameplay, while I'd disagree that this is a GOOD case of dummed down" battles. This isn't some RE5/RE6 level crap
date: this direction is a GOOD change for this game and honestly works with the narative.\n\nI totally recomend playing all three titles if you can."

reviewText:
Certainly the best game of the trilogy, and worth playing even without having played the first two games.
Great combat system that requires some getting into with very customizable outfits and attack setup.
Story is interesting enough, and there's enough incentive to try and get through as many side-quests as possible before your 13 days run out. The desire to unlock all the costumes, weapons, shields and ornaments drives me forward to complete all the quests.
The game also has an excellent soundtrack, and the nice musical touches when using certain included DLC costumes is very cool.

My only complaint is the frequent framedrops in the cities that's very annoying, especially when you need to run from one part of the city to another several times

reviewText:
I won't say I'm much of a fan when it comes to FFXIII in general but Lightning Returns managed to make some changes that made the final installment pretty fun to play. It's nowhere near being a classic in the FF franchise but that's ok.

After being pretty bummed out by the second game in the series, I was pretty happy with the way this game turned out. The voice acting/story/characters are still pretty low points but not much was going to change from the previous games. The gameplay changes were what interested me the most. The time limit mechanic actually being pretty cool and less invasive than one might think.

FPS was also all over the place for me, along with some random crashes in certain areas. Annoying but workable.

Overall I give this game a minor recommendation for those looking to finish off the FXIII series.
