voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is the best PC port from the FFXIII series so far. There is some choppiness from loading in some of the larger city areas, but battles and everything else runs fine for the most part. There's no need to worry about technical issues like there has been for FFXIII and FFXIII-2, previously.

The gameplay is action-oriented this time, with a focus on timing your attacks and blocks during battle that is new to the series. The game in general has an emphasis on keeping things moving, rather than taking your time to think and explore. I am an old-school turn-based RPG fan, and it wasn't so action-based that I couldn't enjoy playing. I haven't found a battle so far that required timing skills to succeed, as long as I have setup Lightning's equipment effectively before-hand so that I had enough HP to survive despite my poor hand-eye-coordination, for example.

The story is bonkers, but that's just how FF games are now. It's a good thing the gameplay is fun enough that it doesn't really matter.

reviewText:
This is a good game but I highly recommend that you play the first to games, FFXIII and FFXIII-2, to get a better understanding on the story. Granted FFXIII is bland, the next game improved on the weak spots and this game sets a good ending to the series.

Main points on this game are:
-This is a great port from consoles. Supports tons of monitor resolutions.
-Does support controllers, I used my xbox 360 one. Only thing that didn't work is vibration.
-When you beat the game you can keep your items/skills and start New Game+ on hard.

The cons of this game are:
-This game is hard and has a steep learning curve. If you start other games like this on normal, *START ON EASY*. You   NEED the ingame abilities and real life skills before going onto normal. Going from easy to newgame+ hard is doable.
-The timer along with the ingame time zones make you feel rushed. This really isn't true because you can finish every quest and have a few days left over.

This is a overall good game and I would recommend it.

reviewText:
The best game of the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy! This conclusion to the trilogy has better, more fast-paced gameplay, more clothing, more accessories, and more lore than the first two games. Speaking of lore, the main quests and sidequests are a joy to do because they give you more insight into the world, and quite a few of them provide comic relief!

The name of the game in Lightning Returns is the Stagger gauge. Many enemies will be difficult (or impossible) to defeat unless staggered. Character development will quickly focus on builds (called schemata") designed to stagger enemies and keep them that way.

I strongly recommend starting the game in Easy mode
date: as in Normal mode you cannot regenerate HP and enemies are far more difficult to kill.\n\nThis game features a monster genocide option. If you kill enough of a certain species
recommended: you will permanently remove that monster from the game. This option makes it easier to explore areas
hoursPlayed: but I found the emptiness... disturbing.\n\nDo not worry about managing your time in this game
voteText: because it features New Game Plus. You will not only be able to finish the quests you couldn't
helpfulPercent: but do over every quest in the game if you so desire. This will allow you to reach apocalyptic levels of might as a one-woman army. Of course
votesHelpful: you can use New Game Plus just to run around and take in the view!\n\nIf you have never played any game from the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy
votesTotal: I strongly recommend Lightning Returns. Like the leading lady herself
votesFunny: this game stands on its own with its gorgeous graphics
commentsCount: beautiful music and rich story."

reviewText: I am utterly baffled at how good this game is. I did not expect great things after FF13 and I bought this knowing it was very different gameplay-wise, but it was still surprising how incredible this game actually is. My only complaints are the quality of some of the models - see: dogs, cats - the odd way the game handles enemy distribution - rendering some enemies far too rare to find or only in very specific areas - and the manual movement in battle being so slow that I'm not sure it wasn't a last minute decision, making manual evasion - not guarding, actually getting out of the way of attacks - a chore and very unclear - by far, the best way to get away from an enemy is guard cancelling magic - and making use of attacks that require specific positioning - such as Blindside, which needs you to get behind enemies - very, very tough.\n\nI initially had some issues with how some places only open up at specific times or NPCs only show up at specific times, but these go away fairly quickly with how much time the game gives you, specially if you use a lot of Chronostasis - I'm done with all main quests, all but two NG+ sidequests and nearly every canvas of prayers' requests and I still have half of the time the game gives you.

reviewText:
Now that the always online requirement has been fixed I'm repurchasing the game and changing my review to reflect my new opinions. Although my play time at the moment is very short I spent upwards of 80 hours on the Xbox 360 version.

The story is pretty good, I felt that it was a satisfying end to the trilogy. If you haven't played the other games or haven't paid attention to the story so far then it will be pretty hard to follow, so I recommend playing them first. Some of the dialogue is a little cheesy, but no more so than in the first two.

The combat system is very different in this installment. It is much more intense and fast paced and will probably appeal a lot more to those that had a problem with the combat system of the first two. The open world aspect offers a lot more to do and explore as well. You can do many parts of the story in whatever order you want, so the game feels a lot less restricted and linear.

Many people are also wary of the clock aspect of this game, and I don't blame them. I generally hate being timed in games, the most notable exception for me being the clock in Majora's Mask. But after 80 hours I can safely add this game to the list. Its presence encourages you to plan out your quests, and the availability of certain events at certain times adds a fun layer of complexity. Part of the reason it works so well is that there really isn't a huge penalty for running out of time. Unlike Majora's Mask, the only thing you lose is your progress on the story. All quest completion will reset, but you get to keep all your items and abilities and whatnot. Plus it's pretty easy to beat all the main quests without running out of time. Completing quests also increases how much time you have left before the end of the world, and you can get up to 13 total in-game days. Don't let the presence of the clock be the factor that keeps you from trying out this game.

Overall, I really loved this game. I spent a ton of time on it and even got all of the achievements. I haven't spent a ton of time on this particular port, but from what I've seen it's a significant improvement over the console versions and it has a ton of graphics options. More than likely if you didn't like the first two 13's then you probably won't like this one either, but this is also the one you are the most likely to enjoy out of the three. Take from that what you will.


Old Review:

I love this game. I played it on the Xbox 360 for upward of 80 hours and took the time to get all the achievements. I was really looking forward to getting it on here and I bought it as soon as it was available, but I just got finished requesting a refund. This game needlessly forces the user to be online and connected to the steam cloud, and I don't want to support that always online DRM practice. This is a single player game with no online features, I mean come on now. There was no reason to ruin this great port with this crap. I encourage everyone who feels the same way to also request a refund so we can get the message across.

If Square Enix fixes this, I will happily repurchase the game and change my review.

Not only does this feel like the old Final Fantasies like all of XIII, but they just keep improving the combat and refining their storytelling craft. LOVED THIS game and the other two. XIII-2 probably being one of my favorite JRPGs since Chrono Trigger. Now I can rest knowing this will be a full-on classic amongst fans. Just keep making the ports just as good as this or better...just don't forget the rumble next time.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I do not follow the franchise and I have not played the previous games (both XIII and XIII-2), so I may be able to give a feedback out from a different perspective.

PROS:

OST -
The music is absolutely amazing, I'm not really into music but all of soundtracks are quite enjoyable (I like Paradigm Shift the most)

Customization -
The system is great, being able to change the outfit of your choice as well as having the option to customize most part of it's colors is great, I did spend some time figuring out what color and adornment the outfit would look better with. Not to mention the weapon/shield diversity.

Battle -
I enjoyed every single monster encounter I had in this game, the battle musics are catchy and the ATB system certainly is different for me, at first it was somewhat confusing and yet frustrating, but once you get used to it you just enjoy it. The skill effects look amazing too.

Main Story -
Simple and straightforward. The game is mostly focused on questing than anything else. Unfortunately there's nothing much to mention in this, it IS good though.

Sub-quest -
Even though most of them are quite bland with all the 'kill this' or 'gather this' that most generic RPGs have, the rewards actually make up for it. As an achiever, collecting items and prizes is one of the most rewarding things to me. I even got upset once when I realised that I have missed a quest and I cannot take it any longer.

Challenges:
Bosses are quite challenging, you rather be well prepared or you have to know what you are actually doing in order to take them down. I haven't beaten the superbosses yet and I think I won't, I'm leaving that for the NG+, once I get geared enough.


CONS:

Controls -
I do not own a controller so I had to play on the keyboard and it's upsetting. The game has so many commands that it is impossible to reach all of them with ease during the gameplay, I have totally given up on using the camera movement one, for example.

Overworld -
I really expected the game to be actually bigger. Having only four different zones did not really satiate me.



I have defeated the last boss once however I moved back to my previous save state to finish the remaining quests. I can say that having spent 60 hours over the first playthrough was enough time to enjoy what the game has to offer.
Right now I'm at Medium difficulty and I'm totally salivating over the NG+ Hard difficulty. I'm also interested on getting the previous games as well.


Do I recommend this game? TOTALLY.

reviewText:
Having played through it once on PS3 I could already say it's a good game. The port improves on graphics, framerate and loading times, making it much more enjoyable to play on PC.

How well it stands when this is the first FFXIII game, I can not say. As a conclusion to the trilogy it's very satisfying. If you don't care about the story, mechanically it's speed questing with a good flow due to the design and a fast combat system that rewards tactics over grind.

All in all, it's a very unique game and worth the investment in time and money.

reviewText:
Very fun, recommended.  I enjoyed this game so much that I completed 100% of the achievements just to ekk out every bit of game-play possible.

In this game you can upgrade your abilities (skills) and completely customize what schema you want to use.  I found that replicating what FF13/13-2 did worked out best for my gaming experience.  You can use three different groups; one as commander (melee), two as ravager (mage), and the third schema as sentinel (tank)/saboteur (debuffs) hybrid.    Following are my final set-ups that beat 99% of the game on normal mode, with the exception of a few switches to battle a couple of the final bosses.

Garb Commander: Soldier of Peace
Weapon: Masamune
Shield: Blasphemy
Accessories: Tiger's Emblem, Dawn Gauntlets
Adornment: Killer Shades
Abilities: Shadownbind, Attack, Heavy Slash, Mediguard
Why use this Schema? Leveled up Heavy Slash turns Artemis's Pierce into a one turn killing machine.  Alternatively use Mediguard to life-up.

Garb Ravager: Spira's Summoner
Weapon: Chaos's Revenge
Shield: Summoner's Shield
Accessories: Falcon Charm, Sniper's Gloves
Adornment: White Mage's Hat
Abilities: Elementa Lv. ★, Mediguard, Magnet, *
Why use this Schema? Elementa Lv. ★ will simply destroy 99% of the game. Alternatively use Mediguard to life-up.  Never found much else to use in the other two slots that was worth ATB Vs. Elementa, besides perhaps magnet and then something like fire or air depending on the enemy.

Garb Sentinel/Saboteur: Guardian Corps
Weapon: Blazefire Saber
Shield: Noblesse Veronique
Accessories: Preta Hood, Runic Ring
Adornment: Black Mage's Hood
Abilities: Deshell, Deprotect, Imperil, Mediguard
Why use this Schema? Those accessories will make you immune to magic attacks.  This is my default garb, so when the battle starts you can cast Deshell and Imperil onto target then smash them with Elementa.  Cast Deprotect before hitting with Heavy Slash.  Mediguard for life-up.  Alternatively switch to Guard Glove & Ghostly Hood accessories when fighting heavy physical enemies.  Also switch Imperil with Poison for some bosses.

Since the PC version of Lightning returns gives you all DLC for free (turn on DLC in the options and buy them for free in the rewards screen) most of these garbs are already available to you... starting out I did use Cloud's SOLDIER 1st Class in place of the commander's Soldier of Peace garb (along with his weapon/shield.)  The Guardian Corps and Blazefire Saber are unlocked for free also if you have a FF13 save file.

reviewText:
Been playing this game for over 70 hrs. now and I don't think I can't stop myself from playing this over and over.
At first I thought this game was gonna tie me tight on schedule due to the story line of the world is gonna end in the 13 days but after I got a hang on how to manage time and learn how to use EP ability instead of game will end in 20 - 30 hrs. as I expected, it got me playing over 40 hrs. just to get end this game normal mode.

For battle system I think it was a lot better than FFXIII and FFXIII-2. When I start playing this game I thought I just walk in stagger the enemy and then pound thier HP down like I did in earlier FFXIII series but it differents. Every enemy I face in the game have different way to stagger them and since I only have only 12 ability to work(3 schematas , 4 each) with instead of a lot of number like in the past and don't forget about guarding. Eevery enemy I face have at least one way or another to get a huge chunk of your HP if you don't guard against its attack. For example when I face nibblet in the first time I thought like Oh what's a cute little monster" and then "thud" I have to say good bye to good chunk of my HP so that's what make this real time ATB system very interesting.

For side quest and farming. There are a ton of side quest to do to keep you occupied until the last day come for sure
but sometime it throw me off schedule sometime. Farming in this game is fun until the extinction system kick in. I think this is making farming very interesting since you can't just farming all day like old time because monster now can come to extinction so it make me have to come up with other plan when one monster come to extinction.

So far playing on the Hard mode NG+ now all I can say is This game was a blast."

reviewText:
As many of you know, this is the final chapter in the FFXIII series.

Is it worth buying? Yes. No question about it.

I recommend playing the first two games, first. Story wise, you'll be hard pressed to find better if you have actually followed the entire series. Yes, you can read a synopsis in the datalogs, but experiencing the journey first hand, wins every time.

Gameplay is good. Initially, I preferred the FFXIII-2 combat system, but I will say that in the end I found this system to be gratifying in it's own unique way. And it does a good job at making you feel like Lighning is now capable of combat on an entirely diffent scale than her friends(and herself) were in their previous story lines.  I was not a big fan of the clock countdown in the beginning, as I hate feeling like I'm under a time constraint. However, after having completed the game, I can tell you that there is no real time constraint. In the end, I was sleeping days away at the Inn's, as I had completed all the side quests. So take your time, and enjoy the journey and the atmosphere of the game.

I would recommend this game to all my friends irl, without any reservations.

reviewText:
I won't say I'm much of a fan when it comes to FFXIII in general but Lightning Returns managed to make some changes that made the final installment pretty fun to play. It's nowhere near being a classic in the FF franchise but that's ok.

After being pretty bummed out by the second game in the series, I was pretty happy with the way this game turned out. The voice acting/story/characters are still pretty low points but not much was going to change from the previous games. The gameplay changes were what interested me the most. The time limit mechanic actually being pretty cool and less invasive than one might think.

FPS was also all over the place for me, along with some random crashes in certain areas. Annoying but workable.

Overall I give this game a minor recommendation for those looking to finish off the FXIII series.

reviewText:
This is the best PC port from the FFXIII series so far. There is some choppiness from loading in some of the larger city areas, but battles and everything else runs fine for the most part. There's no need to worry about technical issues like there has been for FFXIII and FFXIII-2, previously.

The gameplay is action-oriented this time, with a focus on timing your attacks and blocks during battle that is new to the series. The game in general has an emphasis on keeping things moving, rather than taking your time to think and explore. I am an old-school turn-based RPG fan, and it wasn't so action-based that I couldn't enjoy playing. I haven't found a battle so far that required timing skills to succeed, as long as I have setup Lightning's equipment effectively before-hand so that I had enough HP to survive despite my poor hand-eye-coordination, for example.

The story is bonkers, but that's just how FF games are now. It's a good thing the gameplay is fun enough that it doesn't really matter.

reviewText:
The best game of the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy! This conclusion to the trilogy has better, more fast-paced gameplay, more clothing, more accessories, and more lore than the first two games. Speaking of lore, the main quests and sidequests are a joy to do because they give you more insight into the world, and quite a few of them provide comic relief!

The name of the game in Lightning Returns is the Stagger gauge. Many enemies will be difficult (or impossible) to defeat unless staggered. Character development will quickly focus on builds (called schemata") designed to stagger enemies and keep them that way.

I strongly recommend starting the game in Easy mode
date: as in Normal mode you cannot regenerate HP and enemies are far more difficult to kill.\n\nThis game features a monster genocide option. If you kill enough of a certain species
recommended: you will permanently remove that monster from the game. This option makes it easier to explore areas
hoursPlayed: but I found the emptiness... disturbing.\n\nDo not worry about managing your time in this game
voteText: because it features New Game Plus. You will not only be able to finish the quests you couldn't
helpfulPercent: but do over every quest in the game if you so desire. This will allow you to reach apocalyptic levels of might as a one-woman army. Of course
votesHelpful: you can use New Game Plus just to run around and take in the view!\n\nIf you have never played any game from the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy
votesTotal: I strongly recommend Lightning Returns. Like the leading lady herself
votesFunny: this game stands on its own with its gorgeous graphics
commentsCount: beautiful music and rich story."

reviewText:
This is a good game but I highly recommend that you play the first to games, FFXIII and FFXIII-2, to get a better understanding on the story. Granted FFXIII is bland, the next game improved on the weak spots and this game sets a good ending to the series.

Main points on this game are:
-This is a great port from consoles. Supports tons of monitor resolutions.
-Does support controllers, I used my xbox 360 one. Only thing that didn't work is vibration.
-When you beat the game you can keep your items/skills and start New Game+ on hard.

The cons of this game are:
-This game is hard and has a steep learning curve. If you start other games like this on normal, *START ON EASY*. You   NEED the ingame abilities and real life skills before going onto normal. Going from easy to newgame+ hard is doable.
-The timer along with the ingame time zones make you feel rushed. This really isn't true because you can finish every quest and have a few days left over.

This is a overall good game and I would recommend it.

reviewText:
I put off playing this game since I had originally played the first two games on the xbox.  By the time LR had been released I didn't think it looked very fun.  I really only wanted the story since this was the finale.  I built a good computer and found out that FF 13 was coming to steam.  So I replayed them on steam while waiting for the next one.  I never played LR until it came out on steam.

The story is split up from the start.  You get to pick where you want to start in terms of the story.  There are 4 different areas with 5 main storylines and a bunch of side quests.  Completing those main and side quest will reward you with base stats.  So you'll get stronger the more quests you complete.  The game is large so there is quite a bit of running around involved.

Unlike the other two games this game is on a timer.  12 in game days which in my first playthrough was way more than enough to get through the entire main story and almost all side quests.  So don't be stressed about the timer.  Also if you don't happen to make the timer there is the option to new game plus.  You'll keep all the stats and non key items you've earned.

I was very confused at first and frustrated trying to learn how exactly you are supposed to stagger enemies.  Not being able to see their stagger gauge unlike the previous games and just increasing the stagger gauge in general.  It took a while but once you learn the game is very fun.  It's basically the same as the previous games except increasing the gauge is different for every enemy.  Enemies stagger in levels, so basically after staggering an enemy once their condition changes.  They might be aplied debuffs such as deprotect or become vulnerable to certain debuffs and elements.  Some will stagger with a single perfect shield and some have to be staggered 4 times before you can even deal significant damage to them.

Other than that the game can be challenging at times and pretty technical.  It requires a lot of learning to deal with enemies and their attacks.  Perfect shielding and retaliating correctly to stagger them is a lot harder in this game than it sounds.  Especially if you're still learning the basics.  Just stick to it and it'll be a fun game.

reviewText: I am utterly baffled at how good this game is. I did not expect great things after FF13 and I bought this knowing it was very different gameplay-wise, but it was still surprising how incredible this game actually is. My only complaints are the quality of some of the models - see: dogs, cats - the odd way the game handles enemy distribution - rendering some enemies far too rare to find or only in very specific areas - and the manual movement in battle being so slow that I'm not sure it wasn't a last minute decision, making manual evasion - not guarding, actually getting out of the way of attacks - a chore and very unclear - by far, the best way to get away from an enemy is guard cancelling magic - and making use of attacks that require specific positioning - such as Blindside, which needs you to get behind enemies - very, very tough.\n\nI initially had some issues with how some places only open up at specific times or NPCs only show up at specific times, but these go away fairly quickly with how much time the game gives you, specially if you use a lot of Chronostasis - I'm done with all main quests, all but two NG+ sidequests and nearly every canvas of prayers' requests and I still have half of the time the game gives you.

reviewText:
The Goods:
+ The best PC port of the trilogy
+ Open world; to be able to explore around is big in RPG
+ Dressing up Lightning for status boosts is actually fun
+ Semi-real time combat; you actually need to time your blocks
+ Some really nice tracks in the OST

The Mehs:
- Bad storytelling; speaking too much in philosophical terms
- Status up relies on completing side-quests that are mostly not related to the story
- Limited character growth; can't really relate to the characters unless you are a Lightning fan
- The concept of a real-time time limit is not really necessary; you have more than enough time to complete almost all of the quests in one playthrough, yet you feel rushed because there are time-restricted areas. But in the end most players will end up with a couple of days with really nothing to do. The concept of doing the quests in any order you like is nice though.

As many of you know, this is the final chapter in the FFXIII series.

Is it worth buying? Yes. No question about it.

I recommend playing the first two games, first. Story wise, you'll be hard pressed to find better if you have actually followed the entire series. Yes, you can read a synopsis in the datalogs, but experiencing the journey first hand, wins every time.

Gameplay is good. Initially, I preferred the FFXIII-2 combat system, but I will say that in the end I found this system to be gratifying in it's own unique way. I was not a big fan of the clock countdown in the beginning, as I hate feeling like I'm under a time constraint. However, after having completed the game, I can tell you that there is no real time constraint. In the end, I was sleeping days away at the Inn's, as I had completed all the side quests. So take your time, and enjoy the journey and the atmosphere of the game.

I would recommend this game to all my friends irl, without any reservations.

reviewText:
Hands down, best game in the series. Great improvements over the last two games. I won't say much but the game made me occupied for 70 hours, and I love every second of it.

Gameplay is totally different from the last with the combat system having a total overhaul. I love the new system where there is no more just pressing one button and the new introduction of guarding requires precise timing. It made me sit on the edge of my seat and focused on the battle.

But the game do has flaws. Expect A LOT of backtracking. There is a steep learning curve at every bosses (which, for me, is kind of good), voice acting somehow became worse than before, the combat feels cheap once you acquired some very good abilities while I find myself never using most of other abilities, same thing with schematics, and the game feels restrictive when it comes to playtstyle (you WILL end up using a defensive set up).

But the pros outweigh the cons. I absolutely love tons of side quests and bits of lore here and there. I feel connections with the NPCs when I finish the quests and I definitely love dressing Lightning up in cute and sexy outfits.

Final boss is kind of meh, XIII-2 has a better final boss. But hey! Cauis Ballad is in it!

9/10. Would definitely save souls again.

reviewText:
Short Version:

Did you (somewhat) enjoy the previous entries from the 13 series? Want to see out it ends? Hop in! If not, stay clear.


Long Version:

Gameplay: Much like other side FF entries, LR takes the single party member more action oriented approach, as a lover of the ATB system, I actually quite enjoyed the focus on timing/element and had fun killing the variety of enemies (new and recurring). Aside from that, the game is a glorified single player MMO, fetch quest everywhere with a couple decent ones thrown in.

Sound: Lots of tracks from 13/13-2, some original other with sprinkles. Ambience tracks in towns felt good and almost no engrish rap/heavy metal songs. Once again, thumbs up for the japanese VA, I know little but just enough japanese to realise how deeply the translation changes (for the worse 100% of the time) the characters' persona.

Story: (this space was intentionally left blank) But seriously, characters are no more than cameos, main story is bland and repetitive, side characters... what side characters? If you (like me and so many others, felt 13's writing was bad, you'll find they can, unfortunately, make it way worse.

Graphics: They look GREAT, love Lighting's flowing hair, her giant head, her anorexic body, the fanservicy? bikini outfits, everything /s! Anyway, movies look beautiful, everything outside is pretty good and battles look cool, what you've come to expect about this graphics oriented Square-Enix.

reviewText:
I put off playing this game since I had originally played the first two games on the xbox.  By the time LR had been released I didn't think it looked very fun.  I really only wanted the story since this was the finale.  I built a good computer and found out that FF 13 was coming to steam.  So I replayed them on steam while waiting for the next one.  I never played LR until it came out on steam.

The story is split up from the start.  You get to pick where you want to start in terms of the story.  There are 4 different areas with 5 main storylines and a bunch of side quests.  Completing those main and side quest will reward you with base stats.  So you'll get stronger the more quests you complete.  The game is large so there is quite a bit of running around involved.

Unlike the other two games this game is on a timer.  12 in game days which in my first playthrough was way more than enough to get through the entire main story and almost all side quests.  So don't be stressed about the timer.  Also if you don't happen to make the timer there is the option to new game plus.  You'll keep all the stats and non key items you've earned.

I was very confused at first and frustrated trying to learn how exactly you are supposed to stagger enemies.  Not being able to see their stagger gauge unlike the previous games and just increasing the stagger gauge in general.  It took a while but once you learn the game is very fun.  It's basically the same as the previous games except increasing the gauge is different for every enemy.  Enemies stagger in levels, so basically after staggering an enemy once their condition changes.  They might be aplied debuffs such as deprotect or become vulnerable to certain debuffs and elements.  Some will stagger with a single perfect shield and some have to be staggered 4 times before you can even deal significant damage to them.

Other than that the game can be challenging at times and pretty technical.  It requires a lot of learning to deal with enemies and their attacks.  Perfect shielding and retaliating correctly to stagger them is a lot harder in this game than it sounds.  Especially if you're still learning the basics.  Just stick to it and it'll be a fun game.

reviewText:
I got this game on sales and definitely got alot more than what I paid for!

The last Final Fantasy game that I played was FF9 which was on PS1 so I was hesistant to get it lest I didn't like it but I'm glad I did.

80 hours into the game and I've just completed it on normal mode clearing every single quests and bosses.

PROS:
1)Although this is a trilogy of FF13 and FF13-2 ,You DON'T HAVE to play them to understand the game. (This was my main concern before I decided to get it or not)

2)You can save your game anywhere, anytime! (Maybe it's just me but you'll need to reach a savepoint back then in FF9 on PS1 ._.)

3)You can build your own Lightning. Dress her, power her up with different schemetas with different skills up to your own discretion. You can even customize your own colours on the clothes.

4)I like the new battle system where you can fully control Lightning, her movements, timing of skills etc. It's awesomely satisfying executing a perfect block or evading at the last minute.

5)Good news Chocobo lovers, you can ride on your own Chocobo again in this game.

6)You can kill monsters until they go extinct, that's kinda great when you dont run into mobs every few seconds.

7)You can outrun monsters when you dont feel like fighting them or they aren't the mob that you are hunting for.

CONS:
1)There's a new time system on this series which many players will find it tedious and stressed to complete quests right at the beginning.

But the only thing I hate about it is that certain quests can only be done withing a certain time range, e.g 7pm -4am. Even if you talk to the npc by 1 min late, you'll have to come back the next day.

Tho i would say dont worry about time because Lightning has a skill called 'Chronostasis' which actually allows you to freeze time. When you are out in the field with alot of monsters or monsters which gives you alot of EP(which is needed to cast 'Chronostasis') you can basically freeze time until you decided to stop hunting. You can also cast it in town.

I cleared every single main/side quests, killed every optional bosses/monsters and STILL can afford to afk a whole day away because there is basically nothing left to do except for the last boss fight.

NOTE: In game time =/= Real time, every 1 min in-game = 3 seconds in real life.

2)You will need to refer to online guides for some quests because you will waste alot of time figuring them out on your first try.

Even though I cleared the game on my first try, I'm still looking forward to a new game+ on hard mode where I will retain my items and abilities.

Overall I'll rate this game a 4/5* for keeping me entertained for the past month. :D

reviewText: Like Final Fantasy XIII, Lightning Returns isn't a bad game, but i was very disappointed with it. The best aspect of this game is definitely the combat system, mixing the XIII and XIII-2 style with a more action-RPG style, but being neither of those in the end. It's fun to play, but somewhat cluncky. You have 3 garbs in which you assign 4 abilities (for each face button), and using them consumes your ATB. You'll need to switch often (with the shoulder buttons) to ensure that you have actions to perform and don't get stuck without options. The garbs and abilities are highly customizable, which is a plus. The combat isn't great, but it's good. The rest of the game however, is mediocre. This time you have an open world to roam, but it's bland and you only have 3 settings: 2 cities, forest and desert with ruins. That's it. Sounds good, but in practice means little. And then there's the time limit mechanic. I hate it. I admit that the game gives you plenty of time to do all the main quests and plenty of side quests, but if you want to do everything then the time limit will freak you out. And speaking of side quests, that's how you get stronger this time. Fighting enemies gives you less rewards, and sometimes is a bad ideia to fight, making the new combat system less important. What i really hate about this game is the way it's designed: the game almost forces you to play multiple playthroughs, especially if you're a completionist. Even if there wasn't a time limit, you must replay the game at least 3 times to collect everything" (it's very subjective here). Problem is

reviewText:
LRFF13? 13FFLR? F1L3FR? I don't know. Game's great, though. I would recommend this even to people that didn't bother with the first two FF13 games, as it follows a different story and has totally different gameplay.

LR uses an interesting ATB system similar to FFX-2, where you can swap your abilities on the fly. Need to guard? Switch to your defensive role. Want to burst an enemy with magic? Set up a devastating sorceress kit.

The game has a time limit, but it's very fair and I finished the main pre-finale story with about a third of the game time left. This let me pursue sidequests and other activities at my leisure. So, I wouldn't worry about that at all.

Best bits:
+The battle system feels unique, flexible, and is a joy to set up new builds for
+Lumina is a wonderful villain who I loved to hate
+The game doesn't take itself too seriously, allowing for a fun world despite a dreary scenario

Meh bits:
-While Hope has some great lines, he feels under-utilized as a character who had a huge presence in the first two games (and seemed like he WAS going to in this one)
-Wandering around the world can feel very tiresome, even with some ease-of-transport options put in (teleports, chocobo)
-Final boss has some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t stagger resistance, making it not as engaging a fight as it could have been
